column5:
n.教練；經濟艙；(火車)客車車廂；四輪馬車
v.指導；訓練
column6:
(1) The football coach was criticized by the local paper.
(2) The coach is bringing on some girls in the reserve team.
(3) Only soft drinks are complimentary in coach.
(4) The coach was full so a relief was put on.
(5) The coach bears the royal coat of arms.
(6) Mr.White will coach our team for the boat race.
column7:
(1) 這位足球教練受到了當地報紙的批評。
(2) 教練正教導預備隊的女孩們練球。
(3) 在經濟艙內,只有軟性飲料是免費的。
(4) 長途汽車已滿員，所以增開了一輛。
(5) 這輛大馬車上有王室的盾形紋章。
(6) 懷特先生要來訓練我們隊以備戰划船比賽。
column8: Nowadays, we mostly think of a coach as someone who trains a team, but it can also refer to a vehicle, such as a horse-drawn coach or coach bus (the kind with a bathroom in the back).
column9: The first meaning of coach was in the mid-16th Century for a carriage, probably named for Kocs, the Hungarian village where they were first made and called kocsi. In the mid-19th Century, the name was given to railway cars, and nowadays the least expensive travel class is described as "coach." It's thought that the idea of a coach as a teacher came about because of the idea that a coach "carries" a student to success through his or her teaching.
column11:
1[N-COUNT 可數名詞]教練 A coach is someone who trains a person or team of people in a particular sport.

  • Tony Woodcock has joined German amateur team SC Brueck as coach.

    托尼·伍德科克加盟德國業餘隊SC布呂克隊擔任教練。

2[VERB 動詞]為…當教練；訓練；指導 When someone coaches a person or a team, they help them to become better at a particular sport.
  [V n to n]
  [V n]

  • Beckenbauer coached the West Germans to success in the World Cup final in Italy...

    貝肯鮑爾執教西德隊，帶領他們在意大利世界盃決賽中獲勝。

  • I had coached the Alliance team for some time.

    我曾在聯盟隊擔任過一段時間的教練。

3[N-COUNT 可數名詞](體育隊的)主教練 A coach is a person who is in charge of a sports team.
  [mainly AM 主美]
    in BRIT, usually use 英國英語通常用 manager
    4[N-COUNT 可數名詞](棒球運動中，站在一壘或三壘附近，給其他選手信號的)跑壘指揮員 In baseball, a coach is a member of a team who stands near the first or third base, and gives signals to other members of the team who are on bases and are trying to score.
      [AM 美]
      5[N-COUNT 可數名詞](尤指輔導備考的)私人教師，輔導教師 A coach is someone who gives people special teaching in a particular subject, especially in order to prepare them for an examination.
        [oft n N]

      • What you need is a drama coach.

        你需要的是一位戲劇輔導老師。

      6[VERB 動詞]給…補習；(尤指)為…輔導備考 If you coach someone, you give them special teaching in a particular subject, especially in order to prepare them for an examination.
        [V n]

      • He gently coached me in French.

        他為我補習法語，態度十分溫和。

      7[N-COUNT 可數名詞]長途汽車；長途大巴 A coach is a large, comfortable bus that carries passengers on long journeys.
        [also by N]
        [BRIT 英]

      • As we headed back to Calais, the coach was badly delayed by roadworks...

        返回加來時，由於道路施工，我們乘坐的長途大巴嚴重誤點。

      • I hate travelling by coach.

        我不喜歡坐長途汽車。

      in AM, use 美國英語用 bus
      8[N-COUNT 可數名詞](火車的)旅客車廂 A coach is one of the separate sections of a train that carries passengers.
        [BRIT 英]

      • The train was an elaborate affair of sixteen coaches.

        這列火車由16節車廂組成，設計複雜精巧。

      in AM, use 美國英語用 car
      9[N-COUNT 可數名詞]四輪大馬車，公共馬車(舊時用於載客，現在英國等國仍用於慶典場合) A coach is an enclosed vehicle with four wheels which is pulled by horses, and in which people used to travel. Coaches are still used for ceremonial events in some countries, such as Britain.

column5: vi. vt. (流體, 尤指血液)凝結
column6:
(1) blood had coagulated round the edges of the gash.
(2) adrenalin coagulates the blood.
(3) As the egg whites cook, they coagulate and rise to the surface…
column7:
(1) 血液在傷口周邊凝結了.
(2) 腎上腺素使血液凝結.

column5: v.合併；聯合；接合
column6:
(1) The views of party leaders coalesced to form a coherent policy.
(2) I hope patriotism can coalesce under this kind of idea and express itself.
column7:
(1) 黨的領導人的各種觀點已統一為一致的政策。
(2) 願愛國主義在這樣的理念下凝聚起來，表達出來。
column8: Waiting for a plan to come together? You're waiting for it to coalesce. Coalesce is when different elements of something join together and become one.
column9: In coalesce, you see co-, which should tell you the word means "together." The other half of the word comes from alescere, a Latin verb meaning "to grow up." So if you are trying to start up a photography club at school, once you have an advisor, some interested students and support from the administration, things will be coalescing or growing together. Another way to remember that? An adolescent is one who is growing. A lot!
column11:
1[VERB 動詞]聯合；合併 If two or more things coalesce, they come together and form a larger group or system.
  [V prep]
  [V]
  [FORMAL 正式]

  • Cities, if unrestricted, tend to coalesce into bigger and bigger conurbations...

    如果不加限制，城市往往會聯合發展成越來越大的集合城市。

  • His sporting and political interests coalesced admirably in his writing about climbing.

    他在寫登山的文章中，把自己對體育和政治的興趣完美地結合了起來。

column5: n.結合；聯合；聯盟
column6:
(1) There is no coalition of members of the economy.
(2) The two parties have united to form a coalition.
(3) After the election, the coalition fragmented.
column7:
(1) 這種經濟的各部門之間不存在聯合。
(2) 這兩個黨已結成聯盟。
(3) 選舉之後，聯盟瓦解了
column8: A coalition is a group of people who join together for a common cause, like a coalition you form with other skateboarders who want to convince your town to build a skate park.
column9: The noun coalition comes from the Latin word coalitiō, meaning "to grow together." Often, the people and groups that form coalitions have different backgrounds but come together because they share a goal. For example, parents, teachers, business owners, and city council members might form a coalition to build a teen center, just as nations that do not agree on all issues might form a coalition because they all want peace.
column11:
1[N-COUNT 可數名詞]聯合政府 A coalition is a government consisting of people from two or more political parties.
  [oft N n]

  • Since June the country has had a coalition government...

    從6月份起，該國一直由一個聯合政府執掌政權。

  • It took five months for the coalition to agree on and publish a medium-term economic programme.

    聯合政府花了5個月的時間才達成並公佈了一項中期經濟計劃。

2[N-COUNT 可數名詞](政黨、社團等的)同盟，聯盟 A coalition is a group consisting of people from different political or social groups who are co-operating to achieve a particular aim.
  [oft N of n]

  • He had been opposed by a coalition of about 50 civil rights, women's and Latino organizations.

    大約有50個民權組織、女性社團和拉丁裔社團聯合起來反對他。

column5: adj.粗糙的；粗俗的；非精製的
column6:
(1) The medicine powder is too coarse, keep grinding it.
(2) His coarse manners shocked everyone.
column7:
(1) 藥面太粗了，再磨細點。
(2) 他的粗魯的舉止使每個人震驚。
column8: Coarse can mean rough to the touch or vulgar. It's good to have coarse sand paper, but not good to have coarse manners.
column9: Do you lick your dinner plate, wipe your nose on your sleeve, and generally behave like an oaf? No, of course not. You're the kind of person who reads online dictionaries. But if you did do any of things, you'd be coarse — that is, unrefined, boorish, and downright vulgar. Coarse can apply to a wide variety of things other than behavior. If something is of poor quality, cheap and inferior, it's considered coarse.
column11:
1[ADJ-GRADED 能被表示程度的副詞或介詞詞組修飾的形容詞](質地)粗的，粗糙的；粗織的 Coarse things have a rough texture because they consist of thick threads or large pieces.

  • ...a jacket made of very coarse cloth.

    粗布製成的夾克

  • ...a beach of coarse sand.

    粗沙海灘

coarsely

  • ...coarsely ground black pepper.

    粗研黑胡椒粉

2[ADJ-GRADED 能被表示程度的副詞或介詞詞組修飾的形容詞](言行)粗魯的，粗俗的 If you describe someone as coarse, you mean that he or she talks and behaves in a rude and offensive way.
  [disapproval]

  • The soldiers did not bother to moderate their coarse humour in her presence.

    她在的時候，士兵們還是照樣說粗俗的笑話，都懶得收斂。

coarsely

  • The women laughed coarsely at some vulgar joke.

    聽到個有點下流的笑話，女人們放肆地笑了起來。

coarseness

  • The coarseness of her cursing amazed the workmen.

    她罵人的那些粗話讓工人們大吃一驚。

column5: v.哄；誘騙；靈巧慢慢地做
column6:
(1) Mother ran after me, murmuring fine words to coax me.
(2) I've come back to coax a respectable sum of money out of an aged woman who happens also to be my mother.
column7:
(1) 母親在後面小跑著，嘴裡還在不斷地說著好話哄我。
(2) 我回來的目的，是從一個老太婆手上誘騙一筆數目可觀的金錢，她碰巧是我母親。
column8: When you coax someone, you try to convince him gently, with pleasant words and maybe a little flattery. You』ll have to be patient, as you can』t rush someone you』re trying to coax.
column9: When you coax, you have to be nice about it – you can』t threaten or force. You put on a little charm and gently urge, so that the person or thing is happy about being coaxed. You might coax the runaway elephant back into the zoo by patting her gently and talking into her ear. If you wake up with a terrible bedhead, you might coax your hair back into place with the help of a little hair gel and a comb.
column11:
1[VERB 動詞](用好話)勸誘，哄 If you coax someone into doing something, you gently try to persuade them to do it.
  [V n prep]
  [V n to-inf]
  [Also V n]

  • After lunch, she watched, listened and coaxed Bobby into talking about himself...

    吃過午飯，她照看著博比，聽他說話，哄他說說自己的事。

  • The government coaxed them to give up their strike by promising them temporary residence permits.

    政府承諾給他們發放暫住證，誘哄他們放棄罷工。

2[VERB 動詞]連哄帶勸地得到 If you coax something such as information out of someone, you gently persuade them to give it to you.
  [V n out of/from n]

  • The WPC talked yesterday of her role in trying to coax vital information from the young victim...

    昨天，這名女警談到自己在誘導年輕的受害人說出重要信息的過程中所起的作用。

  • It took Louis until Easter to coax a grudging consent from the French King.

    路易斯連哄帶騙，直到復活節才勉強得到法國國王的許可。

3[VERB 動詞]小心地擺弄(機器或裝置) If you coax a machine or device into doing something, you make it work by operating it very slowly and gently.
  [V n prep]

  • He would stride on stage then proceed to coax the sweetest possible sounds out of his violin...

    他會大步走上舞台，然後輕輕地拉他的小提琴，奏出美妙動聽的曲調。

  • He was delighted to coax the monoplane to 330 m.p.h.

    這架單翼飛機在他的擺弄下時速達到了每小時330英里，他感到很高興。

column5: n.蟑螂
column6:
(1) He finds the cockroach is grinning.
(2) She screamed when she found a cockroach in her bed.
column7:
(1) 他發現那頭蟑螂正咧著嘴笑著。
(2) 她在床上找到一隻蟑螂時大聲尖叫。
column11: 1[N-COUNT 可數名詞]蟑螂 A cockroach is a large brown insect that is sometimes found in warm places or where food is kept.

column5:
n.繭；繭狀物
v.包圍；包裹
column6:
(1) Silkworms make cocoons.
(2) A cocoon is a kind of silk covering made by an insect.
(3) The children tore the cocoon open to see if there was a pupa.
(4) Families cocoon around the TV set most evenings.
column7:
(1) 蠶做繭。
(2) 蠶繭是由昆蟲製造的一種由絲組成的外包層。
(3) 孩子們撕開蠶繭看看裡面有沒有蛹。
(4) 好多家庭大部分晚上都圍在電視機前看電視。
column8: Cocoon means a silky web spun around the larvae of many insects; it can also mean a form a self-protection for humans. Famously, caterpillars emerge from their cocoons as butterflies.
column9: For some people, their house is a cocoon, a cozy retreat from which they can escape the world. They cocoon themselves away for a whole weekend, reading, drinking tea, not answering email or the phone. Another word for cocoon is "chrysalis," but only in the context of insects.
column11:
1[N-COUNT 可數名詞]繭；(昆蟲的)卵袋 A cocoon is a covering of silky threads that the larvae of moths and other insects make for themselves before they grow into adults.
    2[N-COUNT 可數名詞]繭狀包裹物 If you are in a cocoon of something, you are wrapped up in it or surrounded by it.
      [usu N of n]

    • He stood there in a cocoon of golden light.

      他站在那兒，一柱金光籠罩著他。

    3[N-COUNT 可數名詞]給人安全感的環境；保護層 If you are living in a cocoon, you are in an environment in which you feel protected and safe, and sometimes isolated from everyday life.
      [usu N of n]

    • ...her innocent desire to envelop her beloved in a cocoon of love...

      她想要把心上人包裹在愛中的天真想法

    • Even though we're living together we walk around in this cocoon of silence...

      儘管我們生活在一起，但卻形同路人。

    • You cannot live in a cocoon and overlook these facts.

      你不能自己縮在套子裡而忽略這些事實。

    4[VERB 動詞]把…保護起來；把…隔絕開來 If something cocoons you from something, it protects you or isolates you from it.
      [V n from/in n]
      [V pron-refl in n]

    • There is nowhere to hide when things go wrong, no organisation to cocoon you from blame...

      如果出了問題，根本無處可躲，沒有哪個機構會庇護你，讓你免受指責。

    • The playwright cocooned himself in a world of pretence.

      這個劇作家與世隔絕，生活在一個虛幻的世界裡。

column5:
n.鱈魚
v.哄騙；愚弄
column6:
(1) The cod was salted away for future use.
(2) He bought a canned cod and a sandwich as supper.
column7:
(1) 鱈魚已用鹽醃起留著日後吃。
(2) 他買了一個鱈魚罐頭和一個三明治作晚飯。
column11:
1[N-VAR 可變名詞]鱈魚 Cod are a type of large edible fish.
  • Cod is this fish eaten as food.鱈魚肉

    • A Catalan speciality is to serve salt cod cold.

      冷盤鹹鱈魚是加泰羅尼亞的一道特色菜。

2[ADJ 形容詞]假的；仿真的；騙人的 You use cod to describe something which is not genuine and which is intended to deceive or amuse people by looking or sounding like the real thing.
  [ADJ n]
  [BRIT 英]

  • ...a cod documentary on what animals think of living in a zoo.

    講述動物如何看待動物園生活的搞笑偽紀錄片

column5: vt.強制；威脅
column6:
(1) You can't coerce her into obedience.
(2) Do you think there is any way that we can coerce them otherwise?
(3) His plan was to resist every effort to coerce him to the last ditch.
(4) The policy of the prohibition against using tortures to coerce a statement is provided clearly and definitely.
column7:
(1) 你不能強制她服從。
(2) 你認為我們有什麼辦法強迫他們不那樣嗎?
(3) 他的計劃就是要同那欺凌他的力量抵抗到底。
(4) 嚴禁逼供信政策明確規定了公安機關及其人員在訊問過程中不得刑訊逼供。
column8: You can bring a horse to water, but you can't make him drink. You can coerce — or pressure — someone to attend your office holiday party, but you can't make them have fun.
column9: If you're at a point where you feel like you need to coerce someone into doing something, it might be more civilized to just give up. To coerce is to manipulate, use aggressive arguments, pressure unfairly, or threaten — really, this isn't very civilized behavior, is it? Handy synonyms for this verb include force and pressure. In a gangster film, you might hear a character say he "put the squeeze" on someone — another way of saying he coerced them.
column11:
1[VERB 動詞]強制；脅迫；迫使 If you coerce someone into doing something, you make them do it, although they do not want to.
  [V n into -ing/n]
  [Also V n to-inf]
  [FORMAL 正式]

  • Potter had argued that the government coerced him into pleading guilty...

    波特辯稱是政府強迫他認罪的。

  • Clark had somehow been able to coerce Jenny into doing whatever he told her to do.

    不知是用什麼辦法，克拉克總能讓珍妮對他言聽計從。

column5: adj. (論點, 論據)清晰的; 合乎邏輯的; 有說服力的, 令人信服的
column6:
(1) He produced cogent reasons for the change of policy.
(2) There were perfectly cogent reasons why Julian Cavendish should be told of the Major's impending return.
column7: (1) 他對改變政策提出了充分的理由.

column5: adj.認識的；認知的；有認識力的
column6:
(1) Thinking in terms of dualisms is common in our cognitive culture.
(2) Linguistics is an important branch in cognitive science.
column7:
(1) 我們的認識文化通常具有兩重性思考。
(2) 語言學是認知科學的一個重要分支。
column8: If it's related to thinking, it's considered cognitive. Anxious parents might defend using flashcards with toddlers as "nurturing their cognitive development."
column9: The adjective, cognitive, comes from the Latin cognoscere "to get to know" and refers to the ability of the brain to think and reason as opposed to feel. A child's cognitive development is the growth in his or her ability to think and solve problems. Many English words that involve knowing and knowledge have cogn- in them such as cognizant "aware of" and recognize "to know someone in the present because you knew them from the past."
column11:
1[ADJ 形容詞]認識過程的；認知的 Cognitive means relating to the mental process involved in knowing, learning, and understanding things.
  [ADJ n]
  [TECHNICAL or FORMAL 術語或正式]

  • As children grow older, their cognitive processes become sharper.

    孩子們越長越大，他們的認知過程變得更為敏銳。

  • ...Vygotsky's theory of cognitive development.

    維果斯基的認知發展理論

column5: vi. 1. 粘合; 凝聚; 2. （指看法、 推理等）邏輯上銜接, 前後一致, 連貫
column6:
(1) he made the series of fictions cohere into a convincing sequence.
(2) this view does not cohere with their other beliefs.
(3) All the details are there and are correct but they don’t cohere.
column7:
(1) 他把這一連串想像拼湊在一起, 把它說成是事情的前因後果, 使人深信不疑。
(2) 這個觀點和他們其他的信念不一致。

column5: n.一致；連貫
column6:
(1) He was starkly unable to achieve coherence.
(2) This article lacks unity and coherence.
(3) Logical connectors is one of the major cohesive devices, it can achieve coherence in discourse.
column7:
(1) 他完全不能達到一致。
(2) 這篇文章層次不清。
(3) 邏輯連接詞是銜接的一種主要方式,能實現語篇的連貫。
column8: When something has coherence, all of its parts fit together well. An argument with coherence is logical and complete — with plenty of supporting facts.
column9: Coherence comes from a Latin word meaning 「to stick together. When you say policies, arguments and strategies are coherent, you』re praising them for making sense. Scientists are always looking for coherence in data to support their hypotheses. And coaches are always looking for coherence in their teams, so they don't fall apart.
column11:
1[N-UNCOUNT 不可數名詞]統一；一致性；連貫性 Coherence is a state or situation in which all the parts or ideas fit together well so that they form a united whole.

  • The anthology has a surprising sense of coherence.

    整本選集有著驚人的連貫性。

column5:
n.卷；圈；線圈
v.盤繞；捲成圈
column6:
(1) He passed me a coil of thread.
(2) The birds are entangled in the coil of a net.
(3) The burnt coil should be renewed.
(4) This is a double induction coil.
(5) The snake coiled itself around the tree.
(6) She coiled her hair at the back of her head.
(7) The shipmaster asked the sailors to coil the ropes down on the ground.
(8) Coil the rope up.
column7:
(1) 他遞給我一卷線。
(2) 鳥被纏在網圈裡了。
(3) 燒穿的線圈應換新的。
(4) 這是一對感應線圈。
(5) 蛇盤繞在樹上。
(6) 她把頭髮盤在腦後。
(7) 船長叫海員把纜繩盤在地上。
(8) 把繩盤繞起來。
column8: A coil is a spiral shape or a series of circles, each one inside another. You might see a coil of rope on a dock or coils of hair in a fancy hairdo.
column9: A snake naturally curls its body into a coil, and the end of a whip after it's been cracked tends to form a coil. To move in this way is also to coil, as when your cat coils around your leg or you coil a necklace around your finger. This verb form is the earliest meaning of coil, from the Middle French coillir, "to gather," with the Latin root colligere, "to gather together."
column11:
1[N-COUNT 可數名詞](繩子、金屬絲等繞成的)卷，圈 A coil of rope or wire is a length of it that has been wound into a series of loops.
  [oft N of n]

  • Tod shook his head angrily and slung the coil of rope over his shoulder...

    托德氣憤地搖了搖頭，然後把那卷繩子往肩上一搭。

  • The steel arrives at the factory in coils.

    鋼材被成卷地運到工廠。

2[N-COUNT 可數名詞]一卷；一圈 A coil is one loop in a series of loops.

  • Pythons kill by tightening their coils so that their victim cannot breathe.

    大蟒蛇緊緊盤繞獵物使之無法呼吸，從而殺死獵物。

3[N-COUNT 可數名詞](電路的)線圈 A coil is a thick spiral of wire through which an electrical current passes.
    4[N-COUNT 可數名詞](汽車發動機的)盤管 In a vehicle, the coil is the part on a petrol engine that sends electricity to the spark plugs.
      5[N-COUNT 可數名詞]子宮節育環；避孕環 The coil is a contraceptive device used by women. It is fitted inside a woman's womb, usually for several months or years.
        [usu the N in sing]
        6[V-ERG 及物/不及物動詞]卷；盤繞 If you coil something, you wind it into a series of loops or into the shape of a ring. If it coils around something, it forms loops or a ring.
          [V n]
          [V prep/adv]
          [V-ed]
          [V n P]
          [V-ed P]
          [Also V P n (not pron)]

        • He turned off the water and began to coil the hose...

          他關掉水龍頭，開始盤水管。

        • Louisa was dancing, spinning by herself, her skirt flying out and coiling around her feet...

          路易莎打著圈兒翩翩起舞，裙擺時而肆意飛揚，時而盤繞腳邊。

        • A huge rattlesnake lay coiled on the blanket.

          一條巨大的響尾蛇盤繞在毯子上。

        • Coil up means the same as coil .coil up 同 coil

          • Once we have the wire, we can coil it up into the shape of a spring...

            一旦有了金屬絲，我們就能把它捲成彈簧的形狀。

          • Her hair was coiled up on top of her head.

            她的頭髮盤在頭頂上。

column5:
n.硬幣；金錢
vt.鑄造（錢幣）；創造（新詞）
adj.硬幣的；投幣的
column6:
(1) He put a coin into the insertion slot.
(2) He paid me in coin.
(3) Father dug up an old coin in the garden.
(4) They were granted the right to coin money.
(5) The government has decided to coin more one-yuan pieces.
(6) Who coined the word "quiz" ?
(7) We'd better not coin terms that are intelligible to nobody.
(8) The reverse of the coin was stamped with an eagle.
(9) This is a coin washing machine.
column7:
(1) 他往投幣孔投入一枚硬幣。
(2) 他付給我的都是硬幣。
(3) 父親在花園裡掘出一枚古錢幣。
(4) 他們獲得鑄造錢幣的授權。
(5) 政府決定再多鑄造一些一元的硬幣。
(6) 誰創造的「quiz」這個詞呀？
(7) 我們最好不要生造誰也不懂的詞語。
(8) 硬幣的反面壓印的是一隻鷹。
(9) 這是一台投幣式洗衣機。
column8: If you coin a phrase, that means you come up with a new way to say something, like the person who coined "webizens" to describe people who constantly use the Internet.
column9: The verb coin literally refers to making coins, the change you probably have in your pocket. The word can be used in a broader sense — creating something new, usually something related to language. For example, you could coin a phrase or a new word for 「joke.」 The language authorities would be proud — unlike federal authorities if you tried to coin money. That kind of coining is a criminal offense.
column11:
1[N-COUNT 可數名詞]硬幣 A coin is a small piece of metal which is used as money.

  • ...50 pence coins.

    50便士的硬幣

  • ...Frederick's gold coin collection.

    弗雷德裡克收藏的金幣

2[VERB 動詞]新造，杜撰(單詞、短語) If you coin a word or a phrase, you are the first person to say it.
  [V n]

  • Jaron Lanier coined the term 'virtual reality' and pioneered its early development...

    傑倫·拉尼爾創造了「虛擬現實」這個詞，並成為推動其早期發展的先驅人物。

  • The word 'lunatic' was coined to describe people who went mad at the full moon.

    lunatic是個生造詞，用來形容月圓時發瘋的人。

3[VERB 動詞]暴富；很快地賺(錢) If you say that someone is coining it or is coining money, you are emphasizing that they are making a lot of money very quickly, often without really earning it.
  [V it]
  [V n]
  [V it P]
  [usu cont]
  [emphasis]
  [INFORMAL 非正式]

  • Many private colleges are coining it...

    很多私立大學正在大發其財。

  • One wine shop is coining money selling Wembley-label champagne.

    一家葡萄酒商店正在靠出售威麗牌子的香檳大把大把賺錢。

  • Coining in means the same as coining .coining in 同 coining

    • She's coining it in with a $10 million contract with Revlon.

      她靠與露華濃簽訂的一筆1,000萬美元的合同發了大財。

4[PHRASE 短語]用個雙關語；套用句老話 You say 'to coin a phrase' to show that you realize you are making a pun or using a cliche

  • Fifty local musicians have, to coin a phrase, banded together to form the Jazz Umbrella.

    50名當地的音樂家，用個雙關詞，「聯合起來」（band亦有「樂隊」之意）組成了「爵士樂大聯盟」。

5[PHRASE 短語]情況的另一面 You use the other side of the coin to mention a different aspect of a situation.
  [PHR with cl]

  • These findings are a reminder that low pay is the other side of the coin of falling unemployment.

    這些研究結果提醒人們，失業率下降的另一面是低薪。

6[PHRASE 短語]一個問題的兩方面 If you say that two things are two sides of the same coin, you mean that they are different ways of looking at or dealing with the same situation.
  [usu v-link PHR]

  • The minister reportedly stressed that economic and political reforms were two sides of the same coin.

    據報道，部長強調經濟改革和政治改革是一個問題的兩個方面。

column5: vi.一致；同時發生；符合
column6:
(1) They didn't coincide in opinion.
(2) Our opinions did not coincide on this case.
(3) My religious beliefs don't coincide with yours.
(4) Their stories coincided.
(5) The demonstration had been carefully stage-managed to coincide with the Prime Minister's visit.
(6) It's a pity our trips to New York don't coincide.
column7:
(1) 他們的意見不統一。
(2) 在這個案例上,我們的意見不一致。
(3) 我的宗教信仰跟你的不一樣。
(4) 他們的敘述一致.
(5) 這次示威活動事先作了精心安排，正好在首相訪問時進行。
(6) 真遺憾我們不能同一時間去紐約旅行。
column8: When things happen at the same time, they are said to coincide. Often, this is because they're intentionally coordinated––"the bake sale coincided with Parent Day"––but not always.
column9: Coincide can also mean happen together in other ways. "My mother's views on appropriate teen fashion do not always coincide with mine" is an uber tactful way to say she hates your clothes. You could also describe two roads coming together as coinciding––though it's more poetic to talk about when they diverge.
column11:
1[V-RECIP 相互動詞]巧合；同時發生 If one event coincides with another, they happen at the same time.
  [V with n]
  [pl-n V]

  • The exhibition coincides with the 50th anniversary of his death...

    展覽恰好在他逝世50週年之際舉行。

  • Although his mental illness had coincided with his war service it had not been caused by it...

    雖然他的精神病剛好在他參戰期間發作，但並不是由此引起的。

  • The beginning of the solar and lunar years coincided every 13 years.

    太陽年和太陰年的起始時間每13年重合一次。

2[V-RECIP 相互動詞](想法、利益等)一致，相符 If the ideas or interests of two or more people coincide, they are the same.
  [pl-n V]
  [V with n]

  • The kids' views on life don't always coincide, but they're not afraid of voicing their opinions...

    孩子們的人生觀並不總是一致，但他們敢於表達自己的觀點。

  • ...a case in which public and private interests coincide...

    一個公眾利益和私人利益一致的例子

  • He gave great encouragement to his students, especially if their passions happened to coincide with his own.

    他給予學生莫大的鼓勵，尤其是當他們與自己志趣相投時。

column5: vi.合作；通敵
column6:
(1) She collaborated with her sister/She and her sister collaborated on a biography of their father.
(2) We would ask you to collaborate with us.
(3) This supplier and I collaborate on certain points.
column7:
(1) 她和姐姐合作寫父親的傳記。
(2) 我們願意請你們和我們合作。
(3) 我與供應商有數方面或以上的合作。
column8: When you work together on shared goal, you collaborate. If you don't just split a project up evenly but work together on creating solutions, you collaborate.
column9: Inside the word you see co-labor, or "working together." Cooperation is simply splitting up the work and getting it done. Collaboration is when you brainstorm, create, and share possible solutions. During World War II, however, Nazi collaborators were sharing ideas with the wrong side. In today's pop music scene, collaboration means featuring a guest star on a record, and it's often a surefire way to boost sales.
column11:
1[V-RECIP 相互動詞]合作，協作(尤指著書或做研究) When one person or group collaborates with another, they work together, especially on a book or on some research.
  [V with n on/in n/-ing]
  [V with n]
  [pl-n V on/in n/-ing]
  [pl-n V]
  [Also pl-n V to-inf]

  • He collaborated with his son Michael on the English translation of a text on food production...

    他和兒子邁克爾合作，把一篇介紹食品生產的文章譯成了英文。

  • The government is urging Japan's firms to collaborate with foreigners.

    政府正在督促日本的公司進行更多的海外合作。

  • ...a place where professionals and amateurs collaborated in the making of music...

    一個專業人士和業餘愛好者合作創作音樂的地方

  • The two men met and agreed to collaborate.

    這兩個人見了面，並同意進行合作。

2[VERB 動詞]通（敵）；勾結(敵人) If someone collaborates with an enemy that is occupying their country during a war, they help them.
  [V with n]
  [Also V]
  [disapproval]

  • He was accused of having collaborated with the secret police.

    他被控與秘密警察勾結。

column5: n.拼貼；拼貼畫；雜燴
column6:
(1) Many zines tend to rely on comics, illustration, and collage.
(2) A collage of coloured paper covers a table top .
(3) That is only a collage of conflicting memories.
column7:
(1) 不少雜誌往往依靠漫畫，插圖，拼貼。
(2) 一副彩紙拼貼畫蓋在桌面上。
(3) 那只是破碎記憶的彙集。
column8: Have you ever cut out a bunch of pictures from magazines and pasted them together to make a big picture? If you have, you have made a collage.
column9: Collage came to English through French from the Greek word for glue, kolla, about 100 years ago. A collage is not only made from magazine pictures. In the world of fine art, it refers to a work made with various small objects sometimes with paint sometimes without. The word can also be used to mean a collection of different things. If it's very loud in your house, you might come home to a collage of sounds from the dog, the TV, your mom on the phone and your brother on the guitar. Years after you graduate, high school might just seem like a collage of memories.
column11:
1[N-COUNT 可數名詞](用彩色紙片、布塊粘貼而成的)拼貼畫 A collage is a picture that has been made by sticking pieces of coloured paper and cloth onto paper.
    2[N-UNCOUNT 不可數名詞]拼貼藝術 Collage is the method of making pictures by sticking pieces of coloured paper and cloth onto paper.
      3[N-COUNT 可數名詞](風格、特性迥異的事物構成的)大雜燴 You can refer to something that has been made by combining a number of very different things as a collage of a particular kind.
        [usu N of n]

      • Rego's work is a rich collage of 20th-century painting styles.

        瑞格的作品糅合了20世紀各種繪畫風格。

column5: vi.碰撞；互撞；砥觸
column6:
(1) The bus and the van collided.
(2) The ships collided in the fog.
(3) As the bus turned the corner, it collided with a van.
(4) But during the collision, one galaxy can rip the other apart gravitationally, and dust and gas common to both galaxies does collide.
(5) The space between stars is so vast that when galaxies collide, the stars in them usually do not collide.
(6) They regularly collide over policy decisions.
(7) Moving at the speed of life, we are bound to collide with each other.
column7:
(1) 公共汽車與客貨車相撞。
(2) 輪船在霧中相撞。
(3) 公共汽車轉過拐角時與客貨車相撞。
(4) 當星系互撞期間，星系可能因重力拉扯另外一個星系，塵埃與雲氣也會因此而合併。
(5) 因為恆星的間距非常大，所以在星系碰撞的過程中，恆星通常不會互撞。
(6) 他們經常在政策決策上發生衝突。
(7) 隨遇而安,人與人之間必定會衝突。
column8: It could be protons bouncing around in a particle accelerator, two cars failing to stop at an intersection, or the priorities of two people with very different goals. When things crash together, they collide.
column9: The verb collide has roots in the Latin word collidere, which comes from col- or 「together」 and laedere, 「to strike or damage," like planes that collide in midair. Collide can also describe ideas that clash, such as expectations that collide with reality or radical views that collide with tradition.
column11:
1[V-RECIP 相互動詞]碰撞；相撞；撞上 If two or more moving people or objects collide, they crash into one another. If a moving person or object collides with a person or object that is not moving, they crash into them.
  [pl-n V]
  [V with n]
  [V with n (non-recip)]

  • Two trains collided head-on in north-eastern Germany early this morning...

    今天早上德國東北部兩列火車迎面相撞。

  • Racing up the stairs, he almost collided with Daisy...

    他飛奔上樓，差點撞到黛西。

  • He collided with a pine tree near the North Gate.

    他撞到了北門旁邊的一棵松樹上。

2[V-RECIP 相互動詞](目標、意見等)衝突，牴觸 If the aims, opinions, or interests of one person or group collide with those of another person or group, they are very different from each other and are therefore opposed.
  [V with n]
  [pl-n V]

  • The aims of the negotiators in New York again seem likely to collide with the aims of the warriors in the field...

    看來，紐約談判人員的目標可能會再次與戰場上勇士們的目標發生衝突。

  • In the next two years, Nasser regularly collided with the different Western powers, who refused to arm him...

    隨後的兩年裡，納賽爾不斷與拒絕為他提供武器裝備的幾個西方大國發生衝突。

  • What happens when the two interests collide will make a fascinating spectacle.

    兩種利益發生衝突時將會上演一場好戲。

column5: adj. (語言)用於日常交談的, 口語的; 非正式的, 非文學的
column6:
(1) ...a colloquial expression...
(2) His stumbling attempts at colloquial Russian amused her.

column5: vi.共謀；串通
column6:
(1) certain officials were colluding in the avoidance of drugs tests.
(2) the president accused his opponents of colluding with foreigners.
(3) [collude in] She knew about the plan, and colluded in it.
(4) It's quite obvious that you have been colluding with him to cheat me of my money.
column7:
(1) 某些官員暗中串通, 逃避藥檢
(2) 總統指控他的對手與外國人勾結。
(4)很顯然地，你跟他共謀來騙我的錢。

column5: n.殖民地；僑居地；僑民；聚居(地)；群體；菌落
column6:
(1) This country used to be a British colony in Asia.
(2) Britain was mandated to govern the former colony of German East Africa.
(3) That first winter in America was very hard for the new colony.
(4) It grows twice as fast as the second colony.
(5) Every specimen makes germiculture and bacterium colony computation.
(6) And if the colony were inside something as large as a pebble, UV protection would be sharply increased.
column7:
(1) 這個國家曾是英國在亞洲的殖民地。
(2) 英國授權代管德國在東非的前殖民地。
(3) 對於新僑民來說,在美國的第一個冬天是非常難熬的。
(4) 它增長的速率是第二個群體的兩倍。
(5) 每份標本作細菌培養和菌落計數。
(6) 如果菌落藏身於卵石般大小的東西內部，紫外線防護效果就會顯著增加。
column8: A colony is a group of people who settle in a new place but keep ties to their homeland. The people who founded the United States first came to America to live as part of a British colony.
column9: Colony comes from the Latin colonia, meaning "settled land, farm." Colony can also mean "a group of people who've gathered to live near each other and share the same interest." An artists' colony would be a place where everyone's an artist, while a Dunkin' Donuts colony would be full of coffee lovers. The same rules apply to the animal kingdom — an ant colony has a shared interest in ruining your picnic.
column11:
1[N-COUNT 可數名詞]殖民地 A colony is a country which is controlled by a more powerful country.
  [usu supp N]

  • In France's former North African colonies, anti-French feeling is growing...

    在北非的一些前法屬殖民地國家，反法情緒日益增長。

  • Puerto Rico, though it calls itself a Commonwealth, is really a self-governing American colony.

    波多黎各儘管自稱共和國，但實際上是有自治權的美國殖民地。

2[N-COUNT 可數名詞](某一類人的)聚居地，聚居區 You can refer to a place where a particular group of people lives as a particular kind of colony .
  [usu with supp]

  • In 1932, he established a school and artists' colony in Stone City, Iowa.

    1932年，他在艾奧瓦州的石頭城創建了一所學校，那兒成了藝術家的聚居地。

  • ...a penal colony.

    罪犯流放地

  • ...industrial colonies.

    工業聚集區

3[N-PLURAL 複數名詞](統稱)英屬殖民地 The colonies means all the countries that used to be British colonies.
  [the N]
  [BRIT 英]
  [OLD-FASHIONED 過時]

  • Many of our troops and officers were scattered around the world in the service of His Majesty in the colonies.

    我們的很多部隊和軍官分駐世界各地的英屬殖民地，為英王效力。

4[N-PLURAL 複數名詞](美國獨立前的)北美十三州 The colonies means the 13 British colonies in North America which formed the original United States.
  [AM 美]

  • On the eve of the Revolution, the colonies produced thirty thousand tons of crude iron a year.

    獨立戰爭前夕，北美十三州每年生產3萬噸生鐵。

5[N-COUNT 可數名詞](鳥、昆蟲或動物的)群體，集群，群落 A colony of birds, insects, or animals is a group of them that live together.
  [oft N of n]

  • The Shetlands are famed for their colonies of sea birds...

    設得蘭群島以其眾多的海鳥而聞名。

  • The caterpillars feed in large colonies.

    毛毛蟲總是成群進食。

column5: adj. 巨大的； <口>異常的
column6:
(1) This is indeed a colossal success.
(2) But to go back to the old ways would be a colossal mistake.
column7:
(1) 這確實是個巨大的成功。
(2) 但是，回到老路上將是一個巨大的錯誤。
column8: Colossal describes something so large it makes you say, "Whoa!" You might have a colossal amount of homework, or see a colossal pyramid while vacationing in Egypt.
column9: Colossal can refer to an item's physical size, like a giant redwood tree, but it can also be used to describe the force or scope of something — like the colossal force of a thunderstorm that knocked down the redwood tree, or the colossal scope of your school project on the history of the redwoods that seems like it will never, ever end. It comes from the Greek word kolossos, meaning "gigantic statue."
column11:
1[ADJ-GRADED 能被表示程度的副詞或介詞詞組修飾的形容詞]巨大的；龐大的 If you describe something as colossal, you are emphasizing that it is very large.
  [emphasis]

  • There has been a colossal waste of public money...

    一直存在巨大的公款浪費。

  • The task they face is colossal.

    他們面臨的任務十分艱巨。

colossally

  • Their policies have been colossally destructive.

    他們的政策極具破壞性。

column5: n.昏迷
column6:
(1) The patient rallied from the coma.
(2) Daddy lingered in a coma for several days.
column7:
(1) 病人從昏迷中甦醒過來。
(2) 爸爸昏迷了數日。
column8: Medically speaking, a coma is the state of protective deep sleep your body goes into when severely injured, as in a car crash. Daytime soap operas would be lost without a good coma every few weeks.
column9: Coma comes from the Greek koma meaning "deep sleep." As with so many words with medical or scientific origins, coma has been appropriated for a far wider range of uses. The zombie-like trance you fall into at family get-togethers like Thanksgiving? That too is a coma, though your chances of recovery are far better than from a real coma. Unless you happen to sit next to Aunt Sadie.
column11:
1[N-COUNT 可數名詞]昏迷 Someone who is in a coma is in a state of deep unconsciousness.
  [usu in/into N]

  • She was in a coma for seven weeks...

    她已經昏迷7個星期了。

  • She had slipped into a coma by the time she reached hospital.

    到醫院時，她已陷入昏迷。

column5:
n.梳子；雞冠；蜂房
v.梳理；徹底搜尋
column6:
(1) She wore a small comb as an ornament.
(2) She swept her hair back with a comb.
(3) Morris said taco sauce makes her comb light up bright red.
(4) His comb was as red as fire, and his feathers were as yellow as gold.
(5) She combed the mud out of the dog's fur.
(6) The police have combed the city for the murderer.
(7) He combed through the files searching for evidence of fraud.
column7:
(1) 她佩戴了一把小梳子作為裝飾品。
(2) 她用梳子將頭髮往後梳。
(3) 莫裡斯說，吃蘸醬墨西哥煎玉米卷讓小雞的雞冠變得油亮鮮紅。
(4) 他的雞冠鮮紅似火，羽毛橙黃如金。
(5) 她梳去狗的皮毛中的泥土。
(6) 警察在全市到處搜查兇手。
(7) 他詳查檔案，尋找欺詐行為的證據。
column8: A comb is a tool for smoothing your hair. You might pull a comb through your curls before you run out the door in the morning to catch your bus.
column9: A comb is made of plastic or wood, with separate teeth that untangle strands of hair. When you use one, you comb: "I grabbed the comb so I could comb my cat before the photo shoot." Another way to comb is to rummage or search, the way you comb through your bag to find your car keys. The Old English root is camb, "crest" or "honeycomb," from a Germanic root that means "toothed object."
column11:
1[N-COUNT 可數名詞]梳子 A comb is a flat piece of plastic or metal with narrow pointed teeth along one side, which you use to tidy your hair.
    2[VERB 動詞]梳理(頭髮) When you comb your hair, you tidy it using a comb.
      [V n]
      [V-ed]

    • Salvatore combed his hair carefully...

      薩爾瓦托認真地梳了梳頭。

    • Her reddish hair was cut short and neatly combed.

      她淡紅色的頭髮剪得短短的，梳得很整齊。

    3[VERB 動詞]在…四處搜尋 If you comb a place, you search everywhere in it in order to find someone or something.
      [V n for n]
      [V n]

    • Officers combed the woods for the murder weapon...

      警察在樹林裡四處搜尋凶器。

    • They fanned out and carefully combed the temple grounds.

      他們呈扇形散開，在寺廟周圍仔細搜尋。

    4[VERB 動詞]在(信息)中仔細搜尋 If you comb through information, you look at it very carefully in order to find something.
      [V through n]

    • Eight policemen then spent two years combing through the evidence.

      之後8位警察花了兩年時間搜尋證據。

    5See also:fine-tooth comb；

column5: n. (1) 小型爵士樂隊; (2) [主北美] (尤指不同食物的) 組合物, 組合餐
column6:
(1) He played trumpet professionally in a jazz combo.
(2) I'll have the steak and chicken combo platter.
(3) Please select a type from the drop down combo box.
column7:
(1) 他在一個爵士樂隊中專業演奏小號。
(2) 我要牛排和雞組合餐。
(3) 請從下拉組合框中選擇一個類型。
column11:
1[N-COUNT 可數名詞](演奏爵士樂、舞曲或流行音樂的)小型樂隊 A combo is a small group of musicians who play jazz, dance, or popular music.
  [INFORMAL 非正式]

  • ...a new-wave rock combo.

    新浪潮搖滾小樂隊

column5:
adj. 可燃的；易動激情的
n. 可燃物
column6: The coach had to keep the combustible players under control.

column5: n.彗星
column6:
(1) That comet is invisible to the unaided eye.
(2) Comets move around the sun like planets, but in long oval course.
column7:
(1) 那顆彗星只用肉眼是看不到的。
(2) 彗星象行星一樣繞太陽運轉，然而其軌道呈狹長的橢圓形。
column8: A comet is a small, icy object that orbits the sun and has a long "tail" of gas. Some comets can be seen from Earth every few years, while others pass by once in a person's lifetime.
column9: Comets are made of ice, dust, and tiny pieces of rock, but to people on Earth, they look like streaks or smudges across the night sky. When the Earth's orbit takes it through one of these comets' tails, their dust burns up in our atmosphere and results in a meteor shower. In Old French, the word was comete, ultimately from a Greek root, kometes, which literally means "long-haired star."
column11:
1[N-COUNT 可數名詞]彗星 A comet is a bright object with a long tail that travels around the sun.

  • Halley's Comet is going to come back in 2061.

    哈雷彗星將於2061年回歸。

column5:
n.舒適；安逸；安慰；慰藉
vt.安慰；使舒適
column6:
(1) The dress is carefully styled for maximum comfort.
(2) First, you need to get out of your comfort zone.
(3) Humanization design is to upgrade the comfort of operation.
(4) They are now living in relative comfort.
(5) He spoke a few words of comfort to me before leaving.
(6) I offer a mite of comfort to him.
(7) My husband was a great comfort to me when my son was ill.
(8) Her children are a great comfort to her.
(9) I tried to comfort him after he was defeated by his opponent.
(10) His friends came to comfort him for his loss.
(11) He comforted his back with soft cushions.
column7:
(1) 這服裝精心設計，力求達到最大限度的舒適。
(2) 首先,你要離開你的習慣,離開你的舒適地帶。
(3) 人性化設計,更提升了操作舒適性。
(4) 他們現在過著比較安逸的生活。
(5) 走之前，他向我說了幾句安慰的話。
(6) 我給了他一點安慰。
(7) 我兒子生病時，丈夫給了我極大的安慰。
(8) 她的孩子是她極大的安慰。
(9) 他被對手擊敗後，我盡力安慰他。
(10) 因為他受了損失, 他的朋友們都來安慰他。
(11) 他鋪上軟墊使背部舒適些。
column8: To comfort someone is to give solace or to soothe. You might comfort your brother when his favorite team gets knocked out of the playoffs.
column9: The verb comfort comes from the Latin word comfortare, which means 「strengthen greatly.」 To give comfort is to shore up the mood or physical state of someone else. It might take a long time to comfort your mother after her cat disappears. As a noun, comfort is anything that provides satisfaction or a relaxed and easy feeling. You might think that the comfort of your new shoes cannot be surpassed.
column11:
1[N-UNCOUNT 不可數名詞]舒適；舒服 If you are doing something in comfort, you are physically relaxed and contented, and are not feeling any pain or other unpleasant sensations.
  [oft in/for N]

  • This will enable the audience to sit in comfort while watching the shows...

    這樣能夠讓觀眾舒舒服服地坐著看表演。

  • The shoe has padding around the collar, heel and tongue for added comfort.

    鞋子的鞋幫、鞋跟和鞋舌部位都有襯墊，以增加舒適度。

2[N-UNCOUNT 不可數名詞]舒適的生活方式；安逸 Comfort is a style of life in which you have enough money to have everything you need.
  [oft in N]

  • Surely there is some way of ordering our busy lives so that we can live in comfort and find spiritual harmony too.

    總會有辦法能安排好我們忙碌的生活，這樣就能過得舒服一點，同時還能達到內心的平靜。

3[N-UNCOUNT 不可數名詞]See also:cold comfort；安慰；慰藉 Comfort is what you feel when worries or unhappiness stop.

  • He welcomed the truce, but pointed out it was of little comfort to families spending Christmas without a loved one...

    他欣然接受休戰，但是指出，那些無法和心愛的人一起過聖誕的家庭並不會由此感到慰藉。

  • He will be able to take some comfort from inflation figures due on Friday...

    預定星期五發佈的通貨膨脹數字將會給他一些寬慰。

  • He found comfort in Eva's blind faith in him.

    伊娃對他的盲目信任讓他感到寬慰。

4[N-COUNT 可數名詞]令人感到安慰的人(或事物) If you refer to a person, thing, or idea as a comfort, you mean that it helps you to stop worrying or makes you feel less unhappy.
  [usu sing]

  • At least he has given her a child who will be a great comfort to her in the years ahead...

    至少他留給她一個孩子，這孩子在未來的歲月裡對她將是莫大的安慰。

  • It's a comfort talking to you...

    跟你聊一聊我好受多了。

  • Being able to afford a drink would be a comfort in these tough times.

    在這樣艱難的時期，能夠有錢買杯酒就是種慰藉了。

5[VERB 動詞]安慰；撫慰 If you comfort someone, you make them feel less worried, unhappy, or upset, for example by saying kind things to them.
  [V n]

  • Ned put his arm around her, trying to comfort her.

    內德摟著她，想安慰她。

6[N-COUNT 可數名詞]See also:creature comforts；使生活舒適的東西 Comforts are things which make your life easier and more pleasant, such as electrical devices you have in your home.
  [usu pl]

  • She enjoys the material comforts married life has brought her...

    她喜歡婚姻生活帶給她的物質享受。

  • Electricity provides us with warmth and light and all our modern home comforts...

    電給我們帶來了溫暖和照明，以及一切現代家庭舒適品。

  • I do like my comforts.

    我確實喜歡這些給我的生活帶來舒適的東西。

7[PHRASE 短語]因太…而令人擔憂 If you say that something is, for example, too close for comfort, you mean you are worried because it is closer than you would like it to be.
  [PHR after v]

  • The bombs fell in the sea, many too close for comfort...

    這些炸彈落入海中，很多離岸邊太近，令人擔憂。

  • Although crimes against visitors were falling, the levels of crime were still too high for comfort.

    儘管針對遊客的犯罪活動有所減少，但犯罪率還是太高，令人擔憂。

column5:
n.安慰者；蓋被；長圍巾
Comforter: 聖靈.
column6:
(1) The comforter told him that he should be patient.
(2) Paul smooth the comforter,adjusting it carefully about his father's neck.
(3) She put on a comforter and went out.
column7:
(1) 那位安慰者告訴他，他應該有耐心。
(2) 保羅展開被子，小心地蓋到父親的脖子周圍。
(3) 她戴上一條長毛織圍巾就出去了。
column11:
1[N-COUNT 可數名詞]安慰者；給人安慰的事物 A comforter is a person or thing that comforts you.

  • He became Vivien Leigh's devoted friend and comforter.

    他成了費雯麗忠誠的朋友和給她安慰的人。

2[N-COUNT 可數名詞]羽絨被 A comforter is a large cover filled with feathers or similar material which you put over yourself in bed instead of a sheet and blankets.
  [AM 美]
    in BRIT, use 英國英語用 duvet, quilt

column5:
n.命令；指揮；掌握；[計算機] DOS命令 : 引用輔助命令處理器
v.命令；指揮；掌握；博得
column6:
(1) He growled a command to her to stop.
(2) The company commander roared his command.
(3) He has a hundred men under his command.
(4) The army is under the king's direct command.
(5) She has a large English vocabulary at her command.
(6) We work hard at English so as to have a good command of it.
(7) For the first time in years, she felt in command of her life.
(8) The general commanded his men to attack the city.
(9) The general spread out a map to command his army.
(10) It's very important to command a certain number of vocabularies.
(11) This great man is able to command everyone's respect.
(12) The plight of the famine victims commands everyone's sympathy.
column7:
(1) 他咆哮著命令她停下來。
(2) 連長高聲發佈命令。
(3) 他指揮一百個人。
(4) 軍隊由國王直接統率。
(5) 她能靈活運用掌握的大量英語辭彙。
(6) 為了掌握英語，我們在學習英語上下苦功夫。
(7) 多少年來第一次，她覺得生活掌握在自己的手裡。
(8) 將軍下令部下攻城。
(9) 將軍攤開地圖指揮軍隊作戰。
(10) 掌握一定的詞彙量是很重要的.
(11) 這位偉人有資格獲得大家的尊敬。
(12) 饑民的苦境值得大家同情。
column8: A command is an order that you have to follow, as long as the person who gives it has authority over you. You don't have to comply with your friend's command that you give him all your money.
column9: Command, which can be a noun or a verb, combines the Latin prefix com-, meaning "with," and mandāre, "to charge, enjoin," so to give someone a command is to say something with the authority that charges him to follow it. Your mother might command you to clean your room. Command can also mean a position of power, like having command of a battleship, or possession of a skill, like having a great command of video games.
column11:
1[VERB 動詞]命令；下令；指示 If someone in authority commands you to do something, they tell you that you must do it.
  [V n to-inf]
  [V with quote]
  [V that]
  [V n with quote]
  [Also V n]
  [mainly WRITTEN 主筆語]

  • He commanded his troops to attack...

    他命令部隊發起進攻。

  • 'Get in your car and follow me,' he commanded...

    「上你自己的車，跟在我後面。」他命令道。

  • He commanded that roads be built to link castles across the land...

    他下令修建連接各地城堡的道路。

  • 'Don't panic,' I commanded myself.

    「不要驚慌，」我命令自己。

  • Command is also a noun.

    • The tanker failed to respond to a command to stop...

      這輛罐車沒有按照命令停下來。

    • I closed my eyes at his command.

      我按照他的指示閉上了眼睛。

    • ...the note of command in his voice.

      他聲音中那種命令的口氣

2[VERB 動詞]博得，贏得，擁有(尊重、服從等) If you command something such as respect or obedience, you obtain it because you are popular, famous, or important.
  [V n]
  [no cont]

  • ...an excellent physician who commanded the respect of all his colleagues...

    贏得所有同事尊敬的優秀的內科醫生

  • There is no limit to what can be achieved here because of the fantastic support we command.

    由於贏得了極大的支持，我們將無往不勝。

3[VERB 動詞]控制；掌管 If an army or country commands a place, they have total control over it.
  [V n]

  • The Royal Navy would command the seas...

    皇家海軍會控制所有海域。

  • Yemen commands the strait at the southern end of the Red Sea.

    也門完全控制著紅海南端的海峽。

  • Command is also a noun.

    • ...the struggle for command of the air.

      對制空權的爭奪

4[VERB 動詞]統率，指揮(軍隊) An officer who commands part of an army, navy, or air force is responsible for controlling and organizing it.
  [V n]
  [V]

  • ...the French general who commands the UN troops in the region...

    統率該地區聯合國部隊的法國將軍

  • He didn't just command. He personally fought in several heavy battles.

    他不僅僅發號施令，還身先士卒參加了幾次激戰。

  • Command is also a noun.

    • ...a small garrison under the command of Major James Craig...

      由詹姆斯·克雷格少校指揮的小規模衛戍部隊

    • In 1942 he took command of 108 Squadron.

      1942年，他是108飛行中隊的指揮官。

5[N-COUNT-COLL 可數集合名詞]司令部；指揮部 In the armed forces, a command is a group of officers who are responsible for organizing and controlling part of an army, navy, or air force.
  [usu supp N]

  • He had authorisation from the military command to retaliate...

    他得到軍事指揮部授權，準備反擊。

  • The army's supreme command has said the army will withdraw, provided the other side does so also.

    陸軍最高司令部說如果對方撤退，他們的部隊也要撤退。

6[N-COUNT-COLL 可數集合名詞]（某一指揮官統率的）部隊，兵團，軍區 In the armed forces, a command is a group of soldiers that a particular officer is in charge of.
  [oft in names after n]

  • There would continue to be a joint command of US and Saudi forces operating within Saudi borders.

    美國軍隊和沙特軍隊共同組成的聯合部隊將繼續在沙特阿拉伯境內實施軍事行動。

  • ...the Strategic Air Command.

    戰略空軍司令部

7[N-COUNT 可數名詞](計算機的)指令 In computing, a command is an instruction that you give to a computer.
    8[N-UNCOUNT 不可數名詞](對局面的)控制，掌握 If someone has command of a situation, they have control of it because they have, or seem to have, power or authority.

    • Whoever was waiting for them there had command of the situation...

      在那邊等候他們的人控制了局勢。

    • Mr Baker would take command of the campaign...

      貝克先生會負責這次運動。

    • In times of currency crisis interest rates can be raised as a sign that a government is in command.

      在發生貨幣危機的時期，利率會提高，以表明政府有控制力。

    9[N-UNCOUNT 不可數名詞]掌握；精通 Your command of something, such as a foreign language, is your knowledge of it and your ability to use this knowledge.
      [N of n]

    • His command of English was excellent.

      他精通英語。

    • ...a singer with a natural command of melody.

      天生樂感很好的歌手

    10[VERB 動詞]居高臨下；俯瞰；清楚地看到 If a place commands a view, especially an impressive one, you can see the view clearly from that place. If a person commands a view of something, they can see it clearly from where they are.
      [V n]
      [no cont]
      [FORMAL 正式]

    • The house commanded some splendid views of Delaware Bay.

      從這座房子可以俯瞰到特拉華灣壯麗的景致。

    • ...a point of rock, from which we could command a view of the loch.

      可以對整個海峽一覽無遺的佈滿岩石的岬角

    11See also:high command；second-in-command；
      12[PHRASE 短語](技術或資源)可運用自如，充分運用，可支配 If you have a particular skill or particular resources at your command, you have them and can use them fully.
        [FORMAL 正式]

      • He came from the Sudan without a word of English at his command...

        他來自蘇丹地區，一句英語都不會。

      • The country should have the right to defend itself with all legal means at its command.

        國家有權運用一切合法手段保衛自身安全。

      13[PHRASE 短語]應付自如 If you are in command or in command of yourself, you are relaxed and able to react and behave in the way that you want to.
        [usu v-link PHR]

      • Nixon looked comfortable and in command...

        尼克松看上去鎮定自若。

      • The man appeared to be in complete command of himself.

        那個男人看上去神態自如。

column5: vt.紀念
column6:
(1) A monument was built to commemorate the victory.
(2) Christmas commemorates the birth of Christ.
(3) They reared a monument to commemorate the great musician.
(4) We celebrate this day to commemorate the brave soldiers.
(5) Today, moon cakes are eaten to commemorate this event.
column7:
(1) 為了紀念勝利，建造了一座紀念碑。
(2) 聖誕節是為了紀念耶酥的誕生。
(3) 他們建立起一座紀念碑，紀念這位偉大的音樂家。
(4) 我們慶祝這天，以紀念英勇的士兵。
(5) 今天，人們吃月餅紀念此事。
column8: To commemorate something means to remember something and by doing so to honor it, as in 「We would like to commemorate his many years of past service by presenting him with this lovely gold watch.」
column9: The word commemorate has a pretty clear echo of memory in it, so it can help to keep it in your mind just by noticing that. You might also notice that you』ve seen the word before, either in late-night infomercials or in various advertisements in magazines, when they talk about commemorative plates, or stamps, or coins: little things that are supposed to honor events or people by recalling them to our collective memory.
column11:
1[VERB 動詞]紀念 To commemorate an important event or person means to remember them by means of a special action, ceremony, or specially created object.
  [V n]

  • One room contained a gallery of paintings commemorating great moments in baseball history...

    有一個房間裡陳列著很多紀念棒球史上偉大時刻的畫作。

  • The 200th anniversary of Mozart's death is being commemorated around the world with concerts featuring his work.

    世界各地將舉辦以莫扎特的作品為主題的音樂會，以紀念他逝世200週年。

commemoration

  • ...the 50th Anniversary Commemoration of the Warsaw Ghetto Uprising.

    華沙猶太區起義50週年紀念

  • ...a service of commemoration.

    紀念儀式

  • ...a march in commemoration of Malcolm X.

    紀念馬爾科姆·艾克斯的遊行

column5: v.開始；著手；<英>獲得學位
column6:
(1) I commence from this point.
(2) The second term commences in March.
(3) I commence a round of visit.
column7:
(1) 我從此點開始。
(2) 第二學期自三月開始。
(3) 我開始著手一系列訪問。
column8: Commence is a fancy way of saying begin at the start of a formal event such as a meeting or war.
column9: If a congressman wants to start a meeting to vote on an important bill, he might say, "This meeting will begin immediately." Or, he could make the same statement in a more formal way by saying, "This meeting will commence immediately. Interestingly enough, while the word commence means to start, a commencement ceremony marks the end of a college career.
column11:
1[V-ERG 及物/不及物動詞]開始 When something commences or you commence it, it begins.
  [V]
  [V n/-ing]
  [V to-inf]
  [FORMAL 正式]

  • The academic year commences at the beginning of October...

    學年於10月初開始。

  • They commenced a systematic search...

    他們開始進行徹底搜查。

  • The hunter knelt beside the animal carcass and commenced to skin it.

    獵人跪在動物屍體旁邊，開始剝皮。

Usage Note :

Commence, start, and begin all have a similar meaning, although commence is more formal and is not normally used in conversation. The meeting is ready to begin... He tore the list up and started a fresh one. ...an alternative to commencing the process of European integration. Note that begin, start, and commence can all be followed by an -ing form or a noun, but only begin and start can be followed by a 'to' infinitive.

commence, start 和 begin 三個詞意思相近，不過 commence 一詞更為正式，通常不用於對話中。例如，The meeting is ready to begin (會議可以開始了)，He tore the list up and started a fresh one (他把清單撕碎，然後另列一張)，an alternative to commencing the process of European integration (啟動歐洲一體化進程的另一種方式)。注意 begin, start 和 commence 都能後接動詞的 -ing 形式或名詞，但只有 begin 和 start 才能後接不定式。

column5: n.開始；畢業典禮
column6:
(1) The commencement of articulate speech belongs to this period.
(2) Seeds begin to burgeon at the commencement of spring.
(3) At commencement, academic degrees are officially given.
(4) The commencement was held in the grand hall.
(5) He made a speech at the commencement.
column7:
(1) 音節分明的語言即開始於這一期。
(2) 春天來臨時種子開始發芽。
(3) 在畢業典禮上，學位被正式頒發。
(4) 畢業典禮在豪華的大廳舉行。
(5) 他在畢業典禮上做了一次演講。
column8: A commencement is the act of starting out, or blazing a new trail.
column9: The suffix -ment makes the word commencement a noun — a thing, an activity, a start. The word can be used for the beginning of anything, from a business meeting to a vacation trip to a marriage. Anything that begins has a moment of commencement. That's why a graduation ceremony is called a commencement — a graduate is embarking on a new life, and the commencement ritual marks the official beginning of that life.
column11:
1[N-UNCOUNT 不可數名詞]開始 The commencement of something is its beginning.
  [usu the N of n]
  [FORMAL 正式]

  • All applicants should be at least 16 years of age at the commencement of this course.

    申請修讀這門課程者至少要年滿16歲。

2[N-VAR 可變名詞]學位授予儀式；(大學或高中的)畢業典禮 Commencement is a ceremony at a university, college, or high school at which students formally receive their degrees or diplomas.
  [usu N n]
  [AM 美]
    in BRIT, use 英國英語用 graduation

column5: v.推薦；稱讚；嘉獎；把 ... 托付給
column6:
(1) I should like to commend this method to you.
(2) I'd like to commend him to my friends.
(3) He commend them for their enthusiasm.
(4) His work was highly commended.
(5) She commended the child to her sister's care.
(6) Almighty Father, we commend all who suffer to your loving care.
column7:
(1) 我想向您推薦這一方法。
(2) 我願意把他推薦給我的朋友們。
(3) 他稱讚他們的熱情。
(4) 他的工作備受讚賞。
(5) 她將孩子委託給她妹妹照管。
(6) 全能的聖父，我們將所有受苦受難的人托付於您的關愛。
column8: Ever shout "Bravo!" at the end of a ballet or coo "Good boy!" to the dog when he relieved himself outdoors instead of on the rug? Then you know how to commend someone — in other words, to express approval aloud.
column9: The most common meaning of commend is to compliment. You commend someone when you tell them "Well done!" You can even say "I commend you on your hard work." Back in the days of Charles Dickens, to commend often meant to put (someone or something) in the hands of someone else for safekeeping. Case in point: David Copperfield was out of luck when his cruel stepdad commended him to the equally cruel schoolmaster Mr. Creakle at Salem house.
column11:
1[VERB 動詞]讚揚；讚許 If you commend someone or something, you praise them formally.
  [V n for/on n/-ing]
  [V n]
  [FORMAL 正式]

  • I commended her for that action...

    我讚揚了她的那一舉動。

  • I commend Ms. Orth on writing such an informative article...

    我對奧思太太寫出內容如此翔實的文章表示讚許。

  • The book was widely commended for its candour...

    這本書以其直言不諱而廣受好評。

  • The reports commend her bravery...

    這些報道讚揚了她的勇敢。

  • His actions were commended by the Jury.

    他的所作所為受到了陪審團的讚許。

commendation

  • The Company received a commendation from the Royal Society of Arts.

    公司受到了皇家藝術協會的讚揚。

2[VERB 動詞]推薦；舉薦 If someone commends a person or thing to you, they tell you that you will find them good or useful.
  [V n to n]
  [FORMAL 正式]

  • I can commend it to him as a realistic course of action.

    我可以把這作為一個切實可行的處理方法推薦給他。

3[VERB 動詞]被接受；得到認可 If something commends itself to you, you approve of it.
  [V pron-refl to n]
  [FORMAL 正式]

  • The Rousseau model commended itself to a lot of early socialists.

    盧梭提出的模式被很多早期的社會主義者接受。

4[PHRASE 短語]令人稱道/乏善可陳 If you say that something has much to commend it, you approve of it. If you say that something has little to commend it, you disapprove of it.
  [usu v PHR pron]
  [FORMAL 正式]

  • The Prime Minister's initiative has much to commend it.

    首相的新方案有不少令人贊許之處。

column5: adj.相稱的；成比例的；適當的
column6:
(1) He was given a job commensurate with his abilities.
(2) Salary will be commensurate with experience.
(3) The salary will be commensurate with your age and experience.
column7:
(1) 他得到一份與他能力相稱的工作。
(2) 薪金將會與資歷相稱。
(3) 工資將會與你的年齡和經歷相稱。
column8: The word commensurate has to do with things that are similar in size and therefore appropriate. Many people think the death penalty is a commensurate punishment for murder. In other words, the penalty fits the crime.
column9: When things are commensurate, they're fair, appropriate, and the right size. If you got a ticket for jaywalking, you shouldn't get ten years in prison — that penalty is not commensurate with the crime. The word commensurate is usually followed by with or to; one thing is commensurate with or to another.
column11:
1[ADJ 形容詞](比例)相當的，相稱的 If the level of one thing is commensurate with another, the first level is in proportion to the second.
  [v-link ADJ with/to n]
  [FORMAL 正式]

  • Employees are paid salaries commensurate with those of teachers...

    給員工的薪水與老師拿的薪水相當。

  • Managers saw a commensurate fall in their revenues.

    經理們發現自己的收入相應地減少了。

commensurately

  • Japanese real wages have not yet increased commensurately with the wealth of Japan...

    日本人的實際工資並沒有隨著國家財富的增長而相應增加。

  • The gain will be commensurately modest.

    相應地，收益不會太多。

column5: n.貿易；商業
column6:
(1) We must promote commerce with neighbouring countries.
(2) Our country has been trying to broaden its commerce with other nations.
(3) In USA, NewYork City is the chief seat of commerce.
(4) Banks are the nerves of commerce.
column7:
(1) 我們必須促進與鄰國的貿易。
(2) 我國一直在努力擴大與其他國家的貿易往來。
(3) 在美國,紐約是主要的商業中心。
(4) 銀行是商業的中樞。
column8: Commerce is the exchange of goods and services. It's business. Competition between cities wanting to host the Olympics is fierce because it increases tourism and commerce.
column9: Commerce made its way into English from the Latin word commercium — com-, meaning "together," and -mercium, meaning "merchandise." Business, trade, and retailing are all common synonyms. Commerce doesn't always refer to buying and selling, though, just as the marketplace doesn't always refer to goods and services. Data, information, and opinions, too, can be exchanged and traded, as on the Internet, which is a great place for the commerce of ideas.
column11:
1[N-UNCOUNT 不可數名詞]See also:chamber of commerce；商業；貿易 Commerce is the activities and procedures involved in buying and selling things.

  • They have made their fortunes from industry and commerce.

    他們靠工商業發了財。

column5:
adj.商業的
n.商業廣告
column6:
(1) Do you fancy having a go at doing a commercial feature film?
(2) The downtown area is zoned for commercial use.
(3) They were much more realistic about its long term commercial prospects.
(4) The Dole commercial is the first time Pfizer has promoted Viagra through television.
(5) Every commercial on television has a web site at the bottom of the screen.
(6) A good commercial puts across the attractive features of a product.
column7:
(1) 對製作商業的影片有沒有興趣?
(2) 市中心被劃出供商業用。
(3) 他們對它的長遠商業前景更為現實。
(4) 多爾的廣告是輝瑞首次通過電視推銷偉哥。
(5) 每個電視廣告下面都有一個網址。
(6) 好廣告能突顯產品吸引人的特徵。
column8: Commercial is an adjective describing something with money-making and marketing intentions. If you』re a bit of a book snob, steer clear of commercial fiction, which is written for the widest enjoyment.
column9: The adjective commercial first appeared in the 1680』s, long before television commercials, which is probably what you think of when you hear the word. An al was added to commerce, and it meant "pertaining to trade." It wasn』t until the 1870's that commercial meant 「done for the sake of financial profit,」 and then later in the 1930's, the noun form was refined to describe 「an advertisement broadcast on radio or TV.」
column11:
1[ADJ 形容詞]商業的；貿易的 Commercial means involving or relating to the buying and selling of goods.
  [usu ADJ n]

  • Docklands in its heyday was a major centre of industrial and commercial activity...

    港區在其最繁榮的時期曾是主要的工商業活動中心。

  • Attacks were reported on police, vehicles and commercial premises.

    據報道，警察、車輛和商業經營場所均遭到襲擊。

2[ADJ-GRADED 能被表示程度的副詞或介詞詞組修飾的形容詞](組織、活動)營利的，商業化的，偏重利潤的 Commercial organizations and activities are concerned with making money or profits, rather than, for example, with scientific research or providing a public service.

  • British Rail has indeed become more commercial over the past decade...

    過去10年來，英國鐵路確實變得更加商業化了。

  • Conservationists in Chile are concerned over the effect of commercial exploitation of forests...

    對森林的商業開發所帶來的影響讓智利的自然資源保護者們感到憂心忡忡。

  • Whether the project will be a commercial success is still uncertain.

    這個項目是否賺錢還是個未知數。

commercially

  • British Aerospace reckon that the plane will be commercially viable if 400 can be sold...

    英國航空航天公司估計這個型號的飛機如果能賣出400架，就可實現盈利。

  • Insulin is produced commercially from animals...

    為獲利從動物體內提取胰島素。

  • Designers are becoming more commercially minded.

    設計者們變得更有商業意識。

3[ADJ 形容詞](產品)商品化的，供市場出售的 A commercial product is made to be sold to the public.
  [ADJ n]

  • They are the leading manufacturer in both defence and commercial products.

    在軍工產品和民用產品的製造方面，他們都處於領先地位。

commercially

  • It was the first commercially available machine to employ artificial intelligence.

    這是第一台作為商品出售的採用人工智能技術的機器。

4[ADJ 形容詞](車輛)商用的 A commercial vehicle is a vehicle used for carrying goods, or passengers who pay.
  [usu ADJ n]

  • Commercial vehicles, coaches and lorries are required by law to be fitted with tachographs.

    法律規定商用車輛、長途汽車和卡車要安裝轉速計。

  • ...the fastest crossing of the Atlantic by a commercial passenger vessel.

    商用客船最快的一次橫渡大西洋

5[ADJ 形容詞](電視、廣播)靠廣告收入維持的，商業性的 Commercial television and radio are paid for by the broadcasting of advertisements, rather than by the government.
  [usu ADJ n]

  • ...Classic FM, the first national commercial radio station.

    國內首家商業廣播電台——經典調頻

6[ADJ-GRADED 能被表示程度的副詞或介詞詞組修飾的形容詞](電影或音樂)商業化的，迎合大眾口味的 Commercial is used to describe something such as a film or a type of music that it is intended to be popular with the public, and is not very original or of high quality.

  • There's a feeling among a lot of people that music has become too commercial.

    很多人都覺得音樂變得過於商業化了。

7[N-COUNT 可數名詞](電視或電台的)商業廣告 A commercial is an advertisement that is broadcast on television or radio.

  • The government has launched a campaign of television commercials and leaflets.

    政府通過電視廣告和傳單的形式發起了宣傳活動。

column5:
n.佣金；委員會；委託；委任；犯罪
vt.授予；使服役；委託
column6:
(1) Do not deduct any commission from the consignment value.
(2) The report was submitted to the commission for consideration.
(3) He had received the commission to build a new bridge over the river.
(4) We all approve of the commission of authority to him.
(5) The prisoner pleaded that he was drawn in to the commission of the crime.
(6) He was commissioned captain of the United States Air Force.
(7) Some wartime vessels are still commissioned in that area.
(8) The musician was commissioned a new symphony for the festival.
column7:
(1) 不要從貨物的價值中扣除佣金。
(2) 這份報告已呈報委員會審批。
(3) 他受委託在這條河上建一座新橋。
(4) 我們都贊成把職權委任於他。
(5) 囚犯辯解說他是受人引誘而犯罪的。
(6) 他被授予美國空軍上校。
(7) 有些戰時的軍艦仍在該地區服役。
(8) 那位音樂家受托為這個節慶寫一首新的交響樂曲。
column8: The word commission has several very different meanings, but in its most basic meaning, commission is the act of passing a responsibility to someone else. If you receive a government commission, that means you have been assigned a task by the government.
column9: Another common meaning of commission is the amount of money an employee earns when they sell something: In addition to his salary, he gets a 1% commission on each sale. A commission is also an order for someone to do something and get paid: The artist received a commission for a new painting to hang in the building lobby. And a commission is a high-ranking position in the armed forces, or a special committee that controls or investigates something.
column11:
1[VERB 動詞]正式委託；委託(做) If you commission something or commission someone to do something, you formally arrange for someone to do a piece of work for you.
  [V n]
  [V n to-inf]
  [V-ed]

  • The Ministry of Agriculture commissioned a study into low-input farming...

    農業部委託對低投入耕作進行研究。

  • You can commission them to paint something especially for you.

    你可以委託他們專門為你畫點什麼。

  • ...specially commissioned reports.

    特別委託撰寫的報告

  • Commission is also a noun.

    • Our china can be bought off the shelf or by commission...

      我們的瓷器可現貨購買，也可以委託製作。

    • He approached John Wexley with a commission to write the screenplay of the film.

      他找到約翰·韋克斯利，委託他創作這部電影的劇本。

-commissioned

  • ...Government-commissioned research.

    政府委託進行的研究

2[N-COUNT 可數名詞]受托之事；(接受報酬的)任務 A commission is a piece of work that someone is asked to do and is paid for.

  • Just a few days ago, I finished a commission.

    就在幾天前，我完成了一項委託創作任務。

3[N-VAR 可變名詞]佣金；回扣 Commission is a sum of money paid to a salesperson for every sale that he or she makes. If a salesperson is paid on commission, the amount they receive depends on the amount they sell.
  [oft on N]

  • The salesmen work on commission only...

    銷售人員只根據銷售量提取佣金。

  • He also got a commission for bringing in new clients.

    他還因為帶來了很多新客戶拿到一筆佣金。

4[N-UNCOUNT 不可數名詞](銀行或公司收取的)服務費，手續費 If a bank or other company charges commission, they charge a fee for providing a service, for example for exchanging money or issuing an insurance policy.
  [BUSINESS 商]

  • Travel agents charge 1 per cent commission on sterling cheques...

    旅行社對英鎊支票收取1%的服務費。

  • Sellers pay a fixed commission fee.

    賣方支付固定的服務費。

5[N-COUNT-COLL 可數集合名詞]委員會；調查團 A commission is a group of people who have been appointed to find out about something or to control something.

  • The authorities have been asked to set up a commission to investigate the murders.

    當局被敦促成立一個委員會負責調查這些謀殺案。

  • ...the Press Complaints Commission.

    媒體投訴委員會

6[N-UNCOUNT 不可數名詞]犯(罪) The commission of a crime is the act of committing a crime.
  [FORMAL 正式]

  • If a person uses a gun in the commission of a crime, then he should be given an additional penalty.

    如果使用槍支進行犯罪，就應該受到額外的懲罰。

7[N-COUNT 可數名詞](軍隊的)任職令 If a member of the armed forces receives a commission, he or she becomes an officer.

  • He accepted a commission as a naval officer.

    他接受任命成為一名海軍軍官。

8[VERB 動詞]委任；任命…為軍官 If a member of the armed forces is commissioned, he or she is made an officer.
  [be V-ed as n]
  [V-ed]
  [Also be V-ed]
  [usu passive]

  • He was commissioned as second lieutenant in the Air Force...

    他被任命為空軍少尉。

  • Only commissioned officers qualify for the Military Cross.

    只有持委任狀的軍官才有資格獲得十字勳章。

9[PHRASE 短語](船、設備等)壞了的，不能使用的 If something, for example a ship or a piece of equipment, is out of commission, it is broken and cannot be used until it is repaired.
  [v-link PHR]

  • The operator expects the ship to be out of commission until the end of September.

    技工預計這艘船到9月底才能修好。

10See also:High Commission；

column5: v.犯罪；承諾；委託；托付
column6:
(1) They committed outrages on innocent citizens.
(2) He committed suicide rather than sell out to the enemy.
(3) He didn't commit himself to anything.
(4) The girl was committed to the care of an aunt.
column7:
(1) 他們對無辜的市民犯下了暴行。
(2) 他寧願自殺而沒有向敵人投降。
(3) 他沒有作任何承諾。
(4) 這女孩被交給姨母照顧。
column8: To commit is to fully dedicate yourself to something. To commit yourself to being the coolest kid on the beach means spending hours at the mall trying on trunks and flip-flops.
column9: Commit can also mean "perform an act" — often the kind that can get you in trouble. Just ask anyone who's committed theft, or arson, or vandalism. If you are committing another person, that means you are sending that person to an institution. Someone may be committed to prison, or to a psychiatric hospital for treatment.
column11:
1[VERB 動詞]犯(罪)；做(壞事) If someone commits a crime or a sin, they do something illegal or bad.
  [V n]

  • I have never committed any crime...

    我從來沒犯過罪。

  • This is a man who has committed murder.

    這是一個殺人犯。

  • ...the temptation to commit adultery.

    與人通姦的誘惑

2[VERB 動詞]自殺 If someone commits suicide, they deliberately kill themselves.
  [V n]

  • There are unconfirmed reports he tried to commit suicide.

    有未經證實的報道說他曾企圖自殺。

3[VERB 動詞]撥出，調配(資金、資源等) If you commit money or resources to something, you decide to use them for a particular purpose.
  [V n to/for n/-ing]
  [V n]

  • They called on Western nations to commit more money to the poorest nations...

    他們呼籲西方國家向極端貧困國家投入更多的錢。

  • The government had committed billions of pounds for a programme to reduce acid rain...

    政府已經給一個旨在減少酸雨的方案撥了幾十億英鎊。

  • He should not commit American troops without the full consent of Congress.

    沒有國會的完全同意，他不應該調遣美國軍隊。

4[VERB 動詞]承諾，保證(做)；忠於(某人) If you commit yourself to something, you say that you will definitely do it. If you commit yourself to someone, you decide that you want to have a long-term relationship with them.
  [V pron-refl to -ing/n]
  [V pron-refl]
  [V to n]
  [Also V n to n]

  • I would advise people to think very carefully about committing themselves to working Sundays...

    我建議大家慎重考慮一下答應週日工作的問題。

  • I'd like a friendship that might lead to something deeper, but I wouldn't want to commit myself too soon...

    我希望擁有一份能進一步發展的友誼，但又不想太快作出承諾。

  • You don't have to commit to anything over the phone.

    你不用在電話裡承諾什麼。

committed

  • He said the government remained committed to peace.

    他說政府仍然致力於和平。

  • ...a committed socialist.

    忠誠的社會主義者

5[VERB 動詞]明確表態 If you do not want to commit yourself on something, you do not want to say what you really think about it or what you are going to do.
  [V pron-refl on n]
  [V pron-refl]
  [with brd-neg]

  • It isn't their diplomatic style to commit themselves on such a delicate issue...

    對這樣一個微妙的問題明確表態並非他們的外交風格。

  • She didn't want to commit herself one way or the other.

    不管怎樣，她都不想明確表態。

6[VERB 動詞]把…正式送進(醫院、監獄等) If someone is committed to a hospital, prison, or other institution, they are officially sent there for a period of time.
  [be V-ed to n]
  [Also be V-ed]
  [usu passive]

  • Arthur's drinking caused him to be committed to a psychiatric hospital.

    阿瑟由於酗酒被送進一家精神病醫院。

7[VERB 動詞](英國)把…提交高等刑事法庭 In the British legal system, if someone is committed for trial, they are sent by magistrates to stand trial in a crown court.
  [be V-ed for n]
  [usu passive]

  • He is expected to be committed for trial at Liverpool Crown Court.

    預計他會被移交利物浦高等刑事法庭。

8[VERB 動詞]把…寫下來；把…記住 If you commit something to paper or to writing, you record it by writing it down. If you commit something to memory, you learn it so that you will remember it.
  [V n to n]

  • She had not committed anything to paper about it...

    關於這件事她未曾寫下隻言片語。

  • I'll repeat that so you can commit it to memory.

    我會重複一下，好讓你們記住。

column5: n.商品；日用品；有價值之物
column6:
(1) Coal is becoming a rare commodity.
(2) The country is heavily dependent on its exports of agricultural commodities.
(3) Time is our most valuable commodity.
column7:
(1) 煤正在成為一種稀缺商品。
(2) 這個國家很大程度上依靠農產品的出口。
(3) 時間是最有價值之物。
column8: A commodity is any useful or valuable thing, especially something that is bought and sold. Grain, vegetables, and precious metals are commodities, but so are personal qualities that can be used to make money: Originality and imagination are rare commodities in the film business.
column9: Farmers closely follow the commodities' markets, where the future value of the crops they grow are traded, and on any given day assigned a different value. Commodity descends from Middle English commodite "benefit, profit," from Old French, from Latin commoditās "fitness," from commodus "convenient, appropriate," from the prefix com- "with" plus modus "measure."
column11:
1[N-COUNT 可數名詞]商品 A commodity is something that is sold for money.
  [BUSINESS 商]

  • The government increased prices on several basic commodities like bread and meat.

    政府提高了麵包、肉類等幾種基本商品的價格。

column5: n.共產主義
column6:
(1) Communism is based on Marxism.
(2) Our ultimate aim is to realize communism.
(3) Marx is the progenitor of Communism.
column7:
(1) 共產主義是以馬克思主義為基礎。
(2) 我們的最終目的是實現共產主義。
(3) 馬克思是共產主義的創始人。
column8: At the opposite end of the spectrum from "capitalism," communism is an economic theory favoring a classless society and the abolition of private property.
column9: Communism derives from the French commun (common). Ideally, according to communism, society shares all property in common, everyone shares the burden of labor, and everyone shares the profits of that labor. Or, as the German philosopher Karl Marx wrote, "From each according to his ability, to each according to his need." As a system of government, communism is often closer to a form of socialism, in which the state owns and operates industry on behalf of the people.
column11:
1[N-UNCOUNT 不可數名詞]共產主義；共產主義信仰 Communism is the political belief that all people are equal and that workers should control the means of producing things.

  • ...the ultimate triumph of communism in the world.

    共產主義在世界上最終的勝利

column5: n.社區；社會；公眾；共同體；團體；共享；共有；[生]群落
column6:
(1) Here is a local Jewish community.
(2) Everyone should invest some time in community service.
(3) Community colleges have become popular and their enrollments have increased rapidly.
(4) The international community forbids use of any chemical weapons.
(5) The welfare of the community is the same as the welfare of its members.
(6) His action was interpreted as constituting a threat to the community.
(7) The political community is composed of a number of diverse economic and functional groups.
(8) He is ill reputed in the business community.
(9) There is a strong sense of community in this town.
(10) The appearance of the ecological community can vary depending on the time of year.
column7:
(1) 這是當地猶太人的一個社區。
(2) 每個人都應該花些時間在社區服務上。
(3) 社區大學日漸增多，報名人數迅速增長。
(4) 國際社會禁止使用一切化學武器。
(5) 社會的福利就等於其成員的福利。
(6) 他的行為被理解為是對公眾的威脅。
(7) 政治共同體由一系列在經濟上和功能上不同的團體組成。
(8) 他在商界名聲不好。
(9) 這個鎮上有一種強烈的社區意識。
(10) 生態群落的形態可能會根據一年之內時間的不同而變化。
column8: If a number of people consider themselves one group based on location, work, religion, nationality, or even activity, they can be called a community. If you like to play online games, you are active in the gamer community.
column9: The original meaning of Latin communitatem "a sense of fellowship" shifted to mean "a specific group of people with a common interest" during the Middle Ages. The modern English word community has both of these meanings available. Street festivals or school fairs can help to develop a sense of community in schools or neighborhoods. If you start a campaign to clean up the community, you want to make the area you live in more attractive.
column11:
1[N-SING-COLL 單數集合名詞](同住一地的人所構成的)社區 The community is all the people who live in a particular area or place.
  [usu the N]

  • He's well liked by people in the community...

    社區的人都非常喜歡他。

  • 'The community are getting impatient,' said a representative of the Residents' Association...

    「社區居民開始不耐煩了，」居民協會的一位代表說。

  • The growth of such vigilante gangs has worried community leaders, police and politicians.

    這類治安維持會成員組成的幫派的壯大讓社區領袖、警察和政界人士十分擔心。

2[N-COUNT-COLL 可數集合名詞]群體；團體 A particular community is a group of people who are similar in some way.
  [usu supp N]

  • The police haven't really done anything for the black community in particular.

    警方並未真正特意為黑人群體做什麼。

  • ...the business community.

    商界

3[N-UNCOUNT 不可數名詞](不同人士、團體之間的)友誼，夥伴關係 Community is friendship between different people or groups, and a sense of having something in common.

  • A supportive house for eight to ten older people, each with his or her own room, provides privacy and a sense of community...

    一幢扶助性住宅可供8至10位老人居住，每個人都有自己單獨的房間，在這裡，他們既能獨處，又有社區歸屬感。

  • Two of our greatest strengths are diversity and community.

    我們最大的兩個優勢是多樣性和團體精神。

column5:
v.通勤；折換；減刑；改變；交換
n.乘車上下班
column6:
(1) Mary used to commute five miles from her home in the suburb.
(2) They chose to commute equity into license agreements.
(3) Regular train travellers may commute a single monthly payment for daily tickets.
(4) He can commute pain for pleasure.
(5) These operators commute with each other.
(6) Her commute to work will be easy.
column7:
(1) 瑪麗過去每天從郊區的家裡走五英里來上班。
(2) 他們選擇了將股權轉換成許可協議。
(3) 經常坐火車的人可以按每天的票價折換購買月票。
(4) 他能變痛苦為快樂。
(5) 這些操作工經常交換崗位。
(6) 她上下班交通會很方便。
column8: A commute is a journey you take from home to work and back again. You might enjoy your subway commute because it gives you lots of time to read.
column9: Your commute is your trip to work, and the verb commute describes making that trip — like your preference to commute by public bus. Another meaning of commute describes changing the length of a judicial sentence, like when a judge commutes someone's time in jail. You can see this meaning in the word's origin — the Latin word commutare, meaning "to change altogether."
column11:
1[VERB 動詞](經很遠的路程)上下班往返；通勤 If you commute, you travel a long distance every day between your home and your place of work.
  [V to/from n]
  [V between n and n]
  [V]

  • Mike commutes to London every day...

    邁克每天都去倫敦上班。

  • McLaren began commuting between Paris and London...

    麥克拉倫開始往返於巴黎與倫敦之間。

  • He's going to commute.

    他打算乘長途車往返上下班。

commuter

  • The number of commuters to London has dropped by 100,000.
