    往返於倫敦的上班族減少了10萬。

  • ...a commuter train.

    通勤列車

2[N-COUNT 可數名詞]上下班路程 A commute is the journey that you make when you commute.
  [mainly AM 主美]

  • The average Los Angeles commute is over 60 miles a day.

    洛杉磯的平均上下班路程為每天60多英里。

3[VERB 動詞]減輕(刑罰) If a death sentence or prison sentence is commuted to a less serious punishment, it is changed to that punishment.
  [be V-ed to n]
  [be V-ed]
  [usu passive]

  • His death sentence was commuted to life imprisonment...

    他的死刑被減為無期徒刑。

  • Prison sentences have been commuted.

    服刑期得以減短。

column5:
adj.緊密的；緊湊的；簡潔的
vt.使簡潔；使裝滿；壓實
n.合約條約；梳妝粉盒；<美>小型汽車
column6:
(1) He received a compact package.
(2) Regulator shall be corrosion resistant, compact and lightweight.
(3) We'd love to buy a compact car.
(4) The kids are try to compact the sand into the mold.
(5) Heat and lack of rain have compacted the soil.
(6) You should sign your name on the right side of the compact.
column7:
(1) 他收到一個扎得很緊的包裹。
(2) 這種調節閥應該是耐腐蝕的，緊湊的和輕型的。
(3) 我們想買一輛簡潔的車。
(4) 孩子們正在設法把這沙土堆積到模子裡。
(5) 高熱少雨使土壤固結。
(6) 你應該在合約的右邊簽上你的名字。
column8: A compact is a signed written agreement that binds you to do what you've promised. It also refers to something small or closely grouped together, like the row of compact rental cars you see when you wanted a van.
column9: As a verb, compact means "to compress or squeeze together," like how the garbage truck compacts your bags of trash. Compact, the adjective, describes something that is tightly packed together, like your luggage that is so compact it fits in the overhead compartment. Compact can also describe a brief summary, like a compact explanation of how the universe began that lasted only 10 minutes!
column11:
The adjective and verb are pronounced /kəm'pakt/. The noun is pronounced /'kɒmpakt/. 形容詞和動詞讀作 /kəm'pakt/，名詞讀作 /'kɒmpakt/。
1[ADJ-GRADED 能被表示程度的副詞或介詞詞組修飾的形容詞]小而緊湊的 Compact things are small or take up very little space. You use this word when you think this is a good quality.
  [usu ADJ n]
  [approval]

  • ...my compact office in Washington.

    我在華盛頓小而緊湊的辦公室

  • ...the new, more compact Czech government.

    更為精簡的新捷克政府

compactness

  • The very compactness of the cottage made it all the more snug and appealing.

    正是村舍的小巧緊湊讓其更為溫暖舒適，也更有吸引力。

2[ADJ-GRADED 能被表示程度的副詞或介詞詞組修飾的形容詞]矮小結實的；矮壯的 A compact person is small but strong.

  • He was compact, probably no taller than me...

    他矮小壯實，可能並不比我高。

  • He looked physically very powerful, athletic in a compact way.

    他看上去非常強壯，像個敦實的運動員。

3[ADJ 形容詞]小巧的；袖珍的 A compact cassette, camera, or car is a small type of cassette, camera, or car.
  [ADJ n]
    4[VERB 動詞]把…壓實(或壓緊) To compact something means to press it so that it becomes more solid.
      [V n]
      [FORMAL 正式]

    • The Smith boy was compacting the trash...

      史密斯家的男孩在把垃圾壓緊。

    • The soil settles and is compacted by the winter rain.

      土壤沉積下來，然後在冬雨的作用下變得堅實。

    compacted

    • ...a pile of compacted earth.

      一堆壓實的土

    compaction

    • Regular forking of beds and borders relieves the compaction caused by rain.

      時常翻動一下花圃和草坪四周會讓被雨水壓緊的土壤鬆動鬆動。

    5[N-COUNT 可數名詞](內有鏡子的)化妝粉盒 A compact is a small, flat case that contains face powder and a mirror.

column5:
v.比較；對比；比喻
n.比較；對照
column6:
(1) I compared the copy with the original, but there was not much difference.
(2) The police compared the suspect's fingerprints with those found at the crime scene.
(3) Life is poetically compared to the morning dew.
(4) She is lovely beyond compare.
(5) Compare respirations and breath sounds with previous findings.
(6) Compare your answers with those at the back of the book to see if they are right.
column7:
(1) 我比較了複印件和原件，但是差別不是很大。
(2) 警察將嫌疑犯的指紋和犯罪現場的指紋進行了對比。
(3) 在詩歌中，人生被比喻為朝露。
(4) 她真是可愛得無與倫比。
(5) 將本次呼吸與呼吸音與前次檢查結果相對照。
(6) 把你的答案同書後面的答案對照一下，看看是否正確。
column8: To compare is to look at two things and see how they are similar and different.
column9: People compare all the time. If you look at two products and compare prices, you're looking for the better bargain. It is hard to compare who was the better athlete, Michael Jordan or Billie Jean King, because they played different sports. At a museum, you can compare different paintings. If you like your math teacher better than your history teacher, you're comparing the two. If a TV shows is bad, you could say "it doesn't compare" to your favorite show.
column11:
1[VERB 動詞]比較；對比 When you compare things, you consider them and discover the differences or similarities between them. to compare notes→see: note；
  [V pl-n]
  [V n with n]
  [V n to n]

  • Compare the two illustrations in Fig 60...

    比較圖60中的兩幅插圖。

  • Was it fair to compare independent schools with state schools?...

    拿私立學校與州立學校相比，這樣公平嗎？

  • Note how smooth the skin of the upper arm is, then compare it to the skin on the elbow.

    請注意上臂的皮膚是多麼光滑，然後把它和肘部的皮膚比較一下。

2[VERB 動詞]把…比作 If you compare one person or thing to another, you say that they are like the other person or thing.
  [V n to/with n/-ing]

  • Some commentators compared his work to that of James Joyce...

    有些評注者把他的作品與詹姆斯·喬伊斯的作品相提並論。

  • I can only compare the experience to falling in love.

    我只能把這段經歷比作墜入愛河。

3[V-RECIP 相互動詞](與…)比起來(好/差) If one thing compares favourably with another, it is better than the other thing. If it compares unfavourably, it is worse than the other thing.
  [V adv with n]
  [pl-n V adv]

  • Our road safety record compares favourably with that of other European countries...

    我們的道路安全紀錄比歐洲其他國家要好。

  • How do the two techniques compare in terms of application?

    這兩種手法實際運用起來哪個好一些？

4[VERB 動詞]相比 If you say that something does not compare with something else, you mean that it is much worse.
  [V with n]
  [usu with neg]

  • The flowers here do not compare with those at home...

    這兒的花比不上家鄉的花。

  • The more recent conifer plantations cannot yet compare with the old woodlands.

    年代較近的針葉樹林場還比不上年代久遠的林場。

5[PHRASE 短語]無與倫比；無可比擬 If you describe something as beyond compare, you mean that it is extremely good or extremely great.
  [n/adj PHR]
  [emphasis]
  [LITERARY 文]

  • She was a storyteller beyond compare.

    她是個無與倫比的講故事高手。

  • ...riches beyond compare.

    無與倫比的財富

6See also:compared；

column5:
n.圓規；指南針；範圍
vt.達到；圍繞；圖謀
column6:
(1) Now we begin to draw a circle with compasses.
(2) I need a compass to draw a circle.
(3) A compass needle points to the north.
(4) Finance is not within the compass of our department.
(5) Her action go beyond the compass of proper social behavior.
(6) In order to compass our object we must work hard.
(7) He tried his best to compass his purpose.
(8) The sailboat compassed the island.
(9) Suddenly we compassed the enemies on all sides.
column7:
(1) 現在我們開始用圓規畫一個圓。
(2) 我需要一支圓規畫圓。
(3) 羅盤的指針永遠指向北方。
(4) 財政不在我們這個部門的管轄範圍之內。
(5) 她的舉動越出了正當的社交行為的範圍。
(6) 為了達到我們的目標，我們必須努力工作。
(7) 他盡力去實現他的目標。
(8) 帆船繞島航行
(9) 我們突然從四面八方將敵人包圍了。
column8: Long before we had GPS (Global Positioning System) devices, people used a magnetic instrument called a compass for navigation. Some people still use a compass to navigate — usually when their GPS isn』t working.
column9: Compass can also refer to another type of instrument, one that』s used for drawing circles; this should be familiar to you if you have ever studied geometry. In addition, compass can mean "range" or "scope." If you decide to hike the Appalachian Trail, using a compass (the navigational kind) should hopefully fall within your compass of ability. If not, we hope you own a reliable GPS.
column11:
1[N-COUNT 可數名詞]指南針；羅盤 A compass is an instrument that you use for finding directions. It has a dial and a magnetic needle that always points to the north.

  • We had to rely on a compass and a lot of luck to get here.

    我們不得不依靠指南針和不錯的運氣找到這兒來。

2[N-PLURAL 複數名詞]圓規 Compasses are a hinged V-shaped instrument that you use for drawing circles.
  [also a pair of N]
    3[N-COUNT 可數名詞]界限；範圍 If something is within the compass of something or someone, it is within their limits or abilities.
      [usu sing]
      [FORMAL 正式]

    • Within the compass of a normal sized book such a comprehensive survey was not practicable.

      在通常一本書的篇幅中要作如此全面的調查不太實際。

column5: n.憐憫；同情
column6:
(1) I had compassion for him.
(2) He teaches us to have compassion on the poor.
(3) I should not have compassion for those lofty birds.
(4) We had compassion for the poor widow.
(5) The nurse had great compassion for her patients.
(6) I feel a measure of compassion for her.
(7) Compassion often engenders love.
column7:
(1) 我憐憫他。
(2) 他教導我們對窮人應有憐憫心。
(3) 我不會憐憫這些高貴的鳥。
(4) 我們同情這個可憐的寡婦。
(5) 那位護士十分同情她的病人。
(6) 我對她懷有一定程度的同情。
(7) 同情常會產生愛情。
column8: If someone shows kindness, caring, and a willingness to help others, they're showing compassion.
column9: This is a word for a very positive emotion that has to do with being thoughtful and decent. Giving to a charity takes compassion. Volunteering to work with sick people or animals takes compassion. When you have compassion, you're putting yourself in someone else's shoes and really feeling for them. Anytime a disaster like a hurricane or earthquake hits, others will feel compassion for the victims. When you feel compassion for someone, you really want to help out.
column11:
1[N-UNCOUNT 不可數名詞]憐憫；同情 Compassion is a feeling of pity, sympathy, and understanding for someone who is suffering.

  • Elderly people need time and compassion from their physicians.

    老年人需要醫生多花時間，還需要他們的關愛。

column5:
adj.一致的；兼容的；適合的
n.兼容
column6:
(1) The proposed new regulation is not compatible with the existing policy.
(2) We should remain the compatible family relationships.
(3) He and his wife are not compatible
(4) It may not be compatible with your version of Mac OS X.
(5) This program is not compatible with the Windows platform.
(6) You find yourself married to someone with whom you're not compatible.
(7) He drove a car at a speed compatible with safety.
column7:
(1) 提出的新規定與現有的政策不符。
(2) 我們應該維持和諧的家庭關係。
(3) 他跟他的妻子合不來。
(4) 它可能與您的Mac OS X版本不兼容。
(5) 這個程序與Windows平台不兼容。
(6) 你發現你嫁給了一個你不適合的人。
(7) 他以安全速度行車。
column8: A word that comes up a lot in discussions of both food and people pairings, compatible speaks to a person or thing』s ability to exist agreeably with something or someone else.
column9: Use the word compatible to describe two things that work well together, like your Wii and your big screen TV, or peanut butter and jelly. You may have heard that opposites attract, but initial attraction doesn』t necessarily mean that opposites will be compatible in the long-term. Advised Russian novelist and philosopher Leo Tolstoy, 「What counts in making a happy marriage is not so much how compatible you are, but how you deal with incompatibility.」
column11:
1[ADJ-GRADED 能被表示程度的副詞或介詞詞組修飾的形容詞](系統、想法和信仰)兼容的，可以並存的 If things, for example systems, ideas, and beliefs, are compatible, they work well together or can exist together successfully.
  [oft ADJ with n]

  • Free enterprise, he argued, was compatible with Russian values and traditions...

    他認為自由企業制並不違背俄羅斯的價值觀和傳統。

  • Marriage and the life I live just don't seem compatible.

    婚姻和我的生活好像就是沒法兼容。

compatibility

  • National courts can freeze any law while its compatibility with European legislation is being tested.

    任一法律與歐洲立法有所衝突時，本國法院可以停止該法的實行。

2[ADJ-GRADED 能被表示程度的副詞或介詞詞組修飾的形容詞]能和諧相處的；合得來的 If you say that you are compatible with someone, you mean that you have a good relationship with them because you have similar opinions and interests.
  [oft ADJ with n]

  • Mildred and I are very compatible. She's interested in the things that interest me...

    我和米爾德麗德很合得來，我感興趣的東西她也感興趣。

  • In a large city you're almost certain to find a physician with whom you are compatible and feel comfortable.

    在大城市，幾乎肯定能找到一個和你意氣相投、讓你覺得舒心的心靈撫慰者。

compatibility

  • As a result of their compatibility, Haig and Fraser were able to bring about wide-ranging reforms.

    黑格和弗雷澤意氣相投，在一起能夠推行大範圍的改革。

3[ADJ 形容詞](尤指與 IBM公司製造的計算機或計算機設備)兼容的 If one make of computer or computer equipment is compatible with another make, especially IBM, they can be used together and can use the same software.
  [oft ADJ with n]
  [COMPUTING 計算機]

column5: v.強迫；迫使；使不得已
column6:
(1) Nothing can compel me to do such a thing.
(2) I was compelled to do so by absolute necessity.
(3) The heavy rain compelled us to stay indoors.
(4) Duty compelled the soldiers to volunteer for the mission.
(5) Her intelligence and skill compel our admiration.
column7:
(1) 沒有什麼可以強迫我做這件事。
(2) 我因絕對的需要,被迫這樣做的。
(3) 大雨迫使我們呆在戶內。
(4) 責任驅使軍人必須志願加入此任務
(5) 她的聰明和技巧使我們非常佩服。
column8: Compel means to force or drive someone to do something. Even if you don't like toast, when you visit the toast-eating natives of Shrintakook Island, you'll be compelled to eat it, or they will not trust you.
column9: You don't want to be compelled to go to a classical music concert if you'd rather listen to rap. School officials might be upset if a winter storm compels them to cancel classes, but you'd be okay with that. A compelling mystery forces you to pay attention because you want to find out "whodunit."
column11:
1[VERB 動詞]強迫；逼迫 If a situation, a rule, or a person compels you to do something, they force you to do it.
  [V n to-inf]
  [Also V n]

  • ...the introduction of legislation to compel cyclists to wear a helmet...

    強制騎自行車者戴頭盔的法律的出台

  • Leonie's mother was compelled to take in washing to help support her family...

    利奧妮的媽媽被迫在家替人洗衣服，以貼補家用。

  • Local housing authorities have been compelled by the housing crisis to make offers of sub-standard accommodation.

    住房危機迫使當地的幾個房管部門提供不夠標準的住房。

2[PHRASE 短語]覺得必須(做…) If you feel compelled to do something, you feel that you must do it, because it is the right thing to do.
  [V inflects]

  • Dickens felt compelled to return to the stage for a final good-bye...

    迪肯斯覺得必須返回舞台作最後的道別。

  • I felt morally compelled to help.

    我覺得從道義上我必須幫忙。

column5: adj.引人注目的；緊迫的；令人信服的
column6:
(1) Her latest book makes compelling reading.
(2) She was really a strange, eager, compelling young woman.
(3) Leaves grown very lush, flowers are opening in full swing, very compelling.
(4) I have no compelling reasons to refuse.
(5) I should not have done so, other than for the most compelling reasons.
(6) It is a compelling study of personal identity.
(7) The lawyer's compelling arguments convinced the jury of the defendant's innocence.
column7:
(1) 她新出的書讀起來扣人心弦。
(2) 她真是個奇特，熱切而令人難以抗拒的年輕女人。
(3) 樹葉長得很茂盛，花也開得如火如荼，非常引人注目。
(4) 我沒有驅使我拒絕的理由。
(5) 要不是出於非常緊迫的原因，我本不應該這樣唐突的。
(6) 這是一部關於人身份的研究，令人信服。
(7) 律師令人信服的辯詞使陪審團相信了被告的無辜。
column8: Compelling means attractive, or irresistible, or really, really convincing. You know your argument for backpacking across Europe is compelling when your parents not only let you go but also pay for all your expenses.
column9: To compel is to drive or force into action––you mom could compel you to finish your homework by threatening not to feed you until it's done. A compelling argument compels you to agree with its logic––it's irresistible. That cute skirt you』ve been eyeing for months is now 75% off? The price is a compelling reason to buy the skirt.
column11:
1[ADJ-GRADED 能被表示程度的副詞或介詞詞組修飾的形容詞]令人信服的；有說服力的 A compelling argument or reason is one that convinces you that something is true or that something should be done.
  [usu ADJ n]

  • Factual and forensic evidence makes a suicide verdict the most compelling answer to the mystery of his death...

    事實證據和法庭證據使得自殺成為解開他死因之謎的最令人信服的答案。

  • My second and more compelling reason for going to Dearborn was to see the Henry Ford Museum.

    我去迪爾伯恩的第二個原因，也是更令人信服的原因，是為了參觀亨利·福特博物館。

2[ADJ-GRADED 能被表示程度的副詞或介詞詞組修飾的形容詞]非常有趣的；很有吸引力的 If you describe something such as a film or book, or someone's appearance, as compelling, you mean you want to keep looking at it or reading it because you find it so interesting.

  • ...a frighteningly violent yet compelling film...

    有可怕的暴力鏡頭但卻引人入勝的電影

  • Her eyes were her best feature, wide-set and compelling.

    她的眼睛是她五官中長得最好的，大而迷人。

compellingly

  • She wrote compellingly, with great zest.

    她滿懷熱情，饒有興致地寫著。

column5: v.補償；賠償；付報酬
column6:
(1) Nothing can compensate for the loss of one's health.
(2) She was compensated by the insurance company for her injuries.
(3) You will have to compensate us for the loss.
column7:
(1) 什麼都不能補償健康受損。
(2) 她受傷後獲得保險公司的賠償。
(3) 你必須賠償我們的損失。
column8: Compensate is about correcting for an imbalance. If you step in an unmarked pothole, the city may compensate you by paying your doctor bills treating a broken ankle.
column9: Compensate can also mean "to adjust for." So, if you did stumble into the pothole and injure your left leg, then you might compensate by leaning heavily on your right leg. Increasingly, compensate is used in place of pay. Day laborers are paid for their time, but executives are more likely to be compensated with a suite that includes salary and other benefits––what is commonly referred to as a compensation package.
column11:
1[VERB 動詞]賠償；補償 To compensate someone for money or things that they have lost means to pay them money or give them something to replace that money or those things.
  [V n for n]
  [Also V n]

  • The official promise to compensate people for the price rise clearly hadn't been worked out properly...

    顯然，官方對物價上漲進行補償的承諾沒有真正兌現。

  • To ease financial difficulties, farmers could be compensated for their loss of subsidies.

    為了緩解經濟困難，農場主們損失的補貼會得到補償。

2[VERB 動詞]彌補；補償 If you compensate for a lack of something or for something you have done wrong, you do something to make the situation better.
  [V for n]
  [V]

  • The company agreed to keep up high levels of output in order to compensate for supplies lost...

    這家公司同意保持高產量以彌補供貨丟失帶來的缺口。

  • She would then feel guilt for her anger and compensate by doing even more for the children.

    之後她會因為自己發火而感到愧疚，會替孩子們做更多的事作為補償。

3[VERB 動詞]抵消 Something that compensates for something else balances it or reduces its effects.
  [V for n]

  • MPs say it is crucial that a system is found to compensate for inflation...

    下議院的議員們說關鍵是要找到一種抵消通貨膨脹影響的機制。

  • The pluses more than compensated for the inconveniences involved in making the trip.

    各種有利因素大大抵消了出行過程中的種種不便。

4[VERB 動詞]彌補(過失或不足) If you try to compensate for something that is wrong or missing in your life, you try to do something that removes or reduces the harmful effects.
  [V]
  [V for n]

  • People who sense that they are inferior have to compensate, and often over-compensate by way of outward achievement.

    覺得自卑的人只有通過外在的成就來彌補自己的不足，但往往都做過了頭。

  • No supportive words could ever compensate for the pain of being separated from her children for 10 years.

    任何表示支持的言語都無法彌補與孩子們分開10年帶給她的痛苦。

column5: vt.編譯；編製；編纂
column6:
(1) We are trying to compile a list of suitable people for the job.
(2) How do we compile a balance of payments statements?
(3) It takes many years of hard work to compile a good dictionary.
(4) We are able to design and compile teaching materials as customers'needs.
column7:
(1) 我們在努力編製一份適合做這項工作的人員的名單。
(2) 我們如何編製收支平衡表?
(3) 編纂一部好詞典要花多年心血。
(4) 我們可以根據客戶的情況設計和編寫教材。
column8: When you compile something, like a recipe-book or a mix-tape, you put it together using things that already exist (recipes, songs).
column9: Poetry anthologies, greatest-hits albums, and world-record books are all compilations, because they're made up of things that were originally published or released somewhere else. If you want to skip out on soccer practice one day, you might compile of list of excuses.
column11:
1[VERB 動詞]彙編；編製；編纂 When you compile something such as a report, book, or programme, you produce it by collecting and putting together many pieces of information.
  [V n]
  [V-ed]

  • Councils were required to compile a register of all adults living in their areas...

    各地政務委員會被要求編製一份該地區成年居民的名冊。

  • The book took 10 years to compile...

    編這本書花了10年時間。

  • A report compiled by the Fed's Philadelphia branch described the economy as weak.

    一份由聯邦儲備銀行的費城分部彙編的報告說經濟不景氣。

compilation

  • There have been enormous advances in the compilation of data on suspected terrorists.

    恐怖嫌疑犯的資料收集工作已經取得了非常大的進展。

column5: adj.滿足的；自滿的；得意的
column6:
(1) To anyone who has actually witnessed these final stages, the complacent poeticizing of these adolescents must seem as exasperating as they are profoundly pathetic.
(2) This lets Li Dapeng's complacent place just about.
column7:
(1) 對目睹過晚期狀態的人來說，這些年輕人自我滿足的詩情必定會顯得令人氣惱又覺得可憐。
(2) 這正是讓李大鵬得意的地方。
column8: Someone who is complacent has become overly content — the junk-food-eating couch potato might be feeling complacent about his health.
column9: The literal meaning of this word's Latin root is "very pleased," but even though complacent people may seem pleased with themselves, we are rarely pleased with them. They are unconcerned by things that should concern them, and they may neglect their duties. A complacent person might be heard saying, "Ehh, don't worry about it!" — when there really is something to worry about.
column11:
1[ADJ-GRADED 能被表示程度的副詞或介詞詞組修飾的形容詞]自滿的；沾沾自喜的；滿不在乎的 A complacent person is very pleased with themselves or feels that they do not need to do anything about a situation, even though the situation may be uncertain or dangerous.
  [disapproval]

  • We cannot afford to be complacent about our health.

    對於健康我們決不能掉以輕心。

  • ...the Chancellor's complacent attitude towards the far-right's activities.

    總理對極右分子活動表現出的不以為意

complacently

  • He sat back, smiling complacently at his own cleverness.

    他身子往後一靠，為自己的聰明得意地笑了。

column5:
vt.相輔相成
n.補足物；補語；余角
column6:
(1) This wine complements the food perfectly.
(2) His business skill complements her flair for design.
(3) A wine is a complement to a good meal.
(4) In the sentence 'I'm angry', 'angry' is the complement.
column7:
(1) 用這種酒配這種菜餚最妙不過了。
(2) 他的經營技巧和她的設計才能相輔相成。
(3) 美食加美酒才算完備。
(4) 在I'm angry一句中,angry是補語。
column8: A complement is something that makes up a satisfying whole with something else. Those shiny red shoes you just bought complement your shiny red purse.
column9: Complement comes from the Latin complementum, "something that fills up or completes." Complement keeps both the e and the meaning. It's also a verb; if you and your partner complement each other, you make a perfect pair. Something that complements completes or adds a little something.
column11:
The verb is pronounced /'kɒmplɪment/. The noun is pronounced /'kɒmplɪmənt/. 動詞讀作 /'kɒmplɪment/。名詞讀作 /'kɒmplɪmənt/。
1[VERB 動詞]使(優點)突出；襯托出 If one thing complements another, it goes well with the other thing and makes its good qualities more noticeable.
  [V n]

  • Nutmeg, parsley and cider all complement the flavour of these beans well.

    肉豆蔻、西芹和蘋果酒都能很好地突出這些豆子的味道。

2[VERB 動詞]補足；補充；與…相輔相成 If people or things complement each other, they are different or do something different, which makes them a good combination.
  [V n]

  • There will be a written examination to complement the practical test...

    會有筆試作為實踐考試的補充。

  • We complement one another perfectly.

    我們相互取長補短，堪稱完美。

3[N-COUNT 可數名詞]襯托物；補足物 Something that is a complement to something else complements it.
  [usu sing]

  • The green wallpaper is the perfect complement to the old pine of the dresser...

    綠色的牆紙完美地襯托出衣櫥那年代久遠的松木。

  • Political knowledge is a necessary complement to science in approaching solutions to these problems.

    在尋找解決這些問題的方法時，需要有政治知識作為對科學知識的補充。

4[N-COUNT 可數名詞]裝備定額；編製名額 The complement of things or people that something has is the number of things or people that it normally has, which enable it to function properly.
  [usu sing]
  [FORMAL 正式]

  • Each ship had a complement of around a dozen officers and 250 men...

    每艘船的編制人數約為軍官12位，船員250名。

  • Not one house on the Close still had its full complement of windows.

    克洛斯島上沒有一所房子的窗戶仍舊是齊全的。

5[N-COUNT 可數名詞]補語 In grammar, the complement of a link verb is an adjective group or noun group which comes after the verb and describes or identifies the subject. For example, in the sentence 'They felt very tired', 'very tired' is the complement. In 'They were students', 'students' is the complement.

column5:
adj.複雜的；合成的；復合的
n.綜合體；復合體；[醫]綜合症狀；[心]情結
column6:
(1) It was a complex problem.
(2) Complex briary fruit with smoldering oak.
(3) They also provide composable functionality required to support complex, large-scale systems.
(4) Libraries are great complexes of tiny items.
(5) The synaptonemal complex is protein in nature.
(6) An inferiority complex is very harmful to you and is the greatest obstacle .
column7:
(1) 這是一個複雜的問題。
(2) 有復合的水果香和煙熏橡木香。
(3) 並提供可復合的功能以支持複雜的大規模系統。
(4) 圖書館是細小類目的大綜合體。
(5) 聯合復合體實質上是蛋白質。
(6) 自卑心是最傷害自己的，是最大的障礙。
column8: People who are really good at math can handle complex math problems. The rest of us are all set with simple stuff like the times tables. Use complex to refer to something that is not simple.
column9: Something complex has two or more related parts, or is not simple in its structure. As a noun, a complex is a group of units, often a group of buildings. The adjective is stressed on the second syllable, but the noun is stressed on the first syllable. Complex is from Latin complexus, from complecti "to encircle or embrace."
column11:
The adjective is pronounced /kəm'pleks/ in American English. 用作形容詞時在美國英語中讀作 /kəm'pleks/。
1[ADJ-GRADED 能被表示程度的副詞或介詞詞組修飾的形容詞]複雜的；錯綜的 Something that is complex has many different parts, and is therefore often difficult to understand.

  • ...in-depth coverage of today's complex issues.

    對時下一些複雜問題的深度報道

  • ...a complex system of voting.

    錯綜複雜的選舉體制

  • ...her complex personality.

    她複雜的性格

  • ...complex machines.

    結構複雜的機器

2[ADJ 形容詞](句子)復合的 In grammar, a complex sentence contains one or more subordinate clauses as well as a main clause.
  [ADJ n]
    3[N-COUNT 可數名詞]綜合建築群；綜合大樓 A complex is a group of buildings designed for a particular purpose, or one large building divided into several smaller areas.
      [usu with supp]

    • ...plans for constructing a new stadium and leisure complex.

      修建新體育場和休閒中心的計劃

    • ...a complex of offices and flats.

      商住綜合樓

    4[N-COUNT 可數名詞]錯綜複雜的組合；復合體 A complex of things is a group or system of things that are connected with each other in a complicated way.
      [with supp]

    • ...the complex of clans which occupied the land.

      生活在這片土地上的關係複雜的氏族群落

    • ...the military-industrial complex.

      軍工綜合企業

    5[N-COUNT 可數名詞]See also:guilt complex；inferiority complex；(通常指由於過去不愉快的經歷而形成的)情結 If someone has a complex about something, they have a mental or emotional problem relating to it, often because of an unpleasant experience in the past.

    • I have never had a complex about my height.

      我從來沒有擔心過自己的身高。

    • ...a deranged attacker, driven by a persecution complex.

      患有受迫害妄想症、精神失常的襲擊者

column5: n.膚色；面色；體質；特性；局面
column6:
(1) That colour doesn't suit your complexion.
(2) He has a dark complexion.
(3) She has a pale complexion.
(4) Her sparkling jewellery served as the perfect foil for her fine complexion.
(5) This great victory changed the complexion of the war.
column7:
(1) 那顏色不適合你的膚色。
(2) 他膚色黝黑。
(3) 她面色蒼白。
(4) 她戴著閃閃生輝的首飾,更顯得容貌姣好。
(5) 這次大捷使整個戰局為之改觀。
column8: Complexion refers to the color of a person's skin, especially the face. If you have light skin, for example, you might be said to have a fair or pale complexion.
column9: The general character of something can also be called its complexion. If your team's star quarterback is out with an injury, it will change the complexion of the next game and possibly the entire season. Complexion originally referred to the humors that in ancient Greek and Roman medicine supposedly made up a person's temperament and health. The word came from the Latin complexionem, or "combination," but as humorism fell out of favor, this definition of complexion also became obsolete.
column11:
1[N-COUNT 可數名詞]膚色；面色 When you refer to someone's complexion, you are referring to the natural colour or condition of the skin on their face.
  [oft adj N]

  • She had short brown hair and a pale complexion.

    她留著褐色短髮，皮膚白皙。

  • ...those with acne or oily complexions.

    臉上有粉刺或油性膚質的人

  • ...her flawless complexion.

    她光潔的面部皮膚

2[N-COUNT 可數名詞]性質；特性 The complexion of something is its general nature or character.
  [with supp]
  [FORMAL 正式]

  • Every time the political complexion of the government changed, so did the defence policy...

    每當政府的政治性質發生變化，國防政策也會隨之變化。

  • But surely this puts a different complexion on things.

    但是這肯定讓局勢有了變化。

column5:
adj.複雜難懂的；結構複雜的
動詞complicate的過去式和過去分詞.
column6:
(1) The novel is too complicated for your age.
(2) The tax laws are so complicated that only an expert can provide enlightenment.
(3) Obtaining a refund from the company is a complicated procedure.
(4) An automobile is a complicated apparatus.
(5) The business is a large, complicated organism.
column7:
(1) 這小說就你的年齡來說太複雜了。
(2) 稅務法非常複雜，只有專家才能解釋清楚。
(3) 向公司索取退款手續很複雜。
(4) 汽車是台複雜的機器.
(5) 該企業是一個大而複雜的組織。
column8: When things get complicated, they are no longer simple and straightforward. If you are asked a question that would require a long, detailed answer, you might just say, "It's complicated."
column9: The word complicated came about in the 1640's to mean "tangled" or "difficult to unravel." This makes sense, considering it came from the Latin verb complicāre, meaning "to fold together." Consider that something with many folds is more complicated than something flat. Novelist Robert Ludlum said, "Life is extremely complicated," but Confucius long ago suggested that "Life is really simple, but we insist on making it complicated." Just having those two opposing viewpoints indicates how complicated life can be.
column11:
1[ADJ-GRADED 能被表示程度的副詞或介詞詞組修飾的形容詞]複雜的；難懂的；難處理的 If you say that something is complicated, you mean it has so many parts or aspects that it is difficult to understand or deal with.

  • The situation in Lebanon is very complicated.

    黎巴嫩的情況十分複雜。

  • ...a very complicated voting system.

    非常複雜的選舉體制

column5:
n.稱讚；恭維；(複數)致意
vt.恭維；稱讚
column6:
(1) I was embarrassed by their compliment.
(2) I feel greatly flattered at your compliment.
(3) They paid him a high compliment.
(4) My compliments to your wife.
(5) He complimented her on her new dress without even looking at it.
column7:
(1) 對他們的稱讚我感到很不安。
(2) 我對你的稱讚感到受寵若驚。
(3) 他們非常恭維他。
(4) 向您的夫人致意。
(5) 他連看都沒看一眼，就稱頌她的新衣服。
column8: A compliment is an expression of respect or admiration, like, "You're such a good writer," or "You know so many words!" Keep them coming.
column9: Compliments are always welcome, because they usually make people feel good. It』s saying something nice about someone or something. If you get mysterious flowers, look at the card – perhaps it will say 「compliments of your upstairs neighbors,」 as an apology for playing their music too loud all night. Or if you say, 「my compliments to the chef!」 you really liked your meal.
column11:
The verb is pronounced /'kɒmplɪment/. The noun is pronounced /'kɒmplɪmənt/. 動詞讀作 /'kɒmplɪment/。名詞讀作 /'kɒmplɪmənt/。
1[N-COUNT 可數名詞]讚美；恭維(話) A compliment is a polite remark that you say to someone to show that you like their appearance, appreciate their qualities, or approve of what they have done.

  • You can do no harm by paying a woman compliments...

    對女人說些恭維話沒有壞處。

  • 'Well done, Cassandra,' Crook said. She blushed, but accepted the compliment with good grace.

    「幹得好，卡桑德拉。」克魯克說。她臉一下子紅了，但還是很有風度地接受了恭維。

2[VERB 動詞]讚美；恭維 If you compliment someone, you pay them a compliment.
  [V n on n]
  [Also V n]

  • They complimented me on the way I looked each time they saw me...

    每次見到我，他們都稱讚我的外貌。

  • Firstly I compliment you on most of your excellent Spring issue of 'Triangle'.

    首先，讓我來誇幾句，你們《三角迷蹤》春季號的大部分內容都非常精彩。

3[N-COUNT 可數名詞]讚美；讚賞 If you consider something that a person says or does as a compliment, it convinces you of your own good qualities, or that the person appreciates you.

  • We consider it a compliment to be called 'conservative'...

    我們認為被稱作「保守分子」是對我們的一種讚賞。

  • It's obvious he's worried about us and I'm taking it as a compliment.

    顯然他擔心我們，我把這當做一種讚美。

4[N-PLURAL 複數名詞]致謝；祝賀；致意 You can refer to your compliments when you want to express thanks, good wishes, or respect to someone in a formal way.
  [usu poss N]
  [politeness]

  • My compliments to the chef...

    請向廚師代為致意！

  • Give my compliments to your lovely wife when you write home.

    寫信回家的時候，代我問候你可愛的妻子。

5[PHRASE 短語]回報；回敬 If you say that someone returns the compliment, you mean that they do the same thing to someone else as that person has done to them.
  [V inflects]

  • The actors have entertained us so splendidly during this weekend, I think it's time we returned the compliment.

    這週末演員們給我們帶來了精彩的演出，我覺得我們該回請他們了。

6[PHRASE 短語](尤指贈送禮物或給予幫助時)…敬贈，請接受…的敬意 If you say that you are giving someone something with your compliments, you are saying in a polite and fairly formal way that you are giving it to them, especially as a gift or a favour.
  [PHR after v]
  [politeness]

  • Please give this to your boss with my compliments...

    請把這個給你的老闆，算是我的一點心意。

  • On my bedside table awaited, with the compliments of the management, an appetizing breakfast.

    一份讓人垂涎的早餐擺在我的床頭桌上，那是管理人員的一點小意思。

column5: adj.問候的；稱讚的；免費贈送的
column6:
(1) My boss was very complimentary about my work.
(2) She was highly complimentary about my paintings.
(3) My boss was very complimentary about my work.
(4) Don't be fooled by all his complimentary remarks they were all said with tongue in cheek.
(5) The small gift box is complimentary.
(6) Would you like a complimentary drink?
column7:
(1) 老闆對我的工作極其稱讚。
(2) 她對我的畫給予了高度評價.
(3) 老闆對我的工作極其稱讚。
(4) 別讓他的恭維話給糊弄住--那些話可當不得真。
(5) 這個小禮品盒是免費贈送。
(6) 您要一點免費的飲品嗎?
column8: If you say something complimentary, like, "Grandma, that plastic flower looks so pretty in your hair," you are flattering, praising or admiring someone.
column9: Resembling a compliment is one way to define the word complimentary, when you use it in the sense of giving praise. A second meaning of complimentary is "free." If your hotel includes breakfast with the price of your room, they may call it a complimentary breakfast. It's easy to get complimentary confused with complementary, which sounds exactly the same but means "filling in or completing."
column11:
1[ADJ-GRADED 能被表示程度的副詞或介詞詞組修飾的形容詞]讚美的；讚揚的 If you are complimentary about something, you express admiration for it.
  [usu v-link ADJ]

  • The staff have been very complimentary, and so have the customers...

    員工們對此大加讚揚，顧客們也一樣。

  • We often get complimentary remarks regarding the cleanliness of our patio.

    我們經常聽人稱讚我們的露台非常乾淨。

2[ADJ 形容詞](座位、票或書)免費贈送的 A complimentary seat, ticket, or book is given to you free.
  [usu ADJ n]

  • He had complimentary tickets to take his wife to see the movie.

    他有幾張贈票，可以帶妻子去看電影。

  • ...a complimentary copy of Dr Sherwood's recently published book.

    捨伍德博士最近出版的作品的贈書

column5:
n.零部件；元件；組成部分；成分
adj.組成的；構成的
column6:
(1) Each of the components is useful in its degree.
(2) The militia is a component of the state's armed forces.
(3) A chemist can seperate a medicine into its components.
(4) Can you resolve it into its component elements?
(5) The processing and assembling business is a component part of our foreign trade.
column7:
(1) 每一個元件都各有程度不同的用處。
(2) 民兵是國家武裝力量的組成部分。
(3) 化學家能把一種藥物的各種成分分解出來。
(4) 你能把它分解為組成它的元素嗎?
(5) 加工裝配貿易是我們對外貿易的一個組成部分。
column8: It's the Ikea curse: You spend four hours figuring out how to piece together your new furniture, only to be left with one random component, or part, that doesn't seem to fit anywhere.
column9: It's not surprising that component is related to a Latin word that means "to put together." You simply can't put something together without all of the correct components. Technically speaking, a component is an element of a system or a part of a machine. But a component can also be a factor or ingredient, such as the components of a decision or the components of a really good chocolate cake.
column11:
1[N-COUNT 可數名詞]組成部分；成分 The components of something are the parts that it is made of.

  • Enriched uranium is a key component of a nuclear weapon...

    濃縮鈾是核武器的關鍵組成部分。

  • The management plan has four main components...

    管理計劃有4個主要部分。

  • They were automotive component suppliers to motor manufacturers.

    他們為汽車製造商供應汽車零件。

2[ADJ 形容詞]組成的；構成的 The component parts of something are the parts that make it up.
  [ADJ n]

  • Gorbachev failed to keep the component parts of the Soviet Union together...

    戈爾巴喬夫沒能把蘇聯各成員國團結在一起。

  • Polish workers will now be making component parts for Boeing 757s.

    現在波音757飛機的組成部件將由波蘭工人製造。

column5: v.作曲；創作；編排；形成；使鎮靜
column6:
(1) She began to compose songs at an early age.
(2) He was composing at the piano at the age of seven.
(3) He sat down and composed a letter of resignation.
(4) Water is composed of hydrogen and oxygen.
(5) Compose yourself and try to tell me what happened.
column7:
(1) 她還很年輕時就已經開始創作歌曲。
(2) 他7歲時就會鋼琴作曲。
(3) 他坐下來,寫了一封辭職信。
(4) 水由氫和氧組成。
(5) 慢慢來,告訴我發生什麼事情了。
column8: To compose is to put something together, like a song, poem, or even yourself. You might want to compose yourself before returning to the party after a good cry.
column9: The word compose began with the Latin ponere, which means "to put, place," referring to placing or arranging any piece of work. It's been in the music business since the 1590s, and it's generally still used to describe the act of writing songs. But you can use it whenever you're pulling something together: you might compose an essay for English class, or notice that the class is composed of all girls.
column11:
1[VERB 動詞]組成；構成 The things that something is composed of are its parts or members. The separate things that compose something are the parts or members that form it.
  [be V-ed of n]
  [V n]
  [V-ed]

  • The force would be composed of troops from NATO countries...

    這支軍隊將由來自北約國家的部隊組成。

  • Protein molecules compose all the complex working parts of living cells...

    活細胞中所有複雜的運行成分都由蛋白質分子構成。

  • They agreed to form a council composed of leaders of the rival factions.

    他們同意成立一個由敵對派系的領袖組成的委員會。

2[VERB 動詞]譜寫(樂曲)；作(曲) When someone composes a piece of music, they write it.
  [V n]
  [V]

  • Vivaldi composed a large number of very fine concertos...

    維瓦爾第創作了很多非常優美的協奏曲。

  • Cale also uses electronic keyboards to compose.

    凱爾也用電子鍵盤譜曲。

3[VERB 動詞]創作，寫(信、詩或演講稿) If you compose something such as a letter, poem, or speech, you write it, often using a lot of concentration or skill.
  [V n]
  [V-ed]
  [FORMAL 正式]

  • He started at once to compose a reply to Anna...

    他馬上開始給安娜寫回信。

  • The document composed in Philadelphia transformed the confederation of sovereign states into a national government.

    在費城起草的這份文件使具有獨立主權的各州組成的邦聯變成了國家政府。

4[VERB 動詞]為（照片、圖像）構圖 If you compose a picture or image, you arrange it in an attractive and artistic way.
  [V n]
  [V-ed]
  [TECHNICAL 術語]

  • Anthony dismounted with his camera and walked away from the walls to compose a shot...

    安東尼拿著照相機下了車，走向離城牆更遠的地方，為拍攝構圖。

  • The drawing is beautifully composed.

    這幅畫的構圖很美。

5[VERB 動詞]使（自己）平靜(或鎮定)；使（表情）鎮靜下來 If you compose yourself or if you compose your features, you succeed in becoming calm after you have been angry, excited, or upset.
  [V pron-refl]
  [V n]

  • She quickly composed herself as the car started off...

    車一上路，她就很快讓自己平靜了下來。

  • Then he composed his features, took Godwin's hand awkwardly and began to usher him from the office.

    然後他定了定神，尷尬地牽著戈德溫的手，開始引領他離開辦公室。

column5: n.成分；作品；組織；作文；合成物
column6:
(1) We examined the rock to find out its composition.
(2) He played many of his compositions for me.
(3) `Swan Lake' is one of Tchaikovsky's best-known compositions.
(4) You've made several grammatical mistakes in the composition.
(5) The composition has copper and zine in it.
column7:
(1) 我們檢驗了這一石塊,想弄清它的構成成分。
(2) 他為我演奏了他的許多樂曲。
(3) 《天鵝湖》是柴可夫斯基最著名的作品之一。
(4) 你的作文中犯了幾處語法錯誤。
(5) 這種合成物裡有銅和鋅。
column8: Composition is another word for writing — the act of writing or the piece of writing that results. It also refers to what something is made of.
column9: The word composition comes from the Latin componere, meaning "put together" and its meaning remains close to this. Writing classes are often called composition classes, and writing music is also called composition. This can also describe things besides writing that are "put together." You could say an abstract painting has an interesting composition. Any mixture of ingredients can be called a composition. Geologists study the composition of the earth: what it's made of and how it formed.
column11:
1[N-UNCOUNT 不可數名詞]組成；構成；組合方式 When you talk about the composition of something, you are referring to the way in which its various parts are put together and arranged.
  [usu with supp]

  • Television has transformed the size and social composition of the audience at great sporting occasions...

    電視改變了重大體育賽事觀眾的規模和其社會階層構成結構。

  • Forests vary greatly in composition from one part of the country to another.

    一個國家不同區域的森林在組成結構上存在很大的差異。

2[N-COUNT 可數名詞](作曲家、畫家等的)作品 The compositions of a composer, painter, or other artist are the works of art that they have produced.

  • Mozart's compositions are undoubtedly amongst the world's greatest.

    莫扎特的作品無疑位居世界上最偉大的作品之列。

3[N-COUNT 可數名詞](學生的)作文 A composition is a piece of written work that children write at school.
    4[N-UNCOUNT 不可數名詞]藝術創作技巧 Composition is the technique or skill involved in creating a work of art.

    • He taught the piano, organ and composition...

      他教授鋼琴、管風琴和作曲。

    • The course is designed to help students with colour and composition.

      設置這門課程是為了指導學生如何運用色彩和構圖。

    5[N-UNCOUNT 不可數名詞](音樂、詩歌等的)創作，作曲 Composition is the act of composing something such as a piece of music or a poem.

    • These plays are arranged in their order of composition.

      這些劇作是按照其創作的先後順序安排的。

column5:
n.化合物；復合詞；複合物
n.院子(用圍牆圈起來的場地）
adj.化合的；【語】（詞語等）復合的；【植】復合的；【動】群體的
vt.混合；調合；使嚴重；私了；【經】以復利計算
vi.妥協
column6:
(1) Water is a compound of hydrogen and oxygen.
(2) 'Bus conductor', 'dark-haired' and 'policeman' are compounds.
(3) Medicines are usually compounds.
(4) All prisoners were frog-marched (out) into the compound.
(5) "Fingerprint" is a compound word.
(6) Rose is a plant with compound leaves.
(7) He compounded various ingredients into an effective drug.
(8) I ran out of petrol and then, to compound the felony, I found that I'd got a flat tyre.
(9) My bank compounds interests semiannually.
(10) He compounded with his creditors for a remission of what he owed.
(11) He compounded with the house owner for the rent.
column7:
(1) 水是氫和氧的化合物。
(2) bus conductor,dark-haired和policeman都是復合詞。
(3) 藥品通常是複合物。
(4) 犯人都被迫反剪雙臂(出來)進入院子。
(5) 「Fingerprint」（指紋）是一個復合詞。
(6) 玫瑰是復葉植物。
(7) 他將各種成分混合成一種有效的藥物。
(8) 我的汽油用完了，然而使事情更糟的是，我發現有一隻車胎爆破了。
(9) 我的銀行以半年為單位計算復利。
(10) 他和他的債權人談妥免除其債務。
(11) 他同房主就租金之事作了妥協。
column8: If you compound a problem you add something to it to make it worse, like say, putting water on a grease fire. Compound means to combine; a compound is a combination or mixture of two or more things.
column9: Compound has several specialized uses. A compound is either a mixture or two or more things, or a heavily guarded residence, such as a drug lord might have. In botany, a compound leaf consists of more than one part. In linguistics, a compound is a word that consists of two or more independent words. In chemistry, a compound is a substance created when atoms from chemical elements join together.
column11:
The noun is pronounced /'kɒmpaʊnd/. The verb is pronounced /kəm'paʊnd/. 名詞讀作 /'kɒmpaʊnd/，動詞讀作 /kəm'paʊnd/。
1[N-COUNT 可數名詞](作特殊用途的)大院，有圍牆的場地 A compound is an enclosed area of land that is used for a particular purpose.

  • Police fired on them as they fled into the embassy compound.

    當他們逃進使館大院時，警察向他們開了槍。

  • ...a military compound.

    軍營

2[N-COUNT 可數名詞](化學中的)化合物 In chemistry, a compound is a substance that consists of two or more elements.

  • Organic compounds contain carbon in their molecules.

    有機化合物的分子中含碳。

3[N-COUNT 可數名詞]混合物；組合物 If something is a compound of different things, it consists of those things.
  [usu sing]
  [FORMAL 正式]

  • Honey is basically a compound of water, two types of sugar, vitamins and enzymes.

    蜂蜜基本上是水、兩種糖、幾種維生素和酶的混合物。

4[ADJ 形容詞]復合的；組合的；混合的 Compound is used to indicate that something consists of two or more parts or things.
  [ADJ n]

  • ...a tall shrub with shiny compound leaves.

    長有油光閃亮的復葉的高株灌木

  • ...the compound microscope.

    複式顯微鏡

5[ADJ 形容詞](單詞)復合的 In grammar, a compound noun, adjective, or verb is one that is made up of two or more words, for example 'fire engine', 'bottle-green', and 'force-feed'.
  [ADJ n]
    6[ADJ 形容詞](句子)復合的 In grammar, a compound sentence is one that is made up of two or more main clauses.
      [ADJ n]
      7[VERB 動詞]使惡化；使複雜化；加重 To compound a problem, difficulty, or mistake means to make it worse by adding to it.
        [V n]
        [FORMAL 正式]

      • Additional bloodshed and loss of life will only compound the tragedy...

        額外的流血和犧牲只會加重這場悲劇。

      • The problem is compounded by the medical system here.

        這兒的醫療體制使問題進一步惡化。

column5: vt.充分理解；領悟；包括
column6:
(1) I cannot comprehend this phrase.
(2) If you can use a word correctly and effectively you comprehend it.
(3) The child couldn't comprehend the text.
(4) The park comprehends all the land on the other side of the river.
column7:
(1) 我無法理解這個片語。
(2) 你如果可以正確有效地使用一個詞，你就是瞭解它了。
(3) 這孩子不懂該課文的含義。
(4) 這個公園包括河對岸的所有地方。
column8: To comprehend something is to understand it, like when you have to read a difficult passage more than once in order to comprehend it.
column9: When you comprehend something, you grasp its meaning. Comprehend is a verb that originates from the Latin word comprehendere, which means 「catch or seize.」 When an idea is clear to you and you understand it completely, you comprehend it, like doing extra problems to make sure you comprehend a difficult algebra rule, or finding it hard to comprehend why someone would paint his house neon yellow.
column11:
1[VERB 動詞]理解；領悟 If you cannot comprehend something, you cannot understand it.
  [V n]
  [V]
  [with brd-neg]
  [FORMAL 正式]

  • I just cannot comprehend your attitude...

    我就是無法理解你的態度。

  • Whenever she failed to comprehend she invariably laughed.

    每當她聽不懂的時候，她總是會笑。

column5: adj.全面的；廣泛的；綜合的；理解的
column6:
(1) The reporter has made a comprehensive report.
(2) She has a comprehensive grasp of the subject.
(3) Applying the most comprehensive metal is iron.
(4) We have a rather comprehensive subway system here.
(5) He was educated at the local comprehensive school.
(6) This book should be adapted to the comprehensive ability of the freshmen.
column7:
(1) 記者已做了全面的報道。
(2) 她已全面掌握了這一學科。
(3) 應用最廣泛的金屬是鐵。
(4) 我們這兒有相當廣泛的地鐵系統。
(5) 他曾在地區的綜合中學受教育。
(6) 應該將本書改寫一下,以便適合新生的理解能力。
column8: When you want to describe something that includes all or most details, you can use the adjective comprehensive. If you get the comprehensive treatment at a spa, it might include massage, manicure and a facial.
column9: Comprehensive is from Latin comprehensivus, from comprehensus, the source of English comprehend. In business, comprehensive insurance is insurance that covers a broad range, offering protection against most risks of a certain type. It applies mainly to car insurance.
column11:
1[ADJ-GRADED 能被表示程度的副詞或介詞詞組修飾的形容詞]綜合性的；全面的 Something that is comprehensive includes everything that is needed or relevant.

  • The Rough Guide to Nepal is a comprehensive guide to the region.

    《尼泊爾概況》是一本全面介紹該地區的旅遊指南。

2[N-COUNT； N-IN-NAMES 名稱名詞；名稱名詞](英國的公立性)綜合中學 In Britain, a comprehensive is a state school in which children of all abilities are taught together.
  [ADJ n]

  • ...Birmingham's inner-city comprehensives...

    伯明翰舊城區的綜合中學

  • She taught French at Cheam Comprehensive in South London.

    她在倫敦南部的奇姆綜合中學教法語。

  • Comprehensive is also an adjective.

    • He left comprehensive school at the age of 16.

      他16歲就從綜合中學畢業了。

    • ...Rushcliffe Comprehensive School.

      拉什克利夫綜合中學

column5: vt.構成；包含
column6:
(1) This month's figures are comprised in the total.
(2) Fifteen separate republics comprised the Soviet Union.
(3) Fifty states comprise the Union.
(4) The chapters that comprise the first part of the novel are especially good.
(5) A cricket team is comprised of eleven players.
(6) The company will comprise the flash memory units of Intel and STMicro.
column7:
(1) 這個月的數字已包含在總數之內。
(2) 蘇聯由十五個加盟共和國組成。
(3) 五十個州組成美國。
(4) 構成那部小說開頭部分的幾章特別好。
(5) 一個板球隊由11名隊員組成。
(6) 新公司由英特爾和意法半導體的閃存部門組成。
column8: When something comprises other things, it is made up of them or formed from them. The periodic table comprises 118 elements, because the whole comprises the parts.
column9: In its traditional use, the word comprise is the opposite of compose: if A comprises X, Y, and Z, then X, Y, and Z compose A. But because compose and comprise sound so much alike, people have long confused the two. So now you often hear things like "The band is comprised of a guitarist, a bassist, and a hairy drummer," whereas sticklers would prefer "is composed of" in that sentence. The word is undergoing a usage shift, making it just as hairy as that drummer!
column11:
1[VERB 動詞]包括；由…組成 If you say that something comprises or is comprised of a number of things or people, you mean it has them as its parts or members.
  [V n]
  [be V-ed of n]
  [V-ed]
  [FORMAL 正式]

  • The special cabinet committee comprises Mr Brown, Mr Mandelson, and Mr Straw...

    特別內閣委員會包括布朗先生、曼德爾森先生和斯特勞先生。

  • The exhibition comprises 50 oils and watercolours...

    展覽陳列了50幅油畫和水彩畫。

  • The task force is comprised of congressional leaders, cabinet heads and administration officials...

    工作小組由國會領導人、內閣首腦和行政官員組成。

  • A crowd comprised of the wives and children of scientists staged a demonstration.

    由科學家們的妻兒們組成的隊伍舉行了示威遊行。

2[VERB 動詞]構成；組成 The things or people that comprise something are the parts or members that form it.
  [V n]
  [FORMAL 正式]

  • ...the multitude of ideas, ambitions and regrets that comprises the culture of Russia today...

    構成現今俄羅斯文化的眾多觀點、抱負和遺憾

  • Women comprise 44% of hospital medical staff.

    女性占醫院醫護人員的44%。

column5:
n.妥協；折衷；折衷案；和解
vt.妥協處理；危害
vi.妥協，和解；讓步
column6:
(1) He did it without compromise of his dignity.
(2) The agreement is a compromise, not a sell-out.
(3) After some discussion we arrive at a compromise.
(4) Or are we ready to compromise our faith?
(5) Build the disorder that does not have the market to compromise project quality forthrightly.
(6) They found it wiser to compromise with her.
(7) The agreement is a compromise, not a sell-out.
(8) The agreement is a compromise, not a sell-out.
(9) I think we'd better reach a compromise.
column7:
(1) 他做這事而不損及他的尊嚴。
(2) 這個協議是雙方妥協的產物而不是一方讓步。
(3) 經過一番討論之後，我們達成一項折衷方案。
(4) 或者，我們準備好了在信仰上折衷嗎？
(5) 建沒市場的混亂直接地危害工程質量。
(6) 他們覺得與她妥協更明智。
(7) 這個協議是雙方妥協的產物而不是一方讓步。
(8) 這個協議是雙方妥協的產物而不是一方讓步。
(9) 我認為我們最好相互讓步。
column8: A compromise is a way of settling differences by everybody making concessions. If you want to stay out until 10 and your friend wants to stay out until midnight, 11 is a good compromise.
column9: Compromise comes from the Latin compromissum, which means "mutual promise." It can be a noun or a verb. If you compromise with your lab partner over how to analyze the experimental data, you find the middle ground between your two ideas. Compromise can also mean to erode or diminish. If you never repair your brakes, you will compromise the safety of the car. If you cheat, you compromise your integrity.
column11:
1[N-VAR 可變名詞]折中；妥協；讓步 A compromise is a situation in which people accept something slightly different from what they really want, because of circumstances or because they are considering the wishes of other people.

  • Encourage your child to reach a compromise between what he wants and what you want...

    鼓勵孩子在他的願望和你的願望之間找到一個折中點。

  • Be ready and willing to make compromises between your needs and those of your partner...

    時刻準備好並樂意在自己與伴侶的需求之間作出讓步。

  • The government's policy of compromise is not universally popular.

    政府的妥協政策並沒有受到普遍歡迎。

2[V-RECIP 相互動詞]妥協；作出讓步 If you compromise with someone, you reach an agreement with them in which you both give up something that you originally wanted. You can also say that two people or groups compromise .
  [V with n over n]
  [pl-n V on n]
  [V on n (non-recip)]
  [Also pl-n V]

  • The government has compromised with its critics over monetary policies...

    政府已經就貨幣政策向批評人士作出讓步。

  • 'Nine,' said I. 'Nine thirty,' tried he. We compromised on 9.15...

    「9點。」我說。「9點半。」他試著說。於是我們各讓一步，定在了9點一刻。

  • Israel had originally wanted $1 billion in aid, but compromised on the $650 million.

    以色列原本想要獲得10億美元的援助，但後來作出讓步，同意接受6.5億的援助。

3[VERB 動詞]使（自己）聲譽受損；違背(信念) If someone compromises themselves or compromises their beliefs, they do something which damages their reputation for honesty, loyalty, or high moral principles.
  [V pron-refl]
  [V n]
  [disapproval]

  • ...members of the government who have compromised themselves by co-operating with the emergency committee...

    因與緊急委員會合作而使自己名譽受損的政府成員

  • He would rather shoot himself than compromise his principles.

    他寧願一槍打死自己也不願違背自己的原則。

column5: adj.強制的；勢在必行的；義務的
column6:
(1) Attendance at evening prayers is not compulsory.
(2) I think it is compulsory.
(3) The car insurance is compulsory.
(4) I think it is compulsory to look over the house.
(5) Building model stars is a compulsory task.
(6) Is English a compulsory subject?
(7) Is military service compulsory in your country?
column7:
(1) 參加晚禱並非硬性規定。
(2) 我認為這是非做不可的。
(3) 這項汽車保險是強制性的。
(4) 我認為檢查這棟房子勢在必行。
(5) 建立恆星模型是一項勢在必行的任務。
(6) 英語是必修科目嗎？
(7) 你們國家實行義務兵役制嗎？
column8: When something is compulsory, it is required or must be done. In most states, it's compulsory for kids to attend school (or an equivalent homeschool) from age six to seventeen.
column9: This adjective is from Medieval Latin compulsorius "using force," from Latin compulsus, from compellere "to force." The Latin suffix –orius corresponds to English -ory "containing or involving." Other English words descended from the same Latin verb are compel and compulsive.
column11:
1[ADJ 形容詞]強制性的；強迫的；義務的 If something is compulsory, you must do it or accept it, because it is the law or because someone in a position of authority says you must.

  • In East Germany learning Russian was compulsory...

    在東德，俄語是必修課。

  • Many young men are trying to get away from compulsory military conscription.

    很多年輕人試圖逃避強制徵兵的政策。

compulsorily

  • Five of the company's senior managers have been made compulsorily redundant.

    公司的高級經理中有5位已經被強制性地裁掉。

column5: vt.隱藏；隱瞞；掩蓋
column6:
(1) He concealed himself behind the tree.
(2) It is against law to conceal evidence.
(3) It is wrong for a man to conceal things from his wife.
(4) She tried to conceal what she had done to them.
(5) He could hardly conceal his joy at his departure.
column7:
(1) 他藏在樹後。
(2) 隱藏證據是違法的。
(3) 一個男人對妻子隱瞞事情是不對的。
(4) 她試圖隱瞞對他們所做的事。
(5) 他幾乎掩飾不住臨行時的喜悅。
column8: When you conceal something, you are keeping it from being discovered: 「To avoid another argument with his cousins, Jonathan worked hard to conceal his disappointment at the outcome of the race.」
column9: The verb conceal can be used to describe the hiding of feelings (as in 「to conceal anger」) or facts (as in 「to conceal identity」). Conceal also can be used to describe the act of hiding or covering an item to prevent discovery. If you eat the last piece of chocolate cake, for example, you may want to conceal the evidence by removing the icing-stained plate from your room.
column11:
1[VERB 動詞]掩蓋；隱藏 If you conceal something, you cover it or hide it carefully.
  [V n]
  [V-ed]

  • Frances decided to conceal the machine behind a hinged panel...

    弗朗西斯決定把機器藏在帶鉸鏈的嵌板的後面。

  • Five people were arrested for carrying concealed weapons.

    5人因身上藏有武器被捕。

2[VERB 動詞]隱瞞（信息)；掩飾(感情) If you conceal a piece of information or a feeling, you do not let other people know about it.
  [V n]
  [V n from n]

  • Robert could not conceal his relief...

    羅伯特無法掩飾自己如釋重負的心情。

  • She knew at once that he was concealing something from her.

    她馬上知道了他有事瞞著她。

3[VERB 動詞]掩蓋；遮住 If something conceals something else, it covers it and prevents it from being seen.
  [V n]

  • ...a pair of carved Indian doors which conceal a built-in cupboard...

    嵌入式壁櫥上的一對印度雕花門

  • The hat concealed her hair.

    帽子遮住了她的頭髮。

column5:
vt.承認；給予；讓步；認輸
vi.讓步
column6:
(1) I concede that you are right.
(2) You must concede that I have tried my best.
(3) The defeated side had to concede some of their territory to the enemy.
(4) You concede nothing to me and I have to concede everything to you.
(5) Mike had to concede when he confronted his parents
column7:
(1) 我承認你是對的。
(2) 你必須承認我已經盡力了。
(3) 戰敗的一方不得不把一部分領土割讓給了敵人。
(4) 你對我無論什麼都不肯讓步；我對你，可無論什麼都得讓步。
(5) 當面對他的父母,麥克不得不讓步。
column8: If you concede something, you admit that it is true, proper, or certain––usually in an unwilling way and often in the context of a competition, as in "At midnight, the candidate finally conceded defeat."
column9: In its most common senses, a near synonym of concede is acknowledge––if your mom is pointing out that you need sleep before the test, you should concede the truth of what she's saying. But another meaning of concede is to give away or grant something: The leaders are not ready to concede power. Concede is from Latin concēdere, from the prefix com- "completely" plus cēdere, "to go along, grant, yield." The corresponding noun is concession.
column11:
1[VERB 動詞](勉強)承認，承認…屬實 If you concede something, you admit, often unwillingly, that it is true or correct.
  [V that]
  [V with quote]
  [V n]
  [Also V n n]

  • Bess finally conceded that Nancy was right...

    貝絲最終承認了南希是對的。

  • 'Well,' he conceded, 'I do sometimes mumble a bit.'...

    「嗯，」他承認道，「我有時候說話的確有點吐字不清。」

  • Mr. Chapman conceded the need for Nomura's U.S. unit to improve its trading skills.

    查普曼先生承認野村證券美國分公司需要提高股票交易技巧。

2[VERB 動詞]賦予，授予(權利、特權) If you concede something to someone, you allow them to have it as a right or privilege.
  [V n]
  [V n to n]
  [Also V n n]

  • The government conceded the right to establish independent trade unions...

    政府承認建立獨立工會的權利。

  • Facing total defeat in Vietnam, the French subsequently conceded full independence to Laos.

    法國人在越南面臨徹底的失敗後，接著又讓老撾取得了完全的獨立。

3[VERB 動詞]讓給；讓與 If you concede something, you give it to the person who has been trying to get it from you.
  [V n]

  • A strike by some ten thousand bank employees has ended after the government conceded some of their demands.

    政府答應了他們的一些要求後，大約有一萬名銀行員工參加的罷工結束了。

4[VERB 動詞](在體育運動中)未能阻止(對方進球或得分) In sport, if you concede goals or points, you are unable to prevent your opponent from scoring them.
  [V n to n]
  [V n]
  [BRIT 英]

  • They conceded four goals to Leeds United...

    他們被利茲聯隊攻進4個球。

  • Luton conceded a free kick on the edge of the penalty area.

    盧頓未能在罰球區的邊緣截住對方的任意球。

in AM, use 美國英語用 give up
5[VERB 動詞]認輸；承認失敗 If you concede a game, contest, or argument, you end it by admitting that you can no longer win.
  [V n to n]
  [V n]

  • Reiner, 56, has all but conceded the race to his rival...

    56歲的賴納在比賽中幾乎已經向對手認輸了。

  • Alain Prost finished third and virtually conceded the world championship.

    阿蘭·普羅斯特以第三名的成績結束比賽，實際上已經將世界冠軍的位置拱手讓人。

6[VERB 動詞]承認(失敗)；認(輸) If you concede defeat, you accept that you have lost a struggle.
  [V n]

  • Airtours conceded defeat in its attempt to take control of holiday industry rival Owners Abroad...

    空中旅遊公司承認其對度假服務行業競爭對手海外業主旅行社的控股企圖以失敗告終。

  • He happily conceded the election.

    他欣然接受了選舉的失敗。

column5: n.自負；個人觀點；幻想；字字珠璣；好評
column6:
(1) This young man is full of conceit.
(2) He jotted down his conceits of his idle hours.
(3) I don't have much conceit of his poems.
column7:
(1) 這個年輕人非常自負。
(2) 他記下閒暇時自己想到的一些念頭。
(3) 我對他的詩作沒有什麼好評。
column8: If you』re always boasting and can』t stop talking about yourself, you have that character flaw known as conceit. Your friends — if you have any — may also complain about your arrogance, vanity, and egotism.
column9: A conceit can also be an artistic device — probably a little forced — like the plot of a movie built on the conceit of everything that happens being foretold in song. You might find an architectural conceit in a Baroque palace, where you think you』re looking down a long hallway lined with columns, but when you get closer you see that it's really a mural painted in perspective so that the columns only seem to disappear in the distance.
column11:
1[N-UNCOUNT 不可數名詞]自負；自高自大 Conceit is very great pride in your abilities or achievements that other people feel is too great.
  [also a N]
  [disapproval]

  • He knew, without conceit, he was considered a genius...

    不是他自命不凡，他知道大家認為他是個天才。

  • Pamela knew she was a good student, and that was not just a conceit.

    帕梅拉知道自己是個好學生，而這絕不僅僅是自負。

2[N-COUNT 可數名詞](文學中)巧妙的比喻，別出心裁的對比 In literature, a conceit is a clever or unusual metaphor or comparison.

  • Critics may complain that the novel's central conceit is rather simplistic.

    批評家們可能會認為小說的核心比喻過於簡單。

column5: v.設想；想出；懷孕
column6:
(1) I cannot conceive of him as a genius.
(2) I cannot conceive that he would wish to harm us.
(3) I can not conceive of anything funnier than that .
(4) She was told she couldn't conceive.
(5) The child was conceived on the night of their wedding.
column7:
(1) 我不能設想他會是一個天才。
(2) 我不能想像他會傷害我們。
(3) 我想不出有比那更有趣的東西。
(4) 她得知自己不能懷孕。
(5) 那孩子是在他們新婚之夜懷上的。
column8: To conceive is to come up with an idea. If you conceive a plan for your little brother's birthday, you dream up the perfect party, complete with a magician, rented ponies, and a cake shaped like a rocket.
column9: Latin roots for conceive (by way of French) point to "take into" either "the womb" or "the mind." An idea is sometimes called "a seed" or "the seed of an idea," and conceive means to produce something from inside the mind — or to become pregnant. Another expression is "pregnant with ideas" or "pregnant with possibilities," and someone who can "conceive of a thousand ways" to solve a problem or design something is full of new ideas.
column11:
1[VERB 動詞]想像；相信 If you cannot conceive of something, you cannot imagine it or believe it.
  [V of n/-ing]
  [Also V that]
  [usu with brd-neg]

  • I just can't even conceive of that quantity of money...

    那麼多錢，我根本都無法想像。

  • He was immensely ambitious but unable to conceive of winning power for himself.

    他雄心勃勃，但是想不出自己能如何贏得權力。

2[VERB 動詞]認為 If you conceive something as a particular thing, you consider it to be that thing.
  [V n as n/-ing]
  [V of n as n/-ing]

  • The ancients conceived the earth as afloat in water...

    古人認為地球飄浮在水裡。

  • We conceive of the family as being in a constant state of change...

    我們認為家庭處於不斷變化之中。

  • Elvis conceived of himself as a ballad singer.

    埃爾維斯認為自己是民謠歌手。

3[VERB 動詞]構思；設想；想出 If you conceive a plan or idea, you think of it and work out how it can be done.
  [V n]
  [V of n]

  • She had conceived the idea of a series of novels...

    她萌生出撰寫系列小說的想法。

  • He conceived of the first truly portable computer in 1968.

    1968年，他構想出第一台真正的便攜式計算機。

4[VERB 動詞]懷孕 When a woman conceives, she becomes pregnant.
  [V]
  [V n]

  • Women, he says, should give up alcohol before they plan to conceive...

    他說女性在計劃懷孕之前應該戒酒。

  • About one in six couples has difficulty conceiving...

    大約1/6的夫妻有受孕困難。

  • A mother who already has non-identical twins is more likely to conceive another set of twins.

    生育過非同卵雙胞胎的母親再懷上雙胞胎的可能性更大。

column5:
adj.全神貫注的；濃縮的；密集的
動詞concentrate的過去式和過去分詞.
column6:
(1) He made a concentrated effort to improve his work.
(2) She diluted the concentrated fruit juice with water.
(3) The presidential palace has been hit again by concentrated artillery fire.
column7:
(1) 他全神貫注地努力改進自己的工作。
(2) 她攙水沖淡濃縮水果汁。
(3) 總統府又遭到密集炮火的攻擊。
column8: Things that are concentrated have been gathered together in the smallest possible bunch. If you use a concentrated cleaning product, you might need to mix it with water before using it.
column9: Concentrated often refers to a liquid solution that's very strong, but it can describe anything that's condensed into one area. When you finally clean your bedroom, you』ll have to pick up the clothes that are scattered everywhere so they』re concentrated in the closet. Concentrated can also mean that something is very focused. When your room looks great, it's because you really concentrated on the cleaning.
column11:
1[ADJ-GRADED 能被表示程度的副詞或介詞詞組修飾的形容詞]濃縮的 A concentrated liquid has been increased in strength by having water removed from it.

  • Sweeten dishes sparingly with honey, or concentrated apple or pear juice.

    加一點蜂蜜或濃縮蘋果汁或梨汁，讓菜帶點甜味。

2[ADJ-GRADED 能被表示程度的副詞或介詞詞組修飾的形容詞]（活動）集中的，密集的 A concentrated activity is directed with great intensity in one place.
  [usu ADJ n]

  • ...a more concentrated effort to reach out to troubled kids.

    把精力更多地集中在與問題兒童的溝通上

column5:
n.音樂會；一致；和諧
vt.協定；協同安排
vi.合作
column6:
(1) The concert will be given on Saturday.
(2) It is good to go to a concert for a change.
(3) The newspaper gave much publicity to the concert.
(4) They did not act in concert with one another.
(5) Then powerful and the powerless try to live in concert.
(6) We will get together to concert our differences.
(7) He refused to concert with his partners.
column7:
(1) 音樂會將於星期六舉行。
(2) 到音樂會去換換環境比較好。
(3) 報紙對這次音樂會進行了充分報道。
(4) 他們的行動互不協調。
(5) 有權者和無權者和諧一致。
(6) 我們將聚集一起協調分歧。
(7) 他拒絕和他的夥伴們合作。
column8: A concert is a performance by musicians or singers for an audience. If you're in the glee club, you know about singing in concerts, and maybe you've seen your favorite bands in concert, too.
column9: A concert usually doesn't involve theatrical staging. You can have a concert version of an opera, but that means the singers stand there and sing without sets or props, and without much acting or moving around. Less commonly, concert is a verb (accent on the second syllable), meaning to agree with others on something. That meaning shows up in the phrase in concert — your objections will carry more weight if you act in concert with your neighbors.
column11:
1[N-COUNT 可數名詞]音樂會 A concert is a performance of music.

  • ...a short concert of piano music...

    一場短暫的鋼琴音樂會

  • I've been to plenty of live rock concerts.

    我去現場看過很多搖滾音樂會。

  • ...a new concert hall.

    新的音樂廳

2[PHRASE 短語]現場演出 If a musician or group of musicians appears in concert, they are giving a live performance.
  [PHR after v]

  • I want people to remember Elvis in concert.

    我希望大家記住現場演唱會上的貓王。

3[PHRASE 短語]合作；同心協力 If a number of people do something in concert, they do it together.
  [PHR after v]
  [FORMAL 正式]

  • He wants to act in concert with other nations.

    他想和其他國家採取一致行動。

column5: vt. (1) 使平息怒氣; 安撫, 安慰 (2) 充當調停人; 調和, 調解: (3) 〈正式〉使和解, 使和好
column6:
(1)concessions were made to conciliate the peasantry.
(2)he sought to conciliate in the dispute.
(3) all complaints about charges will be conciliated if possible.
column7:
(1) 作出讓步以安撫農民
(2) 他試圖調解此爭端
(3) 有可能的話, 所有關於收費的投訴都會得到解決

column5: adj.簡明的；簡要的
column6:
(1) His article is concise and comprehensive.
(2) I gave a concise answer to this.
(3) He gave a concise and firm summary of our position.
column7:
(1) 他的文章言簡意賅。
(2) 我對於此事給了一個簡要的答覆。
(3) 他扼要而堅定地闡述了我方的立場。
column8: If something is concise, it's short and gets right to the point. A concise edition of your diary might be 50 pages of the most important entries.
column9: Concise comes from the Latin word concidere, which means to cut down. When we use concise, we're talking about words that have been cut down. There are no concise trees, but there are concise works of political philosophy. A concise Italian-English dictionary, is shorter than an unabridged one. If you're good at quick explanations, you have a concise manner. A good synonym is succinct.
column11:
1[ADJ-GRADED 能被表示程度的副詞或介詞詞組修飾的形容詞]簡潔的；簡明的 Something that is concise says everything that is necessary without using any unnecessary words.

  • Burton's text is concise and informative...

    伯頓的文章語言簡潔，信息豐富。

  • Whatever you are writing make sure you are clear, concise, and accurate.

    無論寫什麼，一定要清晰、簡練、準確。

concisely

  • He'd delivered his report clearly and concisely.

    他清楚、簡要地作了匯報。

2[ADJ 形容詞](尤指詞典)簡明的，簡縮的 A concise edition of a book, especially a dictionary, is shorter than the original edition.
  [ADJ n]

  • ...Sotheby's Concise Encyclopedia of Porcelain.

    《蘇富比簡明瓷器百科全書》

column5: v.捏造；調製
column6:
(1) And they had taken me so long to concoct.
(2) She'd concocted some unlikely tale about the train being cancelled.
(3) I gave her a tip on how to concoct a new kind of soup.
column7:
(1) 我花了好長時間編造這些謊言。
(2) 她胡編了一通瞎話,說什麼那班火車給取消了。
(3) 我教她配製一種新湯的訣竅。
column8: When you concoct something, you mix up different ingredients. If you want to become a mad scientist or a wizard, you'll have to learn how to concoct strange potions.
column9: If the word concoction makes you think of steaming caldrons or liquids bubbling in test tubes, you』ll be amused to know that it comes from a Latin word for 「digestion.」 Yum! On summer days, children sometimes concoct imaginative stews from grass, leaves and dirt. They may also concoct lies to explain why they tried feeding such concoctions to their little sister.
column11:
1[VERB 動詞]編造；捏造 If you concoct an excuse or explanation, you invent one that is not true.
  [V n]

  • Mr Ferguson said the prisoner concocted the story to get a lighter sentence.

    弗格森先生說犯人捏造了這件事兒以求輕判。

2[VERB 動詞]調製，調配(尤指不尋常之物) If you concoct something, especially something unusual, you make it by mixing several things together.
  [V n]
  [V-ed]

  • Eugene was concocting Rossini Cocktails from champagne and pureed raspberries.

    尤金當時正在用香檳和覆盆子醬調配羅西尼雞尾酒。

  • ...a specially concocted massage oil.

    特製按摩精油

column5:
adj.具體的；實質性的；混凝土的
n.水泥；混凝土；具體物
v.凝結；結合
column6:
(1) He had nothing concrete to fasten it upon.
(2) The statue rests on a bed of concrete.
(3) Between these are fixed precast concrete external cladding panels.
(4) Tom tumbled over and hit his head on the concrete.
(5) They have had the tunnel shored up with concrete.
(6) The house is made of stone, not concrete.
(7) The road was paved with concrete.
(8) Beauty is not concrete but a door is.
(9) The government concreted the road over.
(10) Slabs are concreted complete with ducts and openings framed with metal aprons welded to slab reinforcement and intended to accommodate columns.
(11) It is easier to think in concrete terms rather than in the abstract.
(12) The combination of the spinning wire and constant pulling force cuts a path through the concrete and steel reinforcement.
column7:
(1) 他抓不到什麼具體的證據。
(2) 這座雕像立在混凝土的基座上。
(3) 在它們之間填上預制混凝土的外層空心板。
(4) 湯姆摔倒，頭撞到水泥地。
(5) 他們已經叫人用水泥把坑道加固。
(6) 那房子是石造的，不是混凝土造的。
(7) 路面由混凝土鋪成。
(8) 美麗不是具體物，但門是。
(9) 政府用混凝土鋪路。
(10) 樓板用混凝土澆注成整體，其上留有用金屬擋板圍成的孔道和提升環，它們和樓板配筋焊接在一起，以備將柱子套入其中。
(11) 結合具體的事物來思考要比抽像思考容易些。
(12) 結合紡紗線和不斷削減一條拉力鋼筋混凝土和通過。
column8: Concrete is that pourable mix of cement, water, sand, and gravel that hardens into a super-strong building material. Sidewalks, foundations, and highways are all made of concrete.
column9: Though people use the words cement and concrete as if they were the same, they're not. Concrete has cement in it, but also includes other materials; cement is what binds concrete together. Construction workers hate when kids write their names in concrete before it hardens: once concrete hardens, it's going to be solid for a long time. When used as an adjective, concrete also means solid. If you've got concrete plans for Saturday, then you have a definite plan.
column11:
1[N-UNCOUNT 不可數名詞]混凝土 Concrete is a substance used for building which is made by mixing together cement, sand, small stones, and water.
  [oft N n]

  • The posts have to be set in concrete...

    這些柱子必須用混凝土固定。

  • They had lain on sleeping bags on the concrete floor.

    他們就躺在鋪在混凝土地面上的睡袋上。

  • ...concrete barriers.

    混凝土壁壘

2[VERB 動詞]用混凝土澆築(或覆蓋) When you concrete something such as a path, you cover it with concrete.
  [V n]

  • He merely cleared and concreted the floors.

    他只是把地面清理之後澆上了混凝土。

3[ADJ-GRADED 能被表示程度的副詞或介詞詞組修飾的形容詞]具體的；確實的 You use concrete to indicate that something is definite and specific.
  [usu ADJ n]

  • He had no concrete evidence...

    他沒有確鑿的證據。

  • There were no concrete proposals on the table...

    沒有具體的提議可供討論。

  • I must have something to tell him. Something concrete.

    我必須告訴他點什麼，必須是具體的東西。

concretely

  • ...by way of making their point more concretely.

    通過更為具體地證明他們的觀點

4[ADJ 形容詞]實在的；有形的 A concrete object is a real, physical object.
  [usu ADJ n]

  • ...using concrete objects to teach addition and subtraction.

    用實物來教加減法

5[ADJ 形容詞](名詞)具體的 A concrete noun is a noun that refers to a physical object rather than to a quality or idea.
  [ADJ n]
    6[PHRASE 短語](計劃或觀點)固定的，不變的 If a plan or idea is set in concrete or embedded in concrete, it is fixed and cannot be changed.
      [v-link PHR]

    • As Mr Blunkett emphasised, nothing is yet set in concrete.

      正如布倫基特先生所強調的，一切都還沒有定下來。

column5: v.意見相同；同時發生
column6:
(1) I concur with him in many points.
(2) Did all the members concur in getting a bank loan?
(3) She has expressed her opposition to the plan, and I fully concur .
column7:
(1) 我和他在許多論點上意見是一致的。
(2) 委員們是否都同意向銀行貸款。
(3) 她對計劃表示反對
column8: To concur is to agree or approve of something. If someone says something you agree with, you can say "I concur!"
column9: Like many words with con, concur has to do with agreement and being together. When you concur, you agree with someone about something or let them know you approve. "I concur" is a formal (and sometimes humorous) way of saying "I agree!" or "I hear that!" Also, two events that happen at the same time can be said to concur. People are happy when good things concur, like when a birthday and nice weather happen at the same time.
column11:
1[V-RECIP 相互動詞]意見一致；同意 If one person concurs with another person, the two people agree. You can also say that two people concur .
  [V with n]
  [V in n]
  [pl-n V that]
  [pl-n V]
  [NON-RECIP: V that]
  [V with quote]
  [Also V]
  [FORMAL 正式]

  • Local feeling does not necessarily concur with the press...

    當地人的感受未必與媒體一致。

  • Daniels and Franklin concurred in an investigator's suggestion that the police be commended...

    丹尼爾斯和富蘭克林一致同意一位調查人員的建議，即警方應該受到讚揚。

  • Butler and Stone concur that the war threw people's lives into a moral relief...

    巴特勒和斯通一致認為這場戰爭使人們的生命得到了道義上的解脫。

  • Four other judges concurred...

    還有四位法官表示同意。

  • After looking at the jug, Faulkner concurred that it was late Roman, third or fourth century...

    看了這個罐子之後，福克納贊成罐子屬於羅馬帝國晚期的說法，即3或4世紀。

  • 'It's not an agreeable state of affairs,' concurs Heitham.

    「目前的事態並不令人滿意。」海瑟姆贊同道。

column5: adj.同時發生的
column6:
(1) You can't attend two concurrent events!
(2) The mass murderer was given three concurrent life sentences.
(3) He was imprisoned for two concurrent terms of 30 months and 18 months.
column7:
(1) 你不能同時參加兩項活動！
(2) 那個屠殺群眾的兇手被同時判處並執行三個無期徒刑。
(3) 他被判處30個月和18個月的監禁，合併執行。
column8: Concurrent means happening at the same time, as in two movies showing at the same theater on the same weekend.
column9: You might notice another adjective, current, in concurrent. While current refers to something that is happening right now, concurrent describes two or more things happening at the same time. A prisoner who is serving two concurrent five-year sentences will serve those prison terms together, meaning that he'll probably get out of jail in five years rather than ten. To help you remember the meaning of concurrent, imagine two parallel kayaks being carried down a river by the current at the same time.
column11:
1[ADJ 形容詞]同時發生的 Concurrent events or situations happen at the same time.
  [usu ADJ n]

  • Galerie St. Etienne is holding three concurrent exhibitions...

    聖艾蒂安美術館同時舉辦3場展覽。

  • He will actually be serving three concurrent five-year sentences...

    實際上，他將服3個5年徒刑，合併執行。

  • Concurrent with her acting career, Bron has managed to write two books of her own.

    在其演藝生涯中，布龍還設法寫了兩本自己的書。

concurrently

  • He was jailed for 33 months to run concurrently with a sentence he is already serving for burglary.

    他被判33個月的監禁，與他因入室盜竊已在服的刑期合併執行。

column5: vt. 擊打(人, 動物的)頭部以使暫時失去知覺或神志不清
column6:
(1) Michael was a bit concussed.
(2) He was badly concussed in the collision.
column7:
(1) 邁克爾被打得有點神志不清。
(2) 在猛烈碰撞時他的腦部受到嚴重損傷.

column5: vt.譴責；判刑
column6:
(1) We must not condemn her on pure supposition.
(2) We condemn all sorts of slanders.
(3) Most people are willing to condemn violence.
(4) The criminal was condemned to death.
column7:
(1) 我們不能單憑猜測就譴責她。
(2) 我們譴責一切誹謗中傷的言論。
(3) 大部分的人極力譴責暴力。
(4) 這個罪犯被判死刑。
column8: You can condemn, or openly criticize, someone who is behaving inappropriately. If you are an animal rights activist, you would probably condemn someone for wearing fur.
column9: Condemn originally comes, through Old French, from the Latin word condemnāre, "to sentence, condemn." You may see politicians condemn each other in political ads during a campaign in hopes of improving their chances of winning an election. You also might hear of a convict being "condemned to death." In this sense of the word, to condemn still carries on its Latin meaning of "to sentence."
column11:
1[VERB 動詞]譴責；指責 If you condemn something, you say that it is very bad and unacceptable.
  [V n]
  [V n for n]
  [V n as n]
  [Also V pron-refl]

  • Political leaders united yesterday to condemn the latest wave of violence...

    政界領袖昨日聯合起來對最近激增的暴力事件予以譴責。

  • Graham was right to condemn his players for lack of ability, attitude and application.

    格雷厄姆指責隊員們技藝不佳、態度不端正而且不夠努力，他說得沒錯。

  • ...a document that condemns sexism as a moral and social evil.

    把性別歧視視作道德和社會弊端予以譴責的文件

2[VERB 動詞]宣判；判處(某人刑罰) If someone is condemned to a punishment, they are given this punishment.
  [be V-ed to n]
  [V-ed]
  [usu passive]

  • He was condemned to life imprisonment.

    他被判終身監禁。

  • ...appeals by prisoners condemned to death.

    被判死刑的囚犯們提出的上訴

3[VERB 動詞]使陷入(不愉快的境地) If circumstances condemn you to an unpleasant situation, they make it certain that you will suffer in that way.
  [V n to n/-ing]
  [be V-ed to-inf]
  [Also V n to-inf]

  • Their lack of qualifications condemned them to a lifetime of boring, usually poorly-paid work...

    沒有學歷使他們一輩子都得從事枯燥乏味而且通常報酬很低的工作。

  • He felt condemned to being alone...

    他覺得自己注定要孤獨終老。

  • Mark was condemned to do most of the work.

    馬克被迫承擔大部分工作。

4[VERB 動詞]正式宣佈(建築)不安全 If authorities condemn a building, they officially decide that it is not safe and must be pulled down or repaired.
  [V n]

  • State officials said the court's ruling clears the way for proceedings to condemn buildings in the area.

    州政府官員稱法庭判決為宣佈該地區樓房為危房的行動掃清了道路。

5See also:condemned；

column5: v.濃縮；凝結；縮短
column6:
(1) He condense his speech to half its original length.
(2) Steam condenses into water when cooling down.
(3) Water vapors can condense to form clouds.
(4) The essay is too wordy, you'd better condense it.
column7:
(1) 他把演講的長度濃縮了一半。
(2) 蒸汽冷卻時凝結成水。
(3) 水蒸汽能凝結成雲。
(4) 這篇文章太過冗長, 要簡縮一下。
column8: When you condense something, you cut it down and trim it. You may love every word of your 1000-page novel, but you'll have to condense the plot into a 2-page summary for your editor.
column9: When you condense something, you make it smaller and more compact. If you condense your wardrobe, you get rid things and keep only what you wear most. When a gas or vapor turns to liquid, it condenses. When you take a long, hot shower, the steam condenses in your bathroom, your mirror clouds up, and everything gets damp. Condense comes from Latin con-, 「completely」 and densus, 「thick, dense."
column11:
1[VERB 動詞]壓縮，精簡(尤指文章或講話) If you condense something, especially a piece of writing or speech, you make it shorter, usually by including only the most important parts.
  [V n into n]
  [Also V n]

  • We have learnt how to condense serious messages into short, self-contained sentences...

    我們已經學會了如何把重要的信息壓縮成簡短獨立的句子。

  • The English translation may have been condensed into a single more readable book.

    英譯本可能被壓縮成了更具可讀性的單行本。
