2[V-ERG 及物/不及物動詞](使)冷凝；(使)凝結 When a gas or vapour condenses, or is condensed, it changes into a liquid.
  [V]
  [V into/out of n]
  [Also V n]

  • Water vapour condenses to form clouds...

    水蒸氣凝結形成雲。

  • The compressed gas is cooled and condenses into a liquid...

    壓縮氣體經冷卻凝結成液態。

  • As the air rises it becomes colder and moisture condenses out of it.

    隨著空氣上升，其溫度降低，凝結出水分。

column5: vi. (常作貶義)屈尊; 俯就
column6:
(1) She actually condescended to say hello to me in the street today.
(2) I do wish he wouldn't condescend to the junior staff in his department.
(3) (ironic) Perhaps your father would condescend to help with the washing-up!
column7:
(1) 她今天在街上竟能屈尊跟我打招呼.
(2) 我但願他不要假惺惺地紆尊降貴接近部門里的低級員工
(3) (反語)令尊大人或可紆尊降貴幫助刷鍋洗碗吧!

column5: n.安全套；避孕套
column11: 1[N-COUNT 可數名詞]安全套；避孕套 A condom is a covering made of thin rubber which a man can wear on his penis as a contraceptive or as protection against disease during sexual intercourse.

column5: vt.寬恕
column6:
(1) People cannot condone the use of fierce violence.
(2) No faith or culture should condone the outrages against them.
column7:
(1) 人們不能寬恕使用凶殘的暴力。
(2) 任何信仰或文化都不能寬恕對婦幼施加的暴行。
column8: If you condone something, you allow it, approve of it, or at least can live with it. Some teachers condone chewing gum, and some don't.
column9: Things that are condoned are allowed, even if everyone isn't exactly thrilled about it. People often say, "I don't condone what he did, but I understand it." Condoning is like excusing something. People seem to talk more about things they don't condone than things they do condone. Your mom might say, "I don't condone you staying up till 10, but I know you need to read." That's a way of giving approval and not giving approval at the same time.
column11:
1[VERB 動詞]容忍，縱容（不道德行為） If someone condones behaviour that is morally wrong, they accept it and allow it to happen.
  [V n]
  [oft with brd-neg]

  • I have never encouraged nor condoned violence...

    我從不煽動也不縱容暴力行為。

  • I couldn't condone what she was doing.

    我無法容忍她在做的事。

column5: adj.有助的；有益的
column6:
(1) Fresh air is conducive to health.
(2) The favourable political climate is conducive to economic investment.
(3) Regularity ought to be observed, as regularity is very conducive to health.
column7:
(1) 新鮮空氣有助於健康。
(2) 良好的政治氣候有利於經濟投資。
(3) 生活應遵守規律，因為規律對健康有益。
column8: Conducive means tending to cause or produce something. Regular exercise is conducive to happiness and a feeling of well-being.
column9: This adjective is usually followed by the preposition to, and it refers to bringing about something favorable or helpful: A positive attitude is conducive to good health. Conducive was formed in English from the less common verb conduce "to lead or contribute to a result." The verb conduce descends from Middle English conducen, from Latin conducere, from the prefix com- "together" plus ducere "to lead." And the suffix –ive means "tending to."
column11:
1[ADJ-GRADED 能被表示程度的副詞或介詞詞組修飾的形容詞]有助(於…)的；有益(於…)的 If one thing is conducive to another thing, it makes the other thing likely to happen.
  [usu v-link ADJ]

  • Make your bedroom as conducive to sleep as possible...

    盡量把臥室佈置得適宜睡眠。

  • Sometimes the home environment just isn't conducive to reading.

    有時候，家裡的環境確實不適合看書。

column5:
n.行為；舉動；品行
v.引導；指揮；管理
vt.導電；傳熱
column6:
(1) Your conduct is not consistent with what you say.
(2) His behavior transgressed the unwritten rules of social conduct.
(3) His conduct roused the suspicion of the police.
(4) He has good conduct.
(5) A man of irreproachable conduct commands the respect of others.
(6) The guide conducted us around the ruins of the ancient city.
(7) The visitors were conducted over the factory.
(8) Who is conducting the orchestra tonight?
(9) They hired agents to conduct their company.
(10) Most metals can conduct electricity.
(11) Most plastics do not readily conduct heat or electricity.
(12) Metal conducts heat better than wood.
(13) Copper is a good medium for conducting heat.
column7:
(1) 你的言行不一致。
(2) 他的行為違反了不成文的社交規範。
(3) 他的舉動引起了警察的懷疑。
(4) 他品行端正。
(5) 品行端正的人,受人尊敬。
(6) 導遊引導我們遊覽了古城廢墟。
(7) 參觀者被引導到工廠的各處去參觀。
(8) 誰指揮今晚的管絃樂隊呢?
(9) 他們僱請代理人來管理他們的公司。
(10) 大多數金屬能導電。
(11) 大多數塑料不易導電導熱。
(12) 金屬傳熱性能比木頭好。
(13) 銅是傳熱的良導體。
column8: Conduct is about how you behave––"conduct unbecoming"––and also about carrying something through––"the survey was conducted in May and June."
column9: Conduct's two senses are connected. Your conduct or your own behavior is the way you conduct or lead yourself. Think of your brain as a little man in tails and white tie, holding up a baton to conduct the various parts of you the way he would a symphony orchestra.
column11:
The verb is pronounced /kən'dʌkt/. The noun is pronounced /'kɒndʌkt/. 動詞讀作 /kən'dʌkt/，名詞讀作 /'kɒndʌkt/。
1[VERB 動詞]進行；組織；實施 When you conduct an activity or task, you organize it and carry it out.
  [V n]

  • I decided to conduct an experiment...

    我決定進行一次實驗。

  • He said they were conducting a campaign against democrats across the country...

    他說他們正在全國開展反對民主黨人的運動。

  • The council conducted a survey of the uses to which farm buildings are put.

    地方議會對農場建築的使用情況進行了一次調查。

2[N-SING 單數名詞](任務或活動的)組織方式，實施辦法 The conduct of a task or activity is the way in which it is organized and carried out.
  [with supp]

  • Also up for discussion will be the conduct of free and fair elections...

    同樣提出來進行討論的還有如何進行自由公正的選舉。

  • The Conservative Party did not in the main disagree with Bevin's conduct of foreign policy.

    保守黨大體上不反對貝文的外交施政方式。

3[VERB 動詞]表現；舉止 If you conduct yourself in a particular way, you behave in that way.
  [V pron-refl prep/adv]
  [V n]

  • The way he conducts himself reflects on the party and will increase criticisms against him...

    他個人的行事方式給該黨招來非議，也會招致更多對他個人的批評。

  • Most people believe they conduct their private and public lives in accordance with Christian morality.

    大多數人認為他們是依照基督教的道德體系來處理自己的私生活和公共事務的。

4[N-UNCOUNT 不可數名詞]行為；舉止 Someone's conduct is the way they behave in particular situations.
  [with supp]

  • For Europeans, the law is a statement of basic principles of civilised conduct...

    對於歐洲人來說，法律是對基本文明行為準則的表述。

  • He has trouble understanding that other people judge him by his conduct.

    別人通過他的行為舉止對他進行評判，這一點他很難理解。

5[VERB 動詞]指揮(管絃樂隊或合唱團) When someone conducts an orchestra or choir, they stand in front of it and direct its performance.
  [V n]
  [V]
  [V-ing]

  • Dennis had recently begun a successful career conducting opera in Europe...

    丹尼斯最近開始在歐洲擔任歌劇指揮，事業發展得很成功。

  • Solti will continue to conduct here and abroad...

    索爾蒂將繼續在國內外擔任指揮。

  • At the Curtis Institute he studied conducting with Fritz Reiner.

    在柯蒂斯學院，他師從弗裡茨·賴納學習指揮。

6[VERB 動詞]傳導(熱或電) If something conducts heat or electricity, it allows heat or electricity to pass through it or along it.
  [V n]
  [no cont]

  • Water conducts heat faster than air.

    水的導熱速度比空氣快。

7[VERB 動詞]陪伴；引導；帶領 If you conduct someone to a place, you go there with them.
  [V n]
  [FORMAL 正式]

  • He asked if he might conduct us to the ball which was to bring the proceedings to an end.

    他問是否可以帶我們去舞會現場，整個儀式將在那兒結束。

8See also:safe-conduct；

column5:
adj.導電（或熱等）的；能傳導（電、熱等）的
網絡:傳導的；導電的；傳導性的
column6:
(1) The factors which had influence on synthetic effect of conductive diamond were discussed.
(2) At least one conductive shield electrode is disposed in the gate trench.
(3) The slow delivery wire, please do not conductive A close mouth to see whether the wire out.
column7:
(1) 討論了影響導電金剛石合成效果的因素。
(2) 至少一個置於所述柵溝槽中的導電保護電極；
(3) 慢送絲時，請不要湊近導電嘴去查看焊絲是否送出。

column5: n.售票員；導體；指揮
column6:
(1) The conductor punched his bus ticket.
(2) She knows why the metal is the good conductor.
(3) Rubber is not a conductor, and neither is plastics.
(4) With his baton the conductor was beating time.
(5) Bernstein conducted Mahler like no other conductor.
column7:
(1) 售票員用剪票夾在他的汽車票上打孔。
(2) 她知道金屬為什麼是好的導體。
(3) 橡膠不是導體，塑料也不是導體。
(4) 指揮用指揮棒打著拍節。
(5) 伯恩斯坦指揮馬勒作品的方式與其他指揮家都不同。
column8: A train conductor is the person who takes tickets, shouts "All aboard!" and might control the engine, while a musical conductor is the one who leads an orchestra. Same job title — not the same person.
column9: From the Latin root conducere, meaning "bring together," a conductor does just that. A music conductor makes sure all the musicians come in at the right time and tempo, and a train conductor brings together all of the passengers. Another type of conductor is something that passes on electricity or heat, like a metal spoon, a conductor of heat when left in a pot that's simmering on the stove.
column11:
1[N-COUNT 可數名詞](管絃樂隊或合唱團的)指揮 A conductor is a person who stands in front of an orchestra or choir and directs its performance.
    2[N-COUNT 可數名詞]公交車售票員 On a bus, the conductor is the person whose job is to sell tickets to the passengers.
      3[N-COUNT 可數名詞]列車員 On a train, a conductor is a person whose job is to travel on the train in order to help passengers and check tickets.
        [AM 美]
        in BRIT, use 英國英語用 guard
        4[N-COUNT 可數名詞]See also:lightning conductor；semiconductor；導體 A conductor is a substance that heat or electricity can pass through or along.

column5:
n.圓錐體；錐形物；球果
vt.變成錐形
column6:
(1) Saw-dust has piled up in a great cone.
(2) The little boy likes to eat the ice-cream cone.
(3) The staminate cone of pine is male rather than female.
(4) They coned off a section of motorway during repairs.
column7:
(1) 鋸屑堆積如山。
(2) 小男孩喜歡吃冰淇淋蛋卷。
(3) 松樹雄球果是雄性而非雌性。
(4) 他們用錐形標誌隔開維修中的一段高速公路。
column8: A cone is a shape that has a circle at the bottom and sides that narrow to a point, like a party hat, a rubber pylon at a construction site, or, yes, an ice cream cone.
column9: Why is a cone called a cone? The Latin word conus means "the peak of a helmet," which must have described the shape of this type of hat in the 16th century. The Greek konos means "spinning top" and "pine cone." Both of these objects have one wider end that tapers to a point, describing a cone very accurately.
column11:
1[N-COUNT 可數名詞]圓錐體 A cone is a shape with a circular base and smooth curved sides ending in a point at the top.
    2[N-COUNT 可數名詞](松樹、冷杉樹等的)球果 A cone is the fruit of a tree such as a pine or fir.

    • ...a bowl of fir cones.

      一碗冷杉樹球果

    3[N-COUNT 可數名詞]冰激凌蛋卷筒；蛋筒冰激凌 A cone is a thin, cone-shaped biscuit that is used for holding ice cream. You can also refer to an ice cream that you eat in this way as a cone .

    • She stopped by the ice-cream shop and had a chocolate cone.

      她順便去了趟冰激凌店，買了一個巧克力蛋筒冰激凌。

    4See also:pine cone；traffic cone；

column5: v.商討；授予，賜予
column6:
(1) I must confer with my lawyer before I decide.
(2) I will confer with him on the subject.
(3) The Queen conferred knighthood on several distinguished men.
(4) The university confers master degree on her.
column7:
(1) 我必須先同我的律師商量一下才能做出決定。
(2) 我將和他商議這件事。
(3) 女王將爵士頭銜授予幾位傑出人士。
(4) 學校授予她碩士學位。
column8: If you gab, chat, and talk it up with someone, you have conversation, but if you're looking for input from each other as you talk, you confer, or consult, together. They had a family meeting to confer about a schedule for sharing the new laptop.
column9: Many uses of the verb confer involve consulting with another person or as a group. Confer has a second use meaning "bestow," which means to award or hand over something. You can confer a medal on a winner or hero, or you can confer status through a promotion or assignment. Each year the teacher would confer the special honor of summer hamster-sitter on one responsible student.
column11:
1[V-RECIP 相互動詞]商談；商議；交換意見 When you confer with someone, you discuss something with them in order to make a decision. You can also say that two people confer .
  [V with n]
  [pl-n V]

  • He conferred with Hill and the others in his office...

    他與希爾及其他人在辦公室裡商議了一番。

  • His doctors conferred by telephone and agreed that he must get away from his family for a time.

    診治他的幾位醫生在電話裡討論了一番，一致認為他必須離開家人一段時間。

2[VERB 動詞]授予，賦予(權力、榮譽等) To confer something such as power or an honour on someone means to give it to them.
  [V n on n]
  [V n]
  [FORMAL 正式]

  • The constitution also confers large powers on Brazil's 25 constituent states...

    憲法還賦予巴西的25個成員州很大的權力。

  • An honorary doctorate of law was conferred on him by Newcastle University in 1976...

    1976年，紐卡斯爾大學授予他榮譽法學博士學位。

  • Never imagine that rank confers genuine authority.

    絕對不要幻想那個頭銜會有實權。

column5: n.會議；討論會；協商會；會談
column6:
(1) An international conference will be held in Beijing next month.
(2) There will be a banquet following the conference.
(3) We are all fully confident that the conference will be a great success.
(4) Peace was the dominant theme of the conference.
column7:
(1) 一個國際性的會議下月將在北京舉行。
(2) 會議過後將有一個宴會。
(3) 我們都有充分的信心,這次會議將會非常成功。
(4) 和平是大會的首要議題。
column8: A conference is a formal get-together where people talk (or "confer") about a chosen topic, like when your office holds a conference to talk about the problem of snoring during meetings.
column9: A conference can also be a public meeting arranged for discussion, such as a press conference or a national conference for a particular group. For example, you may no longer have much interest in 18th-century coins, but you still attend the annual conference for coin collectors because it is always held at a hotel in Aruba. A conference can also refer to a sports league, such as for baseball or football.
column11:
1[N-COUNT 可數名詞](常持續數天的)專題討論會，研討會 A conference is a meeting, often lasting a few days, which is organized on a particular subject or to bring together people who have a common interest.

  • The President summoned all the state governors to a conference on education.

    總統召集各州州長召開了一次教育研討會。

  • ...the Conservative Party conference...

    保守黨大會

  • Last weekend the Roman Catholic Church in Scotland held a conference, attended by 450 delegates.

    上週末，蘇格蘭的天主教會舉行了一次會議，450名代表與會。

2[N-COUNT 可數名詞]會議；正式商談 A conference is a meeting at which formal discussions take place.
  [also in N]

  • They sat down at the dinner table, as they always did, before the meal, for a conference...

    他們在餐桌旁坐下，和平常一樣，吃飯之前要開個會。

  • Her employer was in conference with two lawyers and did not want to be interrupted.

    她的老闆在和兩位律師談事情，不想有人打擾。

3See also:press conference；

column5: v.承認；供認；告解；聽取懺悔
column6:
(1) I confess you are right on one point.
(2) Now, I must confess that I'm at my wit's end.
(3) He confessed that he had never seen her before.
(4) He refused to confess to his crime.
(5) This elderly Italian guy goes to his parish priest to confess.
(6) Many Christians regularly confess to a priest.
(7) The priest confessed the young man.
column7:
(1) 我承認你在某一點上是正確的。
(2) 現在我必須承認我已毫無辦法。
(3) 他承認以前從未見過她。
(4) 他拒絕認罪。
(5) 一位年長的意大利男人來向他的神父告解。
(6) 許多基督徒定期向神父懺悔。
(7) 神父聽取那個青年的懺悔。
column8: When you confess, you admit to doing something wrong. You might feel guilty about eating the entire platter of chocolate chip cookies and confess to your mom before she notices. If she presses charges, you would confess to the cookie crime.
column9: Confess can be used to describe admitting to committing a crime. If you watch crime shows on TV, you've likely seen detectives trying to get a suspect to confess. Confess can also be used in a religious context. Catholics confess their sins to a priest on a regular basis. Don't confuse the word confess with apology. An apology involves expressing regret about something. When you confess, you're merely owning up to doing it — you might not be sorry.
column11:
1[VERB 動詞]承認，供認，坦白(自己做錯的事) If someone confesses to doing something wrong, they admit that they did it.
  [V to n/-ing]
  [V that]
  [V n]
  [V]
  [V with quote]
  [Also V wh]

  • He had confessed to seventeen murders...

    他供認了17起謀殺案。

  • Her husband confessed to having had an affair...

    她丈夫承認有過外遇。

  • I had expected her to confess that she only wrote these books for the money...

    我本以為她會承認寫這些書只是為了錢。

  • Most rape victims confess a feeling of helplessness...

    大部分強姦案受害者都承認有一種無助的感覺。

  • Ray changed his mind, claiming that he had been forced into confessing...

    雷翻了供，聲稱自己是被逼招供的。

  • 'I played a very bad match,' he confessed.

    「這場比賽我打得很差。」他坦白道。

2[VERB 動詞](向上帝或神甫)懺悔，告解(罪過) If someone confesses or confesses their sins, they tell God or a priest about their sins so that they can be forgiven.
  [V n]
  [V n to n]
  [Also V]

  • You just go to the church and confess your sins...

    你乾脆去教堂懺悔自己的罪過吧。

  • Once we have confessed our failures and mistakes to God, we should stop feeling guilty.

    一旦我們向上帝告明瞭自己的過失和錯誤，就不該再覺得內疚。

3[PHRASE 短語]我承認，我必須承認(用來對自己的過失等略表歉意) You use expressions like 'I confess', 'I must confess', or 'I have to confess' to apologize slightly for admitting something you are ashamed of or that you think might offend or annoy someone.
  [PHR with cl]
  [politeness]

  • I confess it's got me baffled...

    我承認這把我難倒了。

  • I must confess I'm not a great enthusiast for long political programmes.

    我必須承認自己對時間很長的政治節目不是很熱衷。

column5: adj.秘密的；機密的；表示信任的；獲信賴的
column6:
(1) He has been on confidential missions to Berlin.
(2) He told me the confidential information.
(3) He was an author whose works were so little known as to be almost confidential.
(4) Don't be too confidential with strangers.
(5) She is a confidential secretary of Mr. Smith.
column7:
(1) 他前往柏林執行秘密任務。
(2) 他向我透露了這個秘密的信息。
(3) 他這位作家的著作是如此不為人所知，以致幾乎等於機密文件。
(4) 不要過份相信陌生人。
(5) 她是史密斯先生的一個機要秘書。
column8: If you get a letter stamped confidential, that means you're not supposed to tell anyone else what it says. It's private and you're not supposed to blab about it.
column9: Confidential suggests that you're being let in on a secret — as in Kitchen Confidential, the title of a book by Anthony Bourdain, a famous chef, in which he tells unappetizing stories about the restaurant industry. If you confide in someone, you are trusting him or her with confidential or secret information. Choose your confidants wisely!
column11:
1[ADJ-GRADED 能被表示程度的副詞或介詞詞組修飾的形容詞]秘密的；機密的 Information that is confidential is meant to be kept secret or private.

  • She accused them of leaking confidential information about her private life...

    她指責他們洩露其私生活的秘密。

  • We'll take good care and keep what you've told us strictly confidential, Mr. Lane.

    萊恩先生，我們會非常小心，對您告訴我們的事嚴格保密。

confidentially

  • People can phone in the knowledge that any information they give will be treated confidentially.

    人們盡可放心地打電話來，他們提供的任何信息都會被保密。

confidentiality

  • ...the confidentiality of the client-solicitor relationship.

    委託人與律師之間的保密關係

2[ADJ-GRADED 能被表示程度的副詞或介詞詞組修飾的形容詞]悄悄的；隱秘的 If you talk to someone in a confidential way, you talk to them quietly because what you are saying is secret or private.
  [usu ADJ n]

  • 'Look,' he said in a confidential tone, 'I want you to know that me and Joey are cops.'...

    「聽著，」他悄聲說，「我想讓你知道我和喬伊是警察。」

  • His face suddenly turned solemn, his voice confidential.

    他臉上的神情突然嚴肅起來，聲音也壓低了。

confidentially

  • Nash hadn't raised his voice, still spoke rather softly, confidentially.

    納什沒有提高嗓門，依然悄聲說著，相當輕柔。

column5:
n.結構；佈局；形態；格式塔心理完形
[計算機] 配置.
column6:
(1) It is something resembling this structure in configuration or pattern.
(2) The configuration of this plant is complex.
(3) This is the configuration of the earth's surface.
column7:
(1) 這是一種在外形或結構上類似這種構造的東西。
(2) 這個工廠的佈局很複雜。
(3) 這就是地球表面的形狀。
column8: When you position items into any spatial arrangement, you are creating a configuration, or specific shape. For example, scientists refer to the specific, bonded arrangement of atoms to make a molecule as a configuration.
column9: The root of configuration presents pretty much the current meaning, with the Latin configūrāre meaning "to mold or shape." You can see the word figure in the middle, which presents the idea of a physical form that's being shaped. As an example: the specific configuration, or arrangement, of the genes in your DNA is what makes you the unique individual that you are.
column11:
1[N-COUNT 可數名詞]安排；格局；佈局 A configuration is an arrangement of a group of things.
  [FORMAL 正式]

  • ...Stonehenge, in south-western England, an ancient configuration of giant stones.

    英格蘭西南部的巨石陣——一座古老的巨石陣列

2[N-UNCOUNT 不可數名詞]配置 The configuration of a computer system is way in which all its parts, such as the hardware and software, are connected together in order for the computer to work.
  [COMPUTING 計算機]

  • Prices range from $119 to $199, depending on the particular configuration.

    價格因具體配置而異，從119美元至199美元不等。

column5:
vt.限制；禁閉
n.範圍；界限；約束；限制
column6:
(1) I wish the speaker would confine himself to the subject.
(2) I am sick, I have to confine to bed.
(3) The thief was confined in a prison.
(4) Is it cruel to confine a bird in a cage?
(5) This is outside the confines of human knowledge.
(6) The refiner defined a definite confine with her fine finger.
(7) Our first example of confining waves will be to confine a wave at one boundary.
(8) It will use magnetic fields to confine hydrogen isotopes and heat them to hundreds of millions of degrees Celcius.
(9) The murderer was placed in the confine.
column7:
(1) 我希望演說者不要離題。
(2) 我病了，我得臥床休息。
(3) 竊賊被關押在監獄裡。
(4) 把鳥關在籠子裡殘忍不殘忍?
(5) 這超出了人類知識範疇。
(6) 提煉者用她精細的手指定義了一個明確的界限。
(7) 約束波的第一例子是使波動在一個界面上受到限制。
(8) 它利用磁場約束氫的同位素並將其加熱到數億攝氏度。
(9) 殺人犯被監禁了。
column8: Confine is all about setting limits. If you are confined to the house, it means you can't leave it. If you're really sick, you might be confined to your bed.
column9: Confine can be used abstractly as well. In writing a term paper, your teacher might tell you to confine your examples to ones that you can support with direct evidence. In the 19th century, pregnancy and childbirth were often referred to as a woman's confinement—a time when she couldn't get up or out.
column11:
The verb is pronounced /kən'faɪn/. The noun confines is pronounced /'kɒnfaɪnz/. 動詞讀作 /kən'faɪn/。名詞讀作 /'kɒnfaɪnz/。
1[VERB 動詞]限制，限定（防止擴散蔓延） To confine something to a particular place or group means to prevent it from spreading beyond that place or group.
  [V n to n]
  [V n]

  • Health officials have successfully confined the epidemic to the Tabatinga area...

    衛生官員成功地將疫情控制在塔巴廷加地區。

  • The US will soon be taking steps to confine the conflict.

    美國很快就會採取措施限制衝突。

2[VERB 動詞]限制(自己或自己的活動)；使受局限 If you confine yourself or your activities to something, you do only that thing and are involved with nothing else.
  [V pron-refl to n]
  [V n to n]
  [V-ed]

  • He did not confine himself to the one language...

    他沒把自己局限於這一門語言。

  • Yoko had largely confined her activities to the world of big business...

    洋子主要是做大生意。

  • His genius was not confined to the decoration of buildings.

    他的天賦不單體現在建築物的裝飾上。

3[VERB 動詞]監禁；關押；禁閉 If someone is confined to a mental institution, prison, or other place, they are sent there and are not allowed to leave for a period of time.
  [be V-ed to n]
  [usu passive]

  • The woman will be confined to a mental institution...

    這個女人將被關進精神病院。

  • He announced that the army and police had been confined to barracks.

    他通告說軍隊和警察已經被禁閉在營房中不得外出。

4[N-PLURAL 複數名詞]邊界；界限；範圍 Something that is within the confines of an area or place is within the boundaries enclosing it.
  [usu prep the N of n]
  [FORMAL 正式]

  • The movie is set entirely within the confines of the abandoned factory.

    電影的拍攝完全是在這個廢棄的工廠廠區內進行。

  • ...the wild grass and weeds that grew in the confines of the grandstand.

    大看台上叢生的野草

5[N-PLURAL 複數名詞]限制；局限 The confines of a situation, system, or activity are the limits or restrictions it involves.
  [usu the N of n]

  • ...away from the confines of the British class system...

    超越英國社會等級制度的限制

  • I can't stand the confines of this marriage.

    我受不了這段婚姻的限制。

column5: n.  (1) 大火, 大火災 (2) 暴力場景，戰爭
column6: They may succeed in turning a little local difficulty into a full-blown regional conflagration.

column5: vt. (將不同的信息、文本、觀念等)合而為一;將（兩種資料）合而為一; 混合
column6: (1) The results of the two experiments were conflated. (3) the urban crisis conflates a number of different economic, political, and social issues.
column7:
(1) 這兩項實驗的結果合並在一起了.
(2) 這兩個定義可以合成一個呢, 還是必須分開?
(3) 城市危機使若干不同的經濟、政治和社會問題合成一個綜合的問題。

column5: v.使一致；遵從
column6:
(1) His ideas do not conform to mine.
(2) He doesn't conform to the usual stereotype of the city businessman with a dark suit and rolled umbrella.
(3) She refused to conform to the normal social conventions.
(4) She left home to escape the pressure to conform to her family's way of life.
(5) Students are required to conform to the rules.
column7:
(1) 他的想法和我的不一致。
(2) 他不像典型的城市商人那樣，穿一身深色的套服、 帶一把收好的雨傘。
(3) 她拒絕遵從正常的社會習俗。
(4) 她離家出走以求擺脫她家生活方式對她的束縛。
(5) 學生被要求遵守規則。
column8: To conform means to adapt to fit in with new conditions. So if you travel to Morocco, you should conform to the local custom and adjust your usually skin-bearing wardrobe to one that is more modest.
column9: Sometimes conform gets a bad rap, carrying with it the sense of compromising one』s individuality to fit in or please others. But take note that it doesn』t always have to carry such a negative charge. For example, the manager of a factory that produces bouncy balls would want each ball that came off his conveyor belts to conform to a high standard of durability, bounciness, and roundness.
column11:
1[VERB 動詞]遵守，遵從，符合(法律、意願等) If something conforms to something such as a law or someone's wishes, it is of the required type or quality.
  [V to/with n]

  • The Night Rider lamp has been designed to conform to new British Standard safety requirements...

    「夜行者」燈的設計符合新的英國安全標準的要求。

  • The meat market can continue only if it is radically overhauled to conform with strict European standards.

    肉類市場只有經過徹底的大檢查，嚴格遵守歐洲標準，才能繼續營業。

2[VERB 動詞]按規矩行事；順從；隨潮流 If you conform, you behave in the way that you are expected or supposed to behave.
  [V]
  [V to/with n]

  • Many children who can't or don't conform are often bullied...

    很多不能或不按規矩行事的小孩常常被人欺負。

  • He did not feel obliged to conform to the rules that applied to ordinary men...

    他覺得自己不必遵守那些適用於普通人的規定。

  • We conformed with social and family expectations.

    我們遵從社會和家庭的期望行事。

3[VERB 動詞](與樣式、類型等)非常相似，一致，相吻合 If someone or something conforms to a pattern or type, they are very similar to it.
  [V to n]

  • I am well aware that we all conform to one stereotype or another...

    我們所有人都能找到某種與自己相似的模式化形象，這一點我很清楚。

  • Like most 'peacetime wars' it did not conform to preconceived ideas.

    如同大多數「和平時代的戰爭」一樣，這與我們的預想不同。

column5: vt.使困惑；混淆；挫敗；詛咒
column6:
(1) Don't confound the means with the ends.
(2) To confound two things means not to be able to tell them apart.
column7:
(1) 不要把手段和目的混淆起來。
(2) 混淆兩件事物的意思是說沒能把它們區分開來。
column8: If you have an identical twin, you've probably tried dressing alike so that people confound you with, or mistake you for, one another. You've also probably learned that, unfortunately, this trick doesn』t work on your mom.
column9: The verb confound means both "to mistake" and "to confuse." If you decide to treat yourself to a delicious dessert, you might find yourself confounded by the overwhelming number of choices. If you end up ordering the chocolate cake but the waiter brings you chocolate mousse, the waiter has somehow confounded those two options. Another meaning you may come across in literature is "to damn," as in "Confound it! You are the most exasperating person on the planet."
column11:
1[VERB 動詞]使困惑；使驚訝 If someone or something confounds you, they make you feel surprised or confused, often by showing you that your opinions or expectations of them were wrong.
  [V n]

  • He momentarily confounded his critics by his cool handling of the hostage crisis...

    他對人質危機的冷靜處理一時讓批評者們驚訝不已。

  • The choice of Governor may confound us all.

    州長的選擇可能會讓我們所有人感到困惑。

column5: vt.對抗；遭遇；面臨
column6:
(1) We must confront future with optimism.
(2) You must confront your problems.
(3) It's no use to confront your boss.
(4) A soldier often has to confront danger.
(5) Confronted by an angry crowd, the police retreated.
(6) The difficulties that confront us seem insuperable.
column7:
(1) 我們必須樂觀地面對未來。
(2) 你必須面對自己的問題。
(3) 對抗你的老闆是沒有用的。
(4) 士兵常常要身臨險境。
(5) 警察面對憤怒的人群只好後撤了。
(6) 我們面臨的困難似乎是不可克服的。
column8: Confront means either to face a situation that makes you uncomfortable, or to say something to someone about something they've done that bothers you. Rather than letting things go, when people are rude to you you should confront them.
column9: Confront derives from the Latin con- "with" and -front "front." You can confront a sad truth, you can confront a person by calling them on their behavior, you can confront someone with the fact that they have terrible breath. You can be confronted, too—on the trip through the mountains, we were confronted by the impassibility of the road.
column11:
1[VERB 動詞](問題、任務或困難)降臨，使面臨 If you are confronted with a problem, task, or difficulty, you have to deal with it.
  [be V-ed with/by n]
  [V n]

  • She was confronted with severe money problems...

    她面臨嚴峻的資金問題。

  • Ministers underestimated the magnitude of the task confronting them.

    部長們低估了他們所面臨的任務的艱巨性。

2[VERB 動詞]勇敢地面對；正視 If you confront a difficult situation or issue, you accept the fact that it exists and try to deal with it.
  [V n]

  • We are learning how to confront death...

    我們正在學習如何直面死亡。

  • NATO countries have been forced to confront fundamental moral questions.

    北約國家被迫正視基本的道德問題。

3[VERB 動詞]使面對(有威脅性或困難的事) If you are confronted by something that you find threatening or difficult to deal with, it is there in front of you.
  [be V-ed with/by n]
  [usu passive]

  • I was confronted with an array of knobs, levers, and switches.

    我面對的是一大堆旋鈕、控制桿和開關。

4[VERB 動詞]與…對峙；與…對抗 If you confront someone, you stand or sit in front of them, especially when you are going to fight, argue, or compete with them.
  [V n]

  • She pushed her way through the mob and confronted him face to face...

    她擠過騷動的人群，與他當面對峙。

  • They don't hesitate to open fire when confronted by police...

    他們遭遇警察時毫不猶豫地開火。

  • The candidates confronted each other during a televised debate.

    候選人在電視辯論中當面交鋒。

5[VERB 動詞]與…當面對證(或對質) If you confront someone with something, you present facts or evidence to them in order to accuse them of something.
  [V n with n]
  [V n about n]
  [V n]

  • She had decided to confront Kathryn with what she had learnt...

    她決定拿自己瞭解的事實與凱瑟琳當面對證。

  • I could not bring myself to confront him about it...

    我不忍心就這事和他對質。

  • His confronting me forced me to search for the answers.

    他對我的當面質詢迫使我思索如何作答。

column5: vi. Vt. (1) (尤指冷卻後)凝結, 凝固, 凍結: (2) 〈喻〉成形(尤指形成完美的整體); 融合
column6:
(1) the blood had congealed into blobs
(2) a lump of congealed moussaka
(3) The blood had congealed round the cut on her knee.
(4) Use hot water to rinse the congealed fat off the dinner plates.
(5) the ballet failed to congeal as a single oeuvre.
column7:
(1) 血液已凝成團
(2) 一塊凝結的碎肉茄子蛋
(3) 血液在她的膝蓋傷口周圍凝固了
(4) 用熱水把菜盤上凝結的油漬沖洗掉
(5) 這部芭蕾舞劇未能融合成一個完美的藝術整體

column5: adj.天生的；先天的
column6:
(1) The congenital form is spread to the fetus through the bloodstream.
(2) In most cases, a hydrocele is congenital, i.e. a baby boy is born with it.
column7:
(1) 先天的形式是通過血液傳播給胎兒。
(2) 大多數睪丸鞘膜積液是先天的，也就是說，男嬰生下來就帶有積液。
column8: Congenital refers to something present at birth but not necessarily inherited from the parents. Babies with heart disorders developed in utero can live long and productive lives, in spite of their congenital birth defect.
column9: Congenital derives from the Latin genus, to beget. Something that is present at one』s begetting, during fetal development, or at birth is congenital. Fetal alcohol syndrome, which develops in fetuses if their mothers are drinking heavily while pregnant, is a congenital disorder. You might also use congenital to describe something seemingly inborn "a congenital sense of humor," or a "congenital faith."
column11:
1[ADJ 形容詞](病症)先天的 A congenital disease or medical condition is one that a person has had from birth, but is not inherited.
  [usu ADJ n]
  [MEDICAL 醫]

  • When John was 17, he died of congenital heart disease.

    約翰17歲時死於先天性心臟病。

congenitally

  • ...congenitally deaf patients.

    先天耳聾患者

2[ADJ 形容詞]天生的；生性的 A congenital characteristic or feature in a person is so strong that you cannot imagine it ever changing, although there may seem to be no reason for it.
  [usu ADJ n]

  • He was a congenital liar and usually in debt.

    他生性愛說謊，而且通常債務纏身。

congenitally

  • I admit to being congenitally lazy.

    我承認自己生性懶惰。

column5:
adj.擁擠的；堵塞的；充血的；鼻子不通的
動詞congest的過去式和過去分詞.
column6:
(1) The street was congested with traffic.
(2) He had a cold and was very congested.
column7:
(1) 街道因往來車輛而阻塞。
(2) 他患了感冒，鼻子不通。
column8: If you are having trouble breathing, you keep sneezing, and your head feels like it might explode, you may very well be congested. In other words, fluid may have built up in your sinuses and your lungs.
column9: Being congested is a typical but very unpleasant symptom of the common cold. This adjective literally means 「clogged,」 「overcrowded,」 or 「overfull.」 Congested is also used to describe arteries that are clogged, cities that are overpopulated, and roads that are full of traffic.
column11:
1[ADJ-GRADED 能被表示程度的副詞或介詞詞組修飾的形容詞]（道路或區域）交通阻塞的，擁堵的 A congested road or area is extremely crowded and blocked with traffic or people.

  • He first promised two weeks ago to clear Britain's congested roads...

    他在兩周前首次承諾解決英國道路擁堵的問題。

  • Some areas are congested with both cars and people.

    有些地方擠滿了車和人。

2[ADJ-GRADED 能被表示程度的副詞或介詞詞組修飾的形容詞](身體部位)堵塞的，充血的，淤血的 If a part of the body is congested, it is blocked.
  [FORMAL 正式]

  • The arteries in his neck had become fatally congested.

    他頸動脈栓塞，危在旦夕。

column5:
n.聯合企業；密集體；城郊混合區；[地]礫岩
adj.聚成一團的；成簇的
vt.使聚集；使結成；結合
column6:
(1) An American conglomerate holds a major share in the company.
(2) The firm has been taken over by an American conglomerate.
(3) The house was a conglomerate of architectural styles.
(4) Sandstone and conglomerate are the consolidated equivalent of sand and gravel.
(5) A large number of people conglomerated round her.
column7:
(1) 一家美國的大聯合企業持有該公司的大部分股份。
(2) 該公司已被美國一企業集團接管。
(3) 這幢房子是多種建築風格的綜合。
(4) 砂岩和礫岩分別是砂和礫石固結的產物。
(5) 在她周圍聚集了一大群人。
column8: A conglomerate is a group of things, especially companies, put together to form one. If you are rich enough to buy a TV network, a record company, several newspapers, and a radio station, you too can own a media conglomerate.
column9: The root of conglomerate is glomus, a Latin word for 「ball.」 So think of a conglomerate as a bunch of different things balled together. Before it came to describe giant corporations, a conglomerate was a rock formed from different kinds of minerals. Conglomerate can also be used as a verb — like when your media companies conglomerated successfully.
column11:
1[N-COUNT 可數名詞]大型聯合企業；企業集團 A conglomerate is a large business firm consisting of several different companies.
  [oft adj N]
  [BUSINESS 商]

  • Fiat is Italy's largest industrial conglomerate.

    菲亞特是意大利最大的產業集團。

column5: n.  (1)祝賀或受到祝賀  (2)賀詞 (3) (用作嘆詞)
column6:
(1) a speech of congratulation for the winner
(2) offer sb one's congratulations on his success
(3)Congratulations on winning the prize!
column7:
(1) 對獲勝者的賀詞.
(2) 祝賀某人成功
(3) 祝賀你獲獎!

column5:
v.使集合；聚集；集合
adj.集體的
column6:
(1) We are congregated for a meeting.
(2) A crowd quickly congregated round the speaker.
(3) The highbrows usually congregate there.
(4) The personal benefit can't divide congregate benifit.
column7:
(1) 我們集合起來開會。
(2) 大群的人迅速地在演說者周圍聚集起來。
(3) 知識界人士通常都在那裡聚會。
(4) 個人的利益是與集體的利益分不開的。
column8: Congregate is a verb that means to come together, to assemble, or to gather. At school dances, you may congregate with your friends, because you get nervous in front of kids you don't know very well.
column9: Congregate comes from Latin root words com, meaning "together" and gregare, meaning "to gather in a flock." Congregation, or a gathering or assembly, comes from the same roots, as does gregarious, an adjective describing someone who likes to gather with others to socialize. If you remember the key word is flock — what ministers often call their congregations — you should have no trouble remembering congregate means to flock together.
column11:
1[VERB 動詞]集合；聚集 When people congregate, they gather together and form a group.
  [V]

  • Youngsters love to congregate here in the evenings outside cinemas showing American films...

    晚上，年輕人喜歡聚集在放映美國電影的電影院外面。

  • Visitors congregated on Sunday afternoons to view public exhibitions.

    每週日下午，遊客成群結隊地來看公開展覽。

column5: n.  (1)(尤指政黨、工會或某活動範圍內的)代表會議 (2) (尤指美國)國家立法機關, 國會, 議會 (3) (尤指政治性)協會, 組織, 團體 (4) 聚集, 聚會:
column6:
(1) an international congress of mathematicians.
(2) The President has lost the support of Congress.
column7:
(1) 國際數學家代表大會。
(2) 總統失去國會的支持

column5: adj.合適的；一致的；全等的
column6:
(1) But not all practices are congruent.
(2) And there are many areas of congruent interests.
(3) In addition, care should be made to only use leverage which is congruent with your personal risk tolerance.
column7:
(1) 但不是所有的實踐都是合適的。
(2) 而在其他諸多領域中，雙方不乏和諧一致的利益。
(3) 此外，應注意只使用了槓桿作用是相一致的個人風險承受能力。
column8: The adjective, congruent fits when two shapes are the same in shape and size. If you lay two congruent triangles on each other, they would match up exactly.
column9: Congruent comes from the Latin verb congruere "to come together, correspond with." Figuratively, the word describes something that is similar in character or type. Are your actions congruent with your values? If a friend says something outrageous that you don't want to agree with but don't want to disagree with either, say that your friend's idea is congruent with what you think. That way you can agree with him but change your mind later if you have to.
column11:
1[ADJ 形容詞]相似的；相稱的；一致的 If one thing is congruent with another thing, they are similar or fit together well.
  [usu v-link ADJ]
  [FORMAL 正式]

  • They want to work in an organisation whose values are congruent with their own.

    他們想在一個符合自己價值觀的機構裡工作。

column5: n.針葉樹
column6:
(1) In conifer orchards new stumps should be removed.
(2) They are large evergreen conifer trees, ranging from 23m to 32m high.
column7:
(1) 在針葉樹的種子園，新的伐樁應予除掉。
(2) 它們是 23 米到 32 米高的大型的常綠針葉樹。
column8: A conifer is a type of tree that produces cones and evergreen needles. Spot a pile of cones beneath a tree and you've found yourself a conifer.
column9: With the word cone embedded in it, it's no surprise that conifer is the term used for cone-producing trees. Conifers can often be identified by their typically long needle-shaped leaves like the kind you find on a Christmas tree. Mostly found in northern forests where the winters are cold, the tough prickly leaves on conifers make them adaptable to the weather.
column11: 1[N-COUNT 可數名詞]針葉樹 Conifers are a group of trees and shrubs, for example pine trees and fir trees, that grow in cooler areas of the world. They have fruit called cones, and very thin leaves called needles which they do not normally lose in winter.

column5:
n.推測；臆測
v.推測
column6:
(1) But Manski's model did not confirm this conjecture.
(2) No conjecture can be offered on the subject.
(3) Chronology protection is still just a conjecture, so time travel remains a possibility.
(4) Who can conjecture about tomorrow's weather conditions?
column7:
(1) 但曼斯基的模型並無法證實這個推測。
(2) 關於這個問題不可臆測。
(3) 時序保護還只是個臆測而已，所以時光旅行仍是可能的。
(4) 誰能推測出明天的天氣情況？
column8: Can you guess what conjecture means? It's a word to use when you are not sure of something and have to "guess or surmise."
column9: You can see how the word conjecture means that you create a theory or opinion about something without basing it in fact because the original definition of conjecture, from Old French, is "interpretation of signs and omens." Since signs and omens are pretty subjective, it makes sense that the word would then move to its current meaning. However, even though it only seems like weather reports are conjectures, they are actually based on evidence!
column11:
1[N-VAR 可變名詞]推測；猜測 A conjecture is a conclusion that is based on information that is not certain or complete.
  [FORMAL 正式]

  • That was a conjecture, not a fact...

    那只是猜測，不是事實。

  • There are several conjectures...

    存在著幾種猜測。

  • The attitudes of others were matters of conjecture although there were plenty of rumours about how individuals had behaved.

    儘管對個人的表現存在很多謠傳，但他人的看法還只是一些猜測。

2[VERB 動詞]推測；猜測；揣測 When you conjecture, you form an opinion or reach a conclusion on the basis of information that is not certain or complete.
  [V that]
  [V]
  [Also V wh]
  [FORMAL 正式]

  • He conjectured that some individuals may be able to detect major calamities...

    他猜測說有些人也許能夠察覺重大災難。

  • This may be true or partly true； we are all conjecturing here.

    這可能屬實或者部分屬實，我們都是在這兒揣測。

column5: n.結合；關聯；連詞；(事件等的)同時發生
column6:
(1) The novel should be read in conjunction with the author's biography.
(2) The conjunction of workmanship and artistry in making jewelry decides the value of the jewelry.
(3) The word is a temporal conjunction.
(4) An unusual conjunction of circumstances led to the incident.
(5) The conjunction of heavy rains and high winds caused flooding.
(6) This program is not applicable in conjunction with other promotion offer.
column7:
(1) 這本小說應該和作者傳記一起讀。
(2) 在珠寶飾物的製造中，手工與藝術的結合決定了珠寶的價值。
(3) 該詞是表示時間的連詞。
(4) 各種情況的偶然巧合導致了這件事的發生。
(5) 暴風雨的同時發生引起了洪水氾濫。
(6) 此優惠不能與其它優惠同時享用。
column8: Conjunction Junction, what's your function? Hooking up words and phrases and clauses. These lyrics from Schoolhouse Rock sum it up: a conjunction is all about joining things together.
column9: The words and, but, and or are conjunctions, linking words and phrases together to form sentences. Other kinds of conjunctions bring groups together, such as organizations working in conjunction to present a big event; or bring objects together, like a conjunction in a house's plumbing system where pipes meet. Conjunction could also mean things happening at the same time, such as free Schoolhouse Rock screenings that are presented in conjunction with a National Grammar Day celebration.
column11:
1[N-COUNT 可數名詞](事件的)同時發生，同地發生 A conjunction of two or more things is the occurrence of them at the same time or place.
  [usu N of n]
  [FORMAL 正式]

  • ...the conjunction of two events.

    兩個事件的同時發生

  • ...a conjunction of religious and social factors.

    宗教因素和社會因素的並存

2[N-COUNT 可數名詞](語法中的)連詞 In grammar, a conjunction is a word or group of words that joins together words, groups, or clauses. In English, there are co-ordinating conjunctions such as 'and' and 'but', and subordinating conjunctions such as 'although', 'because', and 'when'.
    3[PHRASE 短語]連同…；與…一起 If one thing is done or used in conjunction with another, the two things are done or used together.
      [usu PHR with n]
      [FORMAL 正式]

    • The army should have operated in conjunction with the fleet to raid the enemy's coast...

      陸軍本應與艦隊共同行動，突襲敵方海岸。

    • Since iron destroys vitamin E, these two nutrients should not be taken in conjunction.

      鐵會破壞維生素E，所以這兩種營養物質不應該同時攝取。

column5: n.鑒識家；內行
column6: (1) He is a connoisseur of antique furniture.
column7: (1) 他是古家俱鑒定家。
column8: A connoisseur is a person who, through study and interest, has a fine appreciation for something, like the connoisseur who can identify the clarinet player on a jazz recording by the sound of his inhalations alone.
column9: A connoisseur is an authority in his field, someone who has expert knowledge and training, especially in the arts. A connoisseur may also be someone with an extremely developed sense of taste, like the connoisseur who can identify rare wine by a flavor others can't even detect. Then again, some people call themselves connoisseurs of just about anything they like — pizza, old vinyl albums, even cartoons — because they know so much about it.
column11:
1[N-COUNT 可數名詞](藝術、食品、酒等的)鑒賞家，鑒定家，行家 A connoisseur is someone who knows a lot about the arts, food, drink, or some other subject.
  [oft n N]

  • Sarah tells me you're something of an art connoisseur.

    薩拉告訴我你是一位藝術鑒賞家。

  • ...connoisseurs of good food.

    美食家

column5: vt.意味著；隱含；暗示
column6:
(1) Very soon 『Third World』 came to connote poverty.
(2) The term "program" is not intended to connote complete rigidyty.
(3) The word 「food」 may connote 「greed」.
(4) Negative symptoms generally connote diminished experience.
column7:
(1) 「第三世界」一詞很快就帶有了貧窮這個含義。
(2) 「程序」這個詞不含有完全定型的意思。
(3) 這個詞可以含有「貪婪」的意思。
(4) 負性症狀一般暗示經驗的縮減。
column8: Often your body language can connote or imply how you feel without you having to saying it directly. For example, if you fold your arms and look away from someone as he speaks to you, you are connoting your discomfort.
column9: When you act a certain way to show how you feel rather than just outright saying it, you're connoting or suggesting that emotion. Words can often connote or suggest certain meanings or ideas. The word turbulent connotes the image of a bumpy ride on an airplane, for example. Connote is also used in formal logic. If A connotes B, then for A to be true, B has to also be true.
column11:
1[VERB 動詞](詞或名字)隱含，暗示，使人聯想到 If a word or name connotes something, it makes you think of a particular idea or quality.
  [V n]
  [FORMAL 正式]

  • The term 'organization' often connotes a sense of neatness. organization

    這個詞常常讓人想到整潔。

column5: n.良心；是非之心；顧忌
column6:
(1) She was afflicted with conscience.
(2) The thief's conscience smote him.
(3) She gave him back the money she'd stolen for the sake of her conscience.
(4) This is a document that serves as the nation's conscience.
column7:
(1) 她受良心責備。
(2) 那個賊突然良心發現。
(3) 為了不受良心的譴責，她把從他那偷來的錢還給他了。
(4) 這是一份表明民族道德準則的文件。
column8: A conscience is a built-in sense of what's right and what's wrong. That sick feeling in your stomach after you meanly told your younger brother the truth about Santa Claus? That might be your conscience bothering you.
column9: The word conscience contains the word science, which comes from the Latin word scientia, meaning "to know" or "knowledge." You can think of your conscience as your knowledge of yourself, especially when it comes to your own morals, or your feelings about right and wrong. Pangs of conscience, which feel like an uncomfortable inner voice, are helpful when you're trying to decide the right thing to do in a particular situation.
column11:
1[N-COUNT 可數名詞]良心；良知 Your conscience is the part of your mind that tells you whether what you are doing is right or wrong. If you have a guilty conscience, you feel guilty about something because you know it was wrong. If you have a clear conscience, you do not feel guilty because you know you have done nothing wrong.
  [usu sing]

  • I have battled with my conscience over whether I should actually send this letter...

    我備受良心的煎熬，不知是否真的應該把這封信寄出去。

  • What if he got a guilty conscience and brought it back?...

    要是他覺得內疚，把東西拿回來了怎麼辦？

  • I could go away again with a clear conscience.

    我可以問心無愧地再次離開。

2[N-UNCOUNT 不可數名詞]See also:prisoner of conscience；信仰；憑良心行事 Conscience is doing what you believe is right even though it might be unpopular, difficult, or dangerous.

  • He refused for reasons of conscience to sign a new law legalising abortion.

    他出於信仰，拒絕簽署使墮胎合法化的新法。

  • ...the law on freedom of conscience and religious organizations.

    有關信仰自由和宗教組織自由的法律

3[N-UNCOUNT 不可數名詞]內疚；良心不安 Conscience is a feeling of guilt because you know you have done something that is wrong.

  • I'm so glad he had a pang of conscience...

    我很高興他會有負疚感。

  • They have shown a ruthless lack of conscience.

    他們沒有表現出絲毫內疚，實在是太無情了。

4[PHRASE 短語]憑良心；出於公道 If you say that you cannot do something in all conscience ,in good conscience, or in conscience, you mean that you cannot do it because you think it is wrong.
  [PHR with cl]

  • She could not, in good conscience, back out on her deal with him.

    憑良心她不能背棄與他達成的協議。

5[PHRASE 短語]內疚；良心不安 If you have something on your conscience, you feel guilty because you know you have done something wrong.
  [PHR after v]

  • Now the murderer has two deaths on his conscience.

    現在，這個殺人犯背著兩條人命，受到了良心的譴責。

column5:
adj.神志清醒的；意識到的；自覺的；有意的
n.意識
column6:
(1) His rudeness was conscious, not accidental.
(2) He was conscious of his guilt.
(3) I am conscious that I have done right.
(4) I had to make a conscious effort not to be rude to him.
(5) His rudeness was conscious, not accidental.
(6) Ink is a high-concept visual thriller that weaves seamlessly between the conscious and the subconscious.
column7:
(1) 他的粗暴無禮是故意的,不是偶然的。
(2) 他自知有罪。
(3) 我相信自己做得不錯。
(4) 我得刻意約束自己不要對他粗魯。
(5) 他的粗暴無禮是故意的,不是偶然的。
(6) 墨水是個超意念的可見實體，可以游離於意識和下意識之間。
column8: Conscious is an adjective that simply means alert and awake. If you fall from a tree and smack your head on the side of the wheelbarrow, there's a good chance you won't be conscious afterward.
column9: Conscious is a Latin word whose original meaning was 「knowing" or "aware.」 So a conscious person has an awareness of her environment and her own existence and thoughts. If you're "self-conscious," you're overly aware and even embarrassed by how you think you look or act. But that sounds better than being unconscious, or totally unaware and out of it.
column11:
1[ADJ-GRADED 能被表示程度的副詞或介詞詞組修飾的形容詞]注意到的；意識到的 If you are conscious of something, you notice it or realize that it is happening.
  [v-link ADJ of n/-ing]

  • He was conscious of the faint, musky aroma of after-shave...

    他注意到了須後水淡淡的麝香味。

  • She was very conscious of Max studying her...

    她非常清楚馬克斯在仔細端詳她。

  • Conscious that he was becoming light-headed again, he went over to the window.

    他意識到自己又開始頭暈了，於是走向窗邊。

2[ADJ-GRADED 能被表示程度的副詞或介詞詞組修飾的形容詞](尤指由於不滿或自覺重要而)注意的，關注的 If you are conscious of something, you think about it a lot, especially because you are unhappy about it or because you think it is important.
  [v-link ADJ of n/-ing]

  • I'm very conscious of my weight...

    我很在意自己的體重。

  • He is acutely conscious that this transition will bring with it the risk of social unrest.

    他非常清楚這種轉變伴隨著社會動亂的危險。

3[ADJ 形容詞](決定、行動等)有意的，刻意的 A conscious decision or action is made or done deliberately with you giving your full attention to it.
  [usu ADJ n]

  • I don't think we ever made a conscious decision to have a big family...

    我覺得我們沒有刻意地決定要生很多孩子。

  • Make a conscious effort to relax your muscles.

    有意識地放鬆肌肉。

consciously

  • Sophie was not consciously seeking a replacement after her father died.

    父親去世後，索菲並沒有刻意地尋找替代他的人。

4[ADJ 形容詞]清醒的；有知覺的 Someone who is conscious is awake rather than asleep or unconscious.
  [usu v-link ADJ]

  • She was fully conscious all the time and knew what was going on.

    她一直都很清醒，知道是怎麼回事。

5[ADJ 形容詞](記憶或想法)有意識的，意識到的 Conscious memories or thoughts are ones that you are aware of.
  [ADJ n]

  • He had no conscious memory of his four-week stay in hospital...

    他對自己住院的4個星期沒有任何有意識的記憶。

  • Beneath the conscious mind there are many levels of the unconscious.

    在意識心理之下存在很多層次的無意識。

consciously

  • Most people cannot consciously remember much before the ages of 5 to 7 years...

    大多數人在5至7歲之前沒有多少有意識的記憶。

  • Sometimes we are not consciously aware of these feelings.

    有時候我們沒有意識到這些情感。

column5: adj.連續的；連貫的
column6:
(1) It has rained for four consecutive days.
(2) He was re-elected for four consecutive terms.
(3) The policy of our Party is consecutive.
column7:
(1) 已連續下了四天雨。
(2) 他連著四屆當選。
(3) 我黨的政策始終如一。
column8: If things are consecutive, they happen one after the other with no break. If there are five consecutive snowstorms on five consecutive days, you'll have to shovel your way out on day six.
column9: Consecutive comes from the Latin consecutus, meaning "following closely" with no gap. Just like those snowstorms — one storm happened each day, back to back, for five days in a row. Consecutive numbers also follow each other, or advance in the right order. For example, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, 10 are consecutive numbers. You should number the pages on a term paper to keep them consecutive so the teacher doesn't get confused.
column11:
1[ADJ 形容詞]連續的；不間斷的 Consecutive periods of time or events happen one after the other without interruption.
  [usu ADJ n]

  • The Cup was won for the third consecutive year by the Toronto Maple Leafs...

    多倫多楓葉隊連續第三年捧杯。

  • Photographs taken at the same time on two consecutive sunny days can be quite different from one another.

    在連續兩個艷陽天的同一時間拍攝的照片也可能大不相同。

consecutively

  • ...a CD player which plays six CDs consecutively.

    可以連續播放6張CD的CD播放機

column5: n.一致；同意；共識
column6:
(1) The two parties have reached a consensus.
(2) It would be a good idea to predict which proposal is most likely to achieve consensus.
column7:
(1) 這兩個政黨達成了一致意見。
(2) 不妨研究一下哪項提案最有可能獲得一致同意。
column8: When there's a consensus, everyone agrees on something. If you're going to a movie with friends, you need to reach a consensus about which movie everyone wants to see.
column9: Ever notice how people disagree about just about everything, from who's the best baseball player to how high taxes should be? Whenever there's disagreement, there's no consensus: consensus means everyone is on the same page. When you're talking about all the people in the world, it's hard to find a consensus on anything. There are just too many opinions. However, in a smaller group, reaching a consensus is possible.
column11:
1[N-SING 單數名詞]一致看法；共識 A consensus is general agreement among a group of people.
  [also no det]

  • The consensus amongst the world's scientists is that the world is likely to warm up over the next few decades...

    世界各國科學家一致認為在未來幾十年裡地球有可能變暖。

  • The question of when the troops should leave would be decided by consensus.

    部隊應該何時撤離的問題將由大家共同決定。

column5:
n.同意；贊成
v.同意；答應
column6:
(1) My father will never give his consent to our marriage.
(2) By the common consent of critics, Shakespeare is the prince of character delineators.
(3) Her smile implied her consent to our proposal.
(4) I'm sure he wouldn't consent
(5) His father would not consent to his leaving school.
(6) I agree with you, but yet I can't consent.
(7) Her father reluctantly consented to the marriage.
column7:
(1) 我父親決不會同意我們的婚姻的。
(2) 評論家一致公認莎士比亞是刻畫人物的大師。
(3) 她的微笑暗示她贊成我們的提議。
(4) 我確信他不會同意。
(5) 他的父親不會同意他放棄學業。
(6) 我同意你的意見, 但是我不能答應。
(7) 她父親勉強答應了這樁婚姻。
column8: Before you have surgery, you'd better give your consent, because the surgeon can't get his scalpel anywhere near your skin without first getting this permission from you.
column9: Consent is permission that can be given or taken away. A father might give his consent to allow a young man to marry his daughter, but he might refuse that consent if he learns that the prospective groom has a prison record. A homeowner who won't give a developer consent to tear down her house and build a shopping mall might finally consent after receiving a very large check from the developer.
column11:
1[N-UNCOUNT 不可數名詞]許可；允許 If you give your consent to something, you give someone permission to do it.
  [usu with poss]
  [FORMAL 正式]

  • At approximately 11:30 p.m., Pollard finally gave his consent to the search...

    大概晚上11點半的時候，波拉德最終同意進行搜查。

  • Can my child be medically examined without my consent?

    能不經我的同意就對我的孩子進行體檢嗎？

2[VERB 動詞]同意；允許 If you consent to something, you agree to do it or to allow it to be done.
  [V to-inf]
  [V to n/-ing]
  [V]
  [FORMAL 正式]

  • He finally consented to go...

    他最終同意去了。

  • He asked Ginny if she would consent to a small celebration after the christening...

    他問金尼是否同意在洗禮之後小小地慶祝一下。

  • I was a little surprised when she consented.

    我有點兒吃驚她竟然同意了。

3See also:age of consent；
    4[PHRASE 短語]經一致同意；經雙方同意 If something happens by common consent or by mutual consent, it happens as the result of an agreement between the people or groups involved.
      [PHR with v]

    • By common consent their talk avoided the reason for their being there at all...

      雙方達成共識，他們的談話對他們去那兒的原因完全避而不談。

    • He left the company by mutual consent last September.

      去年9月，經雙方同意，他離開了公司。

    5[PHRASE 短語]經普遍同意 You can use by general consent or by common consent to indicate that most people agree that something is true.
      [PHR with cl]

    • By common consent this election constituted a historic step on the road to democracy.

      普遍認為這次選舉是邁上民主之路的歷史性一步。

column5: n. (1) (通常作複數)結果; 後果; 影響 (2) 重要性 (3) 由於（某事物）的緣故; 因而
column6:
(1)Her investment had disastrous consequences. She lost everything she owned.
(2) It is of no consequence.
(3) She was found guilty, and lost her job in consequence (of it).
(4) [consequence of] Many believe that poverty is a direct consequence of overpopulation.
(5) [consequence for] Our findings have far-reaching consequences for researchers.
(6) [with ... consequences] He ate some poisonous mushrooms, with fatal consequences.
column7:
(1)她的投資結果很慘, 血本無歸.
(2) 這無關緊要
(3) 她被判有罪, 因而失去了工作

column5:
adj.作為結果的；隨之發生的；合乎邏輯的
n.推論；結論；[數]後項
column6: (1) Finally, suggestions on policy were referred to consequent conclusions.
column7: (1) 文章最後根據分析結論提出了相關政策建議。
column8: Something that happens as a result of something else can be described as consequent. Rapidly melting snow often causes consequent flooding, for example.
column9: A politician might talk about raising the minimum wage and consequent improvements in workers' lives — in other words, she believes the positive changes for workers would be a direct result of higher minimum pay. One thing would follow the other. You're most likely to come across the adjective consequent in formal speech or writing. The Latin root word is consequi, "to follow after."
column11:
1[ADJ 形容詞]因之而起的；作為結果的 Consequent means happening as a direct result of an event or situation.
  [usu ADJ n]
  [FORMAL 正式]

  • The warming of the Earth and the consequent climatic changes affect us all...

    地球變暖以及隨之而來的氣候變化影響著我們所有人。

  • The changes in social work consequent upon reorganization have been considerable.

    重組引起社會福利工作發生了重大變化。

column5: adj. (1) 作為結果的, 由…而起的; 隨之發生的: (2) 【律】間接發生的, 間接引起的 (3) 重要的, 重大的; 有重要意義的
column6:
(1) a loss of confidence and a consequential withdrawal of funds.
(2) the new congress lacked consequential leaders.
column7:
(1) 信心的喪失及隨後的撤資。
(2) 新的國會缺少起決定性作用的領導者

column5: adv.因此；所以
column6:
(1) The scandal being exposed, he was removed from office consequently.
(2) The company went bankrupt and consequently he lost his job.
(3) My car broke down and consequently I was late.
column7:
(1) 他的醜聞被曝光了，他因此被調離了職位。
(2) 公司破產,因此他失業了。
(3) 我的汽車壞了
column8: Consequently is a word that has to do with cause and effect. If you failed math, you'll consequently have to take it again.
column9: Sometimes, we don't know why things happen. Other times, we can see one thing leading to another. That's when you can use the word consequently. An employer could say, "We're losing money. Consequently, we have to fire you." The city might say, "It snowed three feet. Consequently, there's no school." If you know that a consequence is the effect or result of something, then that should help you remember how to use consequently.
column11:
1[ADV 副詞]所以；結果 Consequently means as a result.
  [ADV with cl]
  [FORMAL 正式]

  • Grandfather Dingsdale had sustained a broken back while working in the mines. Consequently, he spent the rest of his life in a wheelchair...

    丁斯戴爾爺爺在礦井裡工作時被壓斷了脊骨，結果，下半輩子都與輪椅為伴了。

  • Relations between the two companies had, consequently, never been close.

    因此，兩家公司之間的關係一直都不太親密。

column5:
n.蜜餞；果醬
v.保存；保持；節省；用糖保存
column6:
(1) This is a recipe for strawberry conserve.
(2) I was surprised to find that the strong man liked to eat conserves.
(3) This is a recipe for strawberry conserve.
(4) We must learn to conserve what remains.
(5) We must conserve our forests and woodlands for future generations.
(6) It is important to conserve energy.
column7:
(1) 這是製作草莓醬的食譜。
(2) 我很驚訝地發現這個強壯的男人喜歡吃蜜餞。
(3) 這是製作草莓醬的食譜。
(4) 我們必須學會保存那些剩餘的資源。
(5) 我們必須為子孫後代保護森林資源。
(6) 節省能源十分重要。
column8: To conserve is to save or protect something, like money, or your energy on a long run. People are also encouraged to conserve energy by turning off lights and not cranking the air conditioner.
column9: Conserve is from the Latin for "to keep, preserve, guard" (conservare). Con means "together," so "together" we can "serve" the planet by not doing doughnuts in the wetlands on our jet skis. You can conserve the planet or a little something for yourself — you might conserve hot water so you can wash your hair later, or try to conserve your old bedroom when you go off to college (and your mom is ready for a home office).
column11:
The verb is pronounced /kən'sɜːv/. The noun is pronounced /'kɒnsɜːv/. 動詞讀作 /kən'sɜːv/，名詞讀作 /'kɒnsɜːv/。
1[VERB 動詞]節約；節省 If you conserve a supply of something, you use it carefully so that it lasts for a long time.
  [V n]

  • The republic's factories have closed for the weekend to conserve energy.

    為了節約能源，該共和國的工廠週末不開工。

2[VERB 動詞]保護；保存 To conserve something means to protect it from harm, loss, or change.
  [V n]

  • ...a big increase in US aid to help developing countries conserve their forests.

    美國為幫助發展中國家保護森林所提供的援助的大幅增長

  • ...the Government-funded body responsible for conserving historic buildings.

    政府資助的歷史建築保護機構

3[N-MASS 物質名詞](含有大塊或整塊水果的)蜜餞，果醬 Conserve is jam containing a large proportion of fruit, usually in whole pieces.

column5: adj.重要的；相當大的；可觀的
column6:
(1) The mayor is a considerable official.
(2) He is a considerable person in that college.
(3) The economy was a considerable issue in the campaign.
(4) His remarks provoked considerable comment.
(5) Your work shows considerable improvement.
(6) It is a considerable sum of money.
(7) He was a man of considerable wealth.
column7:
(1) 市長是一位重要的官員。
(2) 他是那所學院相當重要的人物。
(3) 在競選運動中經濟是一個重要問題。
(4) 他的話引起了相當大的議論。
(5) 你的工作顯示出相當大的改進。
(6) 那是一筆數量可觀的錢。
(7) 他是個有可觀的財富的人。
column8: Use the adjective considerable to describe something that is large in amount. Things you probably spend a considerable amount of time on: homework and laundry. Things you'd rather spend time on: anything that isn't homework and laundry!
column9: The adjective considerable can describe something of importance and is worthy of notice or respect. If you are an excellent singer, dancer, musician, writer, or similar profession, people may ask you to donate your considerable talents to charitable causes. If you're not an excellent singer, dancer, musician, or writer, they will still ask you to donate, but they are more likely to ask for money!
column11:
1[ADJ-GRADED 能被表示程度的副詞或介詞詞組修飾的形容詞]相當多的；相當大的 Considerable means great in amount or degree.
  [usu ADJ n]
  [FORMAL 正式]

  • To be without Pearce would be a considerable blow...

    失去皮爾斯將是一個巨大的打擊。

  • Doing it properly makes considerable demands on our time...

    把這事做好要耗費我們相當多的時間。

  • Vets' fees can be considerable, even for routine visits.

    即使是常規檢查，獸醫的收費也會相當高。

considerably

  • Children vary considerably in the rate at which they learn these lessons...

    孩子們學習這些課文的速度大不相同。

  • Their dinner parties had become considerably less formal.

    他們的晚餐會已經遠不如以前正式。

column5: vi.由 ... 組成；構成；在於；符合
column6:
(1) The United Kingdom consists of Great Britain and Northern Ireland.
(2) How many players does a baseball team consist of?
(3) Matters consist of molecules, and molecules of atoms.
(4) The islands consist of oyster reefs covered with a thin veneer of black mud.
(5) The beauty of the plan consists in its simplicity.
(6) The beauty of Venice consists largely in the style of its ancient buildings.
(7) Health does not consist with intemperance.
(8) The report does not consist with the fact.
column7:
(1) 聯合王國由大不列顛和北愛爾蘭組成。
(2) 棒球隊由幾名隊員組成?
(3) 物質由分子構成，而分子由原子構成。
(4) 由牡蠣礁構成的小島上覆蓋著一層薄薄的黑色軟泥。
(5) 該計劃的妙處在於簡潔明瞭。
(6) 威尼斯的美很大程度上在於它那古代建築的風格。
(7) 健康和酗酒不能相容。
(8) 那報導與事實不合。
column8: Almost always used with the preposition "of," the verb consist means to be made up of, or composed of something. A heated conversation might consist of only two words: "yes" and "no."
column9: If you're talking about something that is made up of other things, consist is your word. A molecule consists of atoms and their bonds. Consist is often used in the past tense, so you're likely to hear it used in a sentence like "the game consisted of fourteen players and one stick." But you can use it in the present tense too. Grammar consists of many, many different rules, all of which are applied differently, depending on whether you're speaking or writing. The clubs all consist of singers, and singers only. If you play an instrument, look elsewhere, bud.
column11:
1[VERB 動詞]由…組成；由…構成 Something that consists of particular things or people is formed from them.
  [V of n/-ing]

  • Breakfast consisted of porridge served with butter.

    早餐是麥片粥配佐餐黃油。

  • Her crew consisted of children from Devon and Cornwall.

    她的團隊由來自德文郡和康沃爾郡的孩子們組成。

2[VERB 動詞]在於；存在於 Something that consists in something else has that thing as its main or only part.
  [V in n/-ing]

  • His work as a consultant consisted in advising foreign companies on the siting of new factories.

    作為一名顧問，他的工作是為外國公司在新廠選址問題上提供建議。

  • ...Baudelaire's idea that genius consists in the ability to summon up childhood.

    波德萊爾認為天才在於喚起童年的能力的觀點

column5: adj.始終如一的；持續的；一致的
column6:
(1) She is a consistent girl in her feeling.
(2) Our aim is to ensure a consistent growth.
(3) Your conduct is not consistent with what you say.
column7:
(1) 在感情方面她是個始終如一的女孩。
(2) 我們的目標是確保持續的增長。
(3) 你的言行不一致。
column8: If you get the same Donkey Kong score every time you play, you're consistent. It's consistent with video-game addiction, however, that you will continue to play in the hopes of beating that score.
column9: Consistent is related to the word consist, which refers to what something is made of—"bread dough consists of flour, water, and salt." Consistency describes texture—a consistent consistency would be brownies as rock-hard in the center as they are at the edge––hopefully, next time you bake you'll get inconsistent results.
column11:
1[ADJ-GRADED 能被表示程度的副詞或介詞詞組修飾的形容詞](行為、態度等)一貫的，一致的，始終如一的 Someone who is consistent always behaves in the same way, has the same attitudes towards people or things, or achieves the same level of success in something.

  • Becker has never been the most consistent of players anyway.

    不管怎麼說，貝克爾從來就不是表現最為穩定的球員。

  • ...his consistent support of free trade.

    他對自由貿易始終如一的支持

consistently

  • It's something I have consistently denied...

    那是我自始至終否認的事。

  • Jones and Armstrong maintain a consistently high standard.

    瓊斯和阿姆斯特朗始終保持著高水準。

2[ADJ 形容詞]（觀點等）一致的，吻合的，不矛盾的 If one fact or idea is consistent with another, they do not contradict each other.
  [v-link ADJ]

  • This result is consistent with the findings of Garnett & Tobin...

    這個結果與加尼特托賓公司的調查結果一致。

  • New goals are not always consistent with the existing policies.

    新目標並不總是與現行政策一致。

3[ADJ 形容詞](觀點或看法)前後一致的，連貫的 An argument or set of ideas that is consistent is one in which no part contradicts or conflicts with any other part.

  • These are clear consistent policies which we are putting into place.

    這些就是我們正在付諸實施的政策，不但清楚而且前後一致。

column5:
vt.安慰；慰藉
n.儀表盤；操控台；(遊戲)平台；落地式支座
column6:
(1) I tried to console her, but in vain.
(2) He consoled himself with the thought that it might have been worse.
(3) He was beyond my skill to quiet or console!
(4) There are many lights and electrical instruments on the computer console.
(5) The console is just like a typewriter.
(6) This game only works with the Japan Asian Version of PlayStation 2 Console.
(7) I have a console model with a 25-inch picture tube.
column7:
(1) 我試著去安慰她，但是無效。
(2) 他聊以自慰的是幸虧事情沒有更糟。
(3) 我可沒有那個本事使他安靜下來，或者能給他慰藉！
(4) 電腦控制板上有許多小燈和電子設備。
(5) 控制台就像一台打字機。
(6) 此遊戲只僅於日本版及亞洲版的PlayStation 2遊戲主機使用。
(7) 我有一台25英吋映像管的落地式電視機。
column8: Perhaps you avoid babysitting your baby brother because you're worried that if he starts to cry, you won』t be able to console him or make him feel better. Or maybe you just hate changing diapers.
column9: You usually try to console someone by providing encouragement and offering solace. Others try to console themselves with tubs of ice cream. From the Latin word consolari, meaning 「to comfort,」 the noun console can also describe a central control panel. In an automobile, the controls for both the radio and air-conditioning are in the same center console.
column11:
The verb is pronounced /kən'səʊl/. The noun is pronounced /'kɒnsəʊl/. 動詞讀作 /kən'səʊl/，名詞讀作 /'kɒnsəʊl/。
1[VERB 動詞]安慰；慰藉；安撫 If you console someone who is unhappy about something, you try to make them feel more cheerful.
  [V with quote]
  [V n]
  [V pron-refl]
  [V pron-refl with/for n]
  [V pron-refl that]
  [Also V n with/for n]

  • 'Never mind, Ned,' he consoled me...

    「沒關係，內德。」他安慰我說。

  • Often they cry, and I have to play the role of a mother, consoling them...

    經常他們一哭，我就要充當母親的角色撫慰他們。

  • He will have to console himself by reading about the success of his compatriots...

    他只能讀讀同胞們成功的故事來安慰自己。

  • I can console myself with the fact that I'm not alone...

    不是只有我一個人才這樣，我可以用這一事實來安慰自己。

  • He consoled himself that Emmanuel looked like a nice boy, who could be a good playmate for his daughter.

    他安慰自己說，伊曼紐爾看上去是個不錯的男孩，會是女兒的好玩伴。

consoling

  • It is not a consoling thought to Germans to see that Americans have the same kind of problem, too.

    看到美國人也碰到了同樣的問題，德國人並不會感到安慰。

consolation

  • The only consolation for the Scottish theatre community is that they look likely to get another chance...

    對蘇格蘭戲劇界來說，唯一感到安慰的就是他們看來可能還有一個機會。

  • He knew then he was right, but it was no consolation.

    當時他知道自己是正確的，但這並不能給他任何安慰。

2[N-COUNT 可數名詞](機器的)操縱台，控制台，儀表板 A console is a panel with a number of switches or knobs that is used to operate a machine.

column5: v.合併；統一；鞏固
column6:
(1) The two companies consolidated last year.
(2) We will consolidate and deliver together then.
(3) He bribes his leader to consolidate his position.
column7:
(1) 這兩個公司去年合併了。
(2) 我們屆時將提前統一運輸。
(3) 他賄賂他的領導來鞏固他的地位。
column8: Consolidate means to bring together. You may feel like you don't have any pens, but if you consolidate all the pens lying around your house into one basket, you might find you in fact have a thousand.
column9: Consolidate has its roots in Latin: by combining com- (meaning "together") with solidare (meaning "to make solid"). So, when you think about consolidate, think about bringing things together to make something solid, stronger, or easier to handle. A general might consolidate his troops, a librarian might consolidate all the books about exciting women on a Women's History Month shelf, or someone with a lot of credit-card debt might try to consolidate the debt from his different cards.
column11:
1[VERB 動詞]加強；鞏固 If you consolidate something that you have, for example power or success, you strengthen it so that it becomes more effective or secure.
  [V n]

  • The question is: will the junta consolidate its power by force?...

    問題是：軍政府會通過武力鞏固其政權嗎？

  • Brydon's team-mate Martin Williamson consolidated his lead in the National League when he won the latest round.

    布賴登的隊友馬丁·威廉森在最近一輪比賽中獲勝，鞏固了自己在全國聯賽中的領先地位。

consolidation

  • But change brought about the growth and consolidation of the working class...

    但是變革使得工人階級發展壯大起來。

  • Even if not total, the Romans' hold was sufficient for them to begin the task of consolidation.

    即使沒有實現完全的控制，羅馬人的勢力也足以讓他們開始著手鞏固政權了。

2[VERB 動詞]合併；使聯合 To consolidate a number of small groups or firms means to make them into one large organization.
  [V n]

  • Judge Charles Schwartz is giving the state 60 days to disband and consolidate Louisiana's four higher education boards...

    查爾斯·施瓦茨法官將給路易斯安那州60天時間來解散然後合併該州的4個高等教育委員會。

  • IBM, which consolidated some operations last summer, has made clear that it needs to continue to streamline them.

    去年夏天合併了部分業務的IBM公司明確表示需要繼續進行精簡，以提高效率。

consolidation

  • This consolidation meant having to reduce the numerical strength of the Army...

    這次合併意味著不得不削減陸軍的兵力。

  • Further consolidations in the industry could follow.

    該產業隨後可能會有進一步的合併。

column5: adj.顯著的；顯眼的；顯而易見的
column6:
(1) Lincoln is a conspicuous example of a poor boy who succeeded.
(2) He was conspicuous for his bravery.
(3) A traffic sign should be conspicuous.
(4) Notices shall be put in conspicuous places.
(5) I found several conspicuous errors in his speech.
column7:
(1) 林肯是一個窮苦孩子而功成名就的出色例子。
(2) 他因驍勇而出名。
(3) 交通標誌應該明顯。
(4) 要保證把佈告貼在顯眼的地方。
(5) 我發現他的演講中有幾個顯而易見的錯誤。
column8: Keep your eye on the adjective conspicuous for something that stands out so much you notice it right away — like that zit in the center of your friend's forehead.
column9: Conspicuous comes from the adjectival form of the Latin verb, conspicere, meaning "to look at." Conspicuous can mean either very obvious to the eye (like something that is conspicuous from a distance) or attracting attention (like conspicuous consumption). If you are doing something wrong, it's wise not to be conspicuous about it!
column11:
1[ADJ-GRADED 能被表示程度的副詞或介詞詞組修飾的形容詞]顯眼的；引人注目的 If someone or something is conspicuous, people can see or notice them very easily.

  • The most conspicuous way in which the old politics is changing is in the growing use of referendums...

    舊式政治最明顯的變化在於其越來越多地進行全民公決。

  • You may feel tearful in situations where you feel conspicuous.

    覺得自己身處眾目睽睽之下時，你可能會有想哭的感覺。

conspicuously

  • Britain continues to follow US policy in this and other areas where American policies have most conspicuously failed...

    在美國政策分明行不通的各領域，英國卻仍舊追隨美國政策。

  • Johnston's name was conspicuously absent from the list.

    顯然，約翰斯頓的名字不在名單之上。

2[PHRASE 短語]因缺席而引人注意的 If you say that someone or something is conspicuous by their absence, you are drawing attention to the fact that they are not in a place or situation where you think they should be.

  • He played no part in the game and was conspicuous by his absence in the post-match celebrations.

    比賽時他沒有上場，並且由於沒有參加賽後的慶祝活動而引起了大家的關注。

column5: v.陰謀；協力；共謀，串通一氣
column6: (1) They conspire against the government.
column7: (1) 他們陰謀推翻政府。
column8: When you conspire, you collaborate with others to do harm, or maybe just keep something from happening, like a group that conspires to get tuna melts booted from the lunch menu by urging everyone to order other things.
column9: You can conspire with someone, meaning you team up with another person to plot against someone else, or you can conspire against someone. This means you devise a scheme to do that person harm. Conspire also can be used in a more figurative sense to describe events that cause problems, like bad weather that may conspire against your picnic plans, or a series of injuries that conspire against a basketball team struggling to make the playoffs.
column11:
1[V-RECIP 相互動詞]密謀；共謀；搞陰謀 If two or more people or groups conspire to do something illegal or harmful, they make a secret agreement to do it.
  [pl-n V to-inf]
  [V with n to-inf]
  [pl-n V against n]
  [Also V with n]

  • They'd conspired to overthrow the government...

    他們曾經密謀推翻政府。

  • Mr Farmer and Mrs Jones both admitted conspiring to murder her husband.

    法默先生和瓊斯太太都承認密謀殺死了瓊斯先生。

  • ...a defendant convicted of conspiring with his brother to commit robberies...

    被判與其兄弟合謀搶劫的被告

  • I had a persecution complex and thought people were conspiring against me.

    我有過被害情結，認為大家都在密謀暗算我。

2[VERB 動詞](事件)湊在一起致使，共同導致 If events conspire to produce a particular result, they seem to work together to cause this result.
  [V to-inf]
  [V against n]

  • History and geography have conspired to bring Greece to a moment of decision...

    歷史和地理因素共同將希臘推至作出抉擇的緊要關頭。

  • But fateful forces beyond the band's control were to conspire against them.

    然而，樂隊無力控制的各種決定性力量將會對他們造成不利的影響。

column5:
adj.不變的；經常的
n.常數；恆量
column6:
(1) The birth rate in this city is almost constant.
(2) The machinery requires constant maintenance.
(3) The constant friction between the young couple finally caused divorce.
(4) The speed of light is an important constant.
(5) The size can be set only as a constant.
(6) This quantity is called the universal gas constant.
column7:
(1) 這城市的出生率幾乎是不變的。
(2) 這些機器需要經常保養維修。
(3) 小夫妻倆之間經常的衝突終於導致了離婚。
(4) 光速是一個重要的常數。
(5) 大小只能被設置為常數。
(6) 這個量叫做普適氣體恆量。
column8: Think of something or someone that does not change as constant. A classmate's constant drumming on the table with his fingers could be a constant source of annoyance.
column9: Constant derives from Latin verb meaning "to stand with," so something constant is continually standing with you and not wavering. You may be thankful for the constant companionship of your dog but not necessarily for your teacher's constant homework assignments. In math and science, a constant is a number that is fixed and known, unlike a variable which changes with the context. That idea crosses over to real life. If a friend is a constant in your life, that means they have always been with you and there for you.
column11:
1[ADJ 形容詞]持續不斷的；重複的；一直存在的 You use constant to describe something that happens all the time or is always there.
  [usu ADJ n]

  • She suggests that women are under constant pressure to be abnormally thin...

    她暗示說女性總是處在保持身材異常瘦削的壓力之下。

  • Inflation is a constant threat...

    通貨膨脹始終是個威脅。

  • He has been her constant companion for the last four months.

    4個月來，他一直陪伴在她身邊。

constantly

  • The direction of the wind is constantly changing...

    風向不斷變化。

  • We are constantly being reminded to cut down our fat intake.

    不斷有人提醒我們要減少脂肪的攝入量。

2[ADJ-GRADED 能被表示程度的副詞或介詞詞組修飾的形容詞]恆定的；不變的 If an amount or level is constant, it stays the same over a particular period of time.

  • The average speed of the winds remained constant.

    平均風速保持穩定。

3[N-COUNT 可數名詞]恆定物；常數；常量；常項 A constant is a thing or value that always stays the same.

  • In the world of fashion it sometimes seems that the only constant is ceaseless change...

    在時裝界，有時似乎唯一永恆不變的東西就是不斷的變化。

  • Two significant constants have been found in a number of research studies.

    若干研究已經發現了兩個重要常量。

Usage Note :

You can use constant, continual, and continuous to describe things that happen or exist without stopping. You describe something as constant when it happens all the time or never goes away. He was in constant pain. ...Eva's constant criticism. Continual is usually used to describe something that happens often over a period of time, especially something undesirable. ...his continual drinking. ...continual demands to cut costs. If something is continuous, it happens all the time without stopping, or seems to do so. ...days of continuous rain. ...a continuous background noise.

constant, continual 和 continuous 均可用來描述不斷發生或一直存在的事物。constant 表示一直在發生或從未消失：He was in constant pain (他的疼痛一直沒有消停)，Eva's constant criticism (伊娃沒完沒了的批評)。continual 通常用來形容一段時期內經常發生的事，尤其是令人討厭的事：his continual drinking (他經常飲酒)，continual demands to cut costs (不斷要求削減成本)。continuous 表示一直沒有間斷，或者貌似如此：days of continuous rain (淫雨霏霏的日子)，a continuous background noise (持續不斷的背景噪音)。

column5: n.星座；星群
column6:
(1) The dragon constellation was visible in the sky.
(2) The Great Riff of the Summer Milky Way splites the constellation.
column7:
(1) 在天空中可以看到龍星座。
(2) 夏日，星群被銀河中的不發光的分子塵霧分開。
column8: When you spot the Big Dipper in the night sky, you're looking at part of the constellation called "Ursa Major." A constellation is a group of stars that form a pattern and have been given a name based on its shape.
column9: The visible night sky is divided into 88 constellations by astronomers. Organizing the stars into specific shapes and patterns helps when people study them, since they're broken down into manageable sections. A constellation can also be a cluster of things, like a constellation of freckles on your friend's nose. The stella in the middle of the word constellation means "star" in Latin, while the entire word means "set with stars."
column11:
1[N-COUNT 可數名詞]星座 A constellation is a group of stars which form a pattern and have a name.

  • ...a planet orbiting a star in the constellation of Cepheus.

    圍繞仙王座中一顆恆星旋轉的行星

2[N-COUNT 可數名詞]一群，一組(相似的事物) A constellation of similar things is a group of them.
  [with supp]
  [FORMAL 正式]

  • Most patients have a constellation of diseases, with few clear-cut distinctions between them...
