    大多數患者的病症都很相似，鮮有明顯的區別。

  • The largest gallery contains at its centre a constellation of photographs called My Wishes.

    最大的畫廊在中心位置展出了一組名為《我的心願》的攝影作品。

column5: n. n.便秘；受限制；受約束
column6: n. (1) 便秘 (2) [喻] 限制, 約束; 局促

column5: n.選區；選區的選民；支持者；主顧
column6:
(1) His constituency at South Leeds was being kept warm for him although he was able to visit once or twice a year.
(2) A constituency there trusts only sober officials.
(3) The Conservative Party is losing ground in that constituency.
(4) The magazine changed its format to appeal to a broader constituency.
column7:
(1) 儘管他一年中到南利茲選區訪問僅一到二次，但那兒的選舉區一直為他保留著。
(2) 那裡的選民只信任不貪杯的官員。
(3) 保守黨在該選區正逐漸失去支持者。
(4) 這本雜誌為了迎合更廣泛讀者的口味而改變版式。
column8: If you're an elected official, your constituency is the group of people whose interests you were elected to represent.
column9: A constituency can be described in general as the population living in a district, state, or region, but it can also be any smaller section of that population, such as individuals or small groups advocating for specific issues. Your "main constituency" usually refers to the people whose needs you feel most strongly about, or the people who are most loyal to you.
column11:
1[N-COUNT 可數名詞](選舉議員或政府代表的)選區 A constituency is an area for which someone is elected as the representative in a parliament or government.
    2[N-COUNT 可數名詞](政黨或政治家的)支持者群體，擁護者群體 A particular constituency is a section of society that may give political support to a particular party or politician.
      [usu with supp]

    • Mr Jackson had a natural constituency among American blacks...

      傑克遜先生在美國黑人中擁有自發的支持。

    • In France, farmers are a powerful political constituency.

      在法國，農場主是強有力的政黨支持群體。

column5: vt.構成；組成；任命；建立；制定
column6:
(1) Twelve months constitute one year.
(2) Correct grammar and sentence structure do not in themselves constitute good writing.
(3) The committee is constituted of members of all three parties.
(4) He was constituted representative of the party.
(5) Laws are constituted to protect individual rights and properties.
column7:
(1) 十二個月構成一年。
(2) 正確的語法和句子結構本身並不能構成一篇好文章。
(3) 委員會由所有三個政黨的成員組成。
(4) 他被任命為該黨的代表。
(5) 法律是為保衛人民的權利和財產而制定的。
column8: To constitute is to make up a whole from smaller parts, or "constituents." "What constitutes a family?" means "What makes up a family?"
column9: Parents, kids, pets, and other family members constitute most people's idea of a family. The Constitution tells us what our country is all about and supposed to be made of — in other words, what constitutes the United States. This word can deal with the present or the future. The items listed in a recipe constitute what will be in a cake; later, the individual ingredients constitute the cake. Eleven players constitute a football team on the field. We can even say that abstract qualities are constituted. For example, some people think wearing sunglasses constitutes coolness. Since everything in the world is made up of other things, there's a lot of constituting going on.
column11:
1[V-LINK 連繫動詞]被視為；可算作 If something constitutes a particular thing, it can be regarded as being that thing.
  [V n]
  [no cont]

  • Testing patients without their consent would constitute a professional and legal offence...

    未經患者同意而對其進行檢查被視為違反職業操守並觸犯法律。

  • The vote hardly constitutes a victory...

    這次投票很難被視為一次勝利。

  • What constitutes abuse?

    怎樣算是虐待？

2[V-LINK 連繫動詞]構成；組成 If a number of things or people constitute something, they are the parts or members that form it.
  [V n]
  [no cont]

  • Volunteers constitute more than 95% of The Center's work force.

    該中心95%以上的工作人員是志願者。

  • ...the four companies constituting the Aramco partnership.

    組成阿美合夥公司的4家公司

3[VERB 動詞]設立，成立(委員會、政府等) When something such as a committee or government is constituted, it is formally established and given authority to operate.
  [be V-ed]
  [V-ed]
  [usu passive]
  [FORMAL 正式]

  • On 6 July a People's Revolutionary Government was constituted...

    7月6日，人民革命政府正式成立。

  • The accused will appear before a specially constituted military tribunal.

    被告將會面臨特別軍事法庭的審判。

column5: n.憲法；組織；體質；構成，組成，構造
column6:
(1) The President swore to uphold the constitution.
(2) The country's constitution embodies the ideals of freedom and equality.
(3) The constitution of a primitive society is not necessarily simple.
(4) Hunger and disease had weakened his constitution.
(5) He has a good constitution.
column7:
(1) 總統宣誓維護憲法。
(2) 這個國家的憲法體現了自由和平等的理想。
(3) 原始社會的結構並不一定就是簡單的。
(4) 他飢餓與疾病交加，體質已削弱。
(5) 他體質很好。
column8: A constitution is a statement of the basic principles and laws of a nation, state, or group, such as the U.S. Constitution. Another very common meaning of constitution is the physical makeup of a person.
column9: The noun constitution is from Latin, from constitutus "set up, established" plus the suffix -ion- "act, state, or condition." So think of a constitution as how a body (yours, the government's) is set up. If you have a strong constitution, it means you don't get sick very often.
column11:
1[N-COUNT 可數名詞](一國的)憲法；(組織的)章程 The constitution of a country or organization is the system of laws which formally states people's rights and duties.

  • The king was forced to adopt a new constitution which reduced his powers.

    國王被迫採用了削弱其權力的新憲法。

  • ...the American Constitution...

    《美國憲法》

  • The club's constitution prevented women from becoming full members.

    這個俱樂部的章程不允許女性成為正式會員。

2[N-COUNT 可數名詞]體質；體格 Your constitution is your health.
  [usu sing]

  • He must have an extremely strong constitution...

    他的體格必定極其強壯。

  • I've always had the constitution of an ox.

    我一向體壯如牛。

column5:
n.約束；強制；約束條件；對感情的壓抑；虛情假意
[計算機] 限制.
column6:
(1) There have been financial and political constraints on development.
(2) The country decides to reduce constraints on imports.
(3) I was aware of a certain constraint on their part when they were in my presence.
column7:
(1) 發展過程中會遇到財政和政治的約束。
(2) 這個國家決定減少對進口物品的限制。
(3) 我覺察到我在時他們有些拘束。
column8: A constraint is a limit or restriction. Hopefully your school won't cut the sports or music programs due to budget constraints!
column9: You might notice that constraint is similar to the verb constrict, as in boa constrictor. A constraint tightens around you like a snake and prevents you from doing what you want. Financial constraints prevent you from buying the latest electronic device. Are you tired of living under the constraint of your parents' rules? Sometimes your worries or feelings act as a constraint. You know that someone has become a close friend when you can talk to them without constraint.
column11:
1[N-COUNT 可數名詞]限制；束縛；約束 A constraint is something that limits or controls what you can do.
  [oft adj N]

  • Their decision to abandon the trip was made because of financial constraints...

    他們決定放棄這次出遊是因為財力有限。

  • Water shortages in the area will be the main constraint on development.

    水資源匱乏將是制約該地區發展的一個主要因素。

2[N-UNCOUNT 不可數名詞]克制 Constraint is control over the way you behave which prevents you from doing what you want to do.

column5: v.壓縮；束緊；使收縮
column6:
(1) Doesn't that tight bracelet constrict your arm?
(2) Don't constrict your hair with tight hair bands and hats.
(3) Panic can constrict the blood vessels and impose an additional burden on the heart.
(4) Nerves constrict the blood vessels in the extremities of the body.
column7:
(1) 那個手鐲那麼緊不會壓迫你的手臂嗎?
(2) 不要用緊繃繃的皮筋或帽子來固定頭髮。
(3) 恐慌會使血管收縮，增加心臟負擔。
(4) 神經促使人手腳處的血管開始收縮。
column8: To constrict is to squeeze uncomfortably. If your new turtleneck sweater constricts your neck, the sweater is probably too small.
column9: When things constrict, they become narrow or make something else become narrow. A boa constrictor kills its prey when it constricts the animal's body until it can no longer breathe, and a necktie that's tied too tightly constricts your neck. In medicine, certain conditions or medications can constrict openings such as airways or blood vessels, sometimes dangerously. The Latin root is constringere, "to bind together or tie tightly."
column11:
1[V-ERG 及物/不及物動詞](使)(身體部位，尤指喉嚨)收緊，收縮 If a part of your body, especially your throat, is constricted or if it constricts, something causes it to become narrower.
  [V n]
  [V]

  • Severe migraine can be treated with a drug which constricts the blood vessels...

    嚴重的偏頭疼可以用一種收縮血管的藥物進行治療。

  • My throat constricted, so that I had to concentrate on breathing.

    我的嗓子發緊，所以我不得不把注意力集中在呼吸上。

constricted

  • His throat began to feel swollen and constricted.

    他開始覺得喉嚨腫脹發緊。

constriction

  • The pain is produced by constriction of the blood vessels.

    這種疼痛是由於血管的收縮而引起的。

2[VERB 動詞]限制；束縛；約束 If something constricts you, it limits your actions so that you cannot do what you want to do.
  [V n]

  • She objects to the tests the Government's advisers have devised because they constrict her teaching style...

    她反對政府顧問設計的考試，因為這些考試限制了她的教學風格。

  • Men and women alike have been constricted by traditional sexual roles.

    男性和女性同樣受到傳統性別角色的束縛。

constricted

  • Many of the women I spoke to left because they felt constricted.

    和我聊過的很多女性因為覺得受拘束離開了。

constricting

  • I find the office environment too rigid and constricting...

    我覺得辦公室的環境太死板，限制太多。

  • The bill is filled with constricting amendments.

    該法案具有很多限制性修正條款。

constriction

  • A general anxiousness developed and increased, leading to a constriction of her normal activities.

    一種普遍的焦慮情緒滋生出來並且不斷加劇，導致她正常的活動都束手束腳。

column5:
n.接觸；聯繫；熟人
v.(與)聯繫；(與)接觸
adj.接觸的
column6:
(1) The rich secluded themselves from contact with the poor.
(2) I finally made contact with her in Paris.
(3) She has a contact in the software industry.
(4) Our patrols on all our fronts contacted no enemy today.
(5) She suffers from a contact skin rash.
column7:
(1) 富人不肯同窮人接觸。
(2) 我終於在巴黎同她取得了聯繫。
(3) 她在軟件行業有個熟人。
(4) 今天我方在各條戰線上的巡邏隊均未遭遇敵人。
(5) 她患上了一種接觸傳染性皮疹。
column8: Contact is the act of touching or communicating with someone or something else. The question increasingly isn't whether there is other life in the universe, but how on earth we will ever make contact with it.
column9: To make contact (the noun) means to establish some form of communication, be it physical, verbal, or some other kind. To contact (the verb) means to establish that communication. If you're looking to contact Madonna, good luck. She's got people whose only job it is to prevent folks like you from making contact with her. Batteries have two contacts, one positive and one negative. They are where the battery makes contact with the thing to which it provides power.
column11:
1[N-UNCOUNT 不可數名詞](尤指經常性的)聯繫，聯絡 Contact involves meeting or communicating with someone, especially regularly.
  [also N in pl]

  • Opposition leaders are denying any contact with the government in Kabul...

    反對派領袖否認與喀布爾政府有任何聯繫。

  • He forbade contacts between directors and executives outside his presence.

    他禁止董事與管理層繞開他私下進行任何聯繫。

2[PHRASE 短語]保持聯繫；有聯繫 If you are in contact with someone, you regularly meet them or communicate with them.
  [usu v-link PHR]

  • He was in direct contact with the kidnappers...

    他與綁架者有直接聯繫。

  • We do keep in contact.

    我們確實保持著聯繫。

3[VERB 動詞]聯繫；聯絡 If you contact someone, you telephone them, write to them, or go to see them in order to tell or ask them something.
  [V n]

  • Contact the Tourist Information Bureau for further details...

    詳情請洽旅遊信息處。

  • When she first contacted me Frances was upset.

    弗朗西絲第一次與我聯繫時很心煩意亂。

4[ADJ 形容詞](信息、電話號碼等)供聯繫的，供聯絡的 Your contact details or number are information such as a telephone number where you can be contacted.
  [ADJ n]

  • You must leave your full name and contact details when you phone.

    打電話時須留下全名與聯絡信息。

5[N-UNCOUNT 不可數名詞]接觸；遇見 If you come into contact with someone or something, you meet that person or thing in the course of your work or other activities.
  [into N with n]

  • Doctors I came into contact with voiced their concern...

    我接觸到的醫生都表示了他們的擔心。

  • The college has brought me into contact with western ideas.

    上大學使我接觸了西方的思想。

6[PHR-RECIP 相互短語]與…聯絡；和…取得聯繫 If you make contact with someone, you find out where they are and talk or write to them.
  [V inflects]

  • Then, after she had become famous, he tried to make contact with her.

    後來，她出名之後，他曾試圖與她聯繫。

7[PHR-RECIP 相互短語]與…失去聯繫；與…斷了聯繫 If you lose contact with someone who you have been friendly with, you no longer see them, speak to them, or write to them.
  [V inflects]

  • Though they all live nearby, I lost contact with them really quickly...

    雖然他們都住在附近，但我很快與他們失去了聯繫。

  • Mother and son lost contact when Nicholas was in his early twenties.

    尼古拉斯20歲出頭的時候母子就失去了聯繫。

8[N-UNCOUNT 不可數名詞]觸碰；接觸 When people or things are in contact, they are touching each other.
  [oft in/into N with n]

  • They compared how these organisms behaved when left in contact with different materials...

    他們比較了與不同材料接觸時這些生物體的反應。

  • The cry occurs when air is brought into contact with the baby's larynx...

    嬰兒的喉嚨接觸到空氣時，就會哭出來。

  • There was no physical contact, nor did I want any...

    沒有身體接觸，我也不想有任何接觸。

  • This shows where the foot and shoe are in contact.

    這顯示了腳和鞋接觸的地方。

9[N-UNCOUNT 不可數名詞](無線電)聯絡，通信 Radio contact is communication by means of radio.

  • He failed to make radio contact.

    他未能進行無線電聯絡。

  • ...a technical problem reported by the pilot moments before he lost contact with the control tower.

    飛行員與控制塔失去聯絡前不久報告的技術故障

10[N-COUNT 可數名詞]熟人；有用的社會關係 A contact is someone you know in an organization or profession who helps you or gives you information.

  • Their contact in the United States Embassy was called Phil.

    他們在美國大使館的熟人叫菲爾。

11
to make eye contact→see: eye；

column5: adj.傳染性的；感染性的
column6:
(1) Scarlet fever is highly contagious.
(2) Have you ever had any contagious disease?
(3) He has contagious laughter.
(4) Nothing is so contagious as enthusiasm.
column7:
(1) 猩紅熱傳染性很強。
(2) 你是否有或曾經有過傳染疾病?
(3) 他有著容易感染人的笑聲。
(4) 熱情是最富有感染力的。
column8: You should probably postpone dinner if your date's cold is contagious — that means it's easily spread and likely to get you sick.
column9: Contagious actually evolved from contagio, the Latin phrase for 「contact." Those smart ancient Romans — they figured out that the sick and contagious can pass on their plague to those they touch or get close to. So the word contagious usually sends people running. But let』s not forget that a smile or good deed can be just as infectious as a cough!
column11:
1[ADJ-GRADED 能被表示程度的副詞或介詞詞組修飾的形容詞]（病）接觸傳染的 A disease that is contagious can be caught by touching people or things that are infected with it.

  • ...a highly contagious disease of the lungs.

    極具傳染性的肺病

2[ADJ-GRADED 能被表示程度的副詞或介詞詞組修飾的形容詞](感情、態度等)感染性的，會迅速蔓延開的 A feeling or attitude that is contagious spreads quickly among a group of people.
  [usu v-link ADJ]

  • Laughing is contagious...

    笑是有感染力的。

  • Antonio has a contagious enthusiasm for the beautiful aspect of food.

    安東尼奧對食品賞心悅目這一方面的熱情非常有感染性。

column5: vt.弄髒；污染
column6:
(1) All over the world, oil spills regularly contaminate coasts.
(2) They are contaminating the minds of our young people with these subversive ideas.
column7:
(1) 在世界各地，油溢出物經常污染著海岸。
(2) 他們這些顛覆性的思想是對我們年輕人的精神污染。
column8: The verb contaminate means the same as pollute. Whether it』s food, air, or water, when you contaminate something, you make it impure or hazardous.
column9: Contaminate comes from the Latin word contaminat-, meaning 「made impure.」 You can use the word to indicate that a hazardous substance has been introduced into something else, such as food that is contaminated with mold. It can also be used figuratively to describe the spoiling of a good thing, like one person's habit of gossiping that can contaminate a conversation among friends.
column11:
1[VERB 動詞]污染；弄髒 If something is contaminated by dirt, chemicals, or radiation, they make it dirty or harmful.
  [be V-ed]
  [V-ed]
  [Also V n]

  • Have any fish been contaminated in the Arctic Ocean?

    北冰洋的魚受到過污染嗎？

  • ...vast tracts of empty land, much of it contaminated by years of army activity.

    大片撂荒的土地，其中大部分由於經年累月的戰火而受到了污染

contaminated

  • Nuclear weapons plants across the country are heavily contaminated with toxic wastes...

    全國的核武器工廠均受到了有毒廢棄物的嚴重污染。

  • More than 100,000 people could fall ill after drinking contaminated water.

    超過10萬人可能會在飲用受到污染的水後患病。

contamination

  • The contamination of the sea around Capri may be just the beginning.

    卡普裡島附近海域的污染也許僅僅是個開始。

column5: vt.注視；沉思；打算
column6:
(1) It terrified me to contemplate the consequence of your action.
(2) The doctor contemplated the difficult operation he had to perform.
(3) We contemplate obtaining a technical license.
(4) He contemplates visiting Beijing.
column7:
(1) 一想到你行動的後果,我就感到害怕。
(2) 醫生細想他要進行的棘手的手術。
(3) 我們希望獲得一項技術許可證。
(4) 他打算訪問北京。
column8: Before you accept a job offer, or a college's offer of admission, you should take time to contemplate the pros and cons of your decision. If you contemplate something, you think about it carefully.
column9: Contemplate is from Latin contemplatus, past participle of contemplari "to gaze attentively, observe," from the prefix com- "together" plus templum "temple." The original meaning of Latin contemplari was "to mark out a space for observing auguries or omens," and the temple was a holy space reserved for this purpose.
column11:
1[VERB 動詞]考慮；思量；思忖 If you contemplate an action, you think about whether to do it or not.
  [V n/-ing]

  • For a time he contemplated a career as an army medical doctor...

    有段時間，他考慮去當軍醫。

  • She contemplates leaving for the sake of the kids.

    她考慮為了孩子而離開。

2[VERB 動詞]深思熟慮；沉思；苦思冥想 If you contemplate an idea or subject, you think about it carefully for a long time.
  [V n]

  • As he lay in his hospital bed that night, he cried as he contemplated his future...

    那天晚上，他躺在醫院的病床上，想到未來，他哭了起來。

  • That makes it difficult to contemplate the idea that the present policy may not be sustainable.

    那讓人難以認真思考這個可能，即目前的政策也許並不能持續下去。

contemplation

  • It is a place of quiet contemplation.

    這是個靜心冥想的好地方。

3[VERB 動詞]凝視；注視 If you contemplate something or someone, you look at them for a long time.
  [V n]

  • He contemplated his hands, still frowning.

    他盯著自己的雙手，眉頭緊鎖。

contemplation

  • He was lost in the contemplation of the landscape for a while.

    有一會兒，他怔怔地注視著周圍的景物。

column5:
adj.同時代的；當代的
n.同時代的人；同齡人
column6:
(1) Marlowe was contemporary with Shakespeare.
(2) He had devoted his whole life to the study of contemporary art.
(3) Thackeray is a contemporary of Dickens.
(4) She and I were contemporaries at college.
(5) He is a contemporary of mine, but our experiences are completely different.
column7:
(1) 馬洛與莎士比亞是同時代的。
(2) 他把他的一生都獻給了當代藝術研究。
(3) 薩克萊跟狄更斯是同時期的人。
(4) 她和我在學院裡是同學。
(5) 他和我是同齡人，但我們的經歷截然不同。
column8: Things that are contemporary are either happening at the same time or happening now. Contemporary art is recent art.
column9: In history class, if you hear that one famous person was a contemporary of another, that means they lived at the same time. Contemporaries are people and things from the same time period. Contemporary can also describe things happening now or recently. It's common to speak of contemporary music or contemporary furniture, for example. Those things are new, not old. Anything characteristic of the present day can be called contemporary.
column11:
1[ADJ-GRADED 能被表示程度的副詞或介詞詞組修飾的形容詞]當代的；現代的 Contemporary things are modern and relate to the present time.
  [usu ADJ n]

  • She writes a lot of contemporary music for people like Whitney Houston...

    她給像惠特尼·休斯敦這樣的人寫了很多當代音樂作品。

  • Perhaps he should have a more updated look, a more contemporary style...

    也許他應該有一個更新的形象，更具時代性的風格。

  • Only the names are ancient； the characters are modern and contemporary.

    只有姓名是古代的； 人物都是現代的、摩登的。

2[ADJ 形容詞]同時發生的；同時期的；同時代的 Contemporary people or things were alive or happened at the same time as something else you are talking about.
  [usu ADJ n]

  • ...drawing upon official records and the reports of contemporary witnesses.

    利用官方的記錄與當時的見證者的報告

3[N-COUNT 可數名詞]同時期的人；同時代的人 Someone's contemporary is a person who is or was alive at the same time as them.
  [usu pl]

  • Like most of my contemporaries, I grew up in a vastly different world.

    和大多數同輩人一樣，我生長在一個截然不同的世界。

  • ...a glossary of musical terms found in Shakespeare and his contemporaries.

    莎士比亞及其同時代人音樂術語彙編

column5: n.輕視；輕蔑
column6:
(1) Her gesture was indicative of contempt.
(2) Such behaviour is beneath contempt.
(3) They showed nothing but contempt for him.
(4) Her behavior underlined her contempt for him.
column7:
(1) 她的動作表示輕視。
(2) 這種行為令人不齒。
(3) 他們對他輕蔑已極。
(4) 她的態度清楚地表示了對他的輕蔑。
column8: Reserve the noun contempt for an extreme lack of respect: a food snob has nothing but contempt for mass-produced burgers and fries at a fast-food joint.
column9: Contempt has nothing to do with the verb condemn, despite the similarity in sound and meaning; it is from Latin temnere "to despise," and if you despise someone, you have contempt for them. It's a harsh term and should be used with care; it's stronger than either disdain or scorn. It suggests you find someone or something utterly worthless. That food snob might say the words "Big Mac" or "Whopper" with a voice dripping in contempt.
column11:
1[N-UNCOUNT 不可數名詞]鄙視；蔑視；輕視 If you have contempt for someone or something, you have no respect for them or think that they are unimportant.
  [oft N for n]

  • He has contempt for those beyond his immediate family circle...

    他鄙視直系親屬圈子以外的人。

  • I hope voters will treat his advice with the contempt it deserves.

    我希望選民們給予其建議應有的鄙視。

2[N-UNCOUNT 不可數名詞]同 contempt of court Contempt means the same as contempt of court .
  [LEGAL 法律]

  • Mr. Kelly was sentenced to six months in prison for contempt.

    凱利先生因藐視法庭被判6個月監禁。

3[PHRASE 短語]鄙視；蔑視；輕視 If you hold someone or something in contempt, you feel contempt for them. familiarity breeds contempt→see: familiarity；
  [V inflects]

  • Small wonder that many voters hold their politicians in contempt.

    無怪乎很多選民看不起他們的政治家。

column5: v.競爭；爭鬥；爭辯；堅決主張
column6:
(1) Three armed groups were contending for power.
(2) John has to contend with great difficulties.
(3) They have to contend against drought every year.
(4) But the potential is simply too significant, the experts contend.
column7:
(1) 三個武裝集團在爭奪權力。
(2) 約翰得與那些艱難困苦作鬥爭。
(3) 他們每年都得與乾旱做鬥爭。
(4) 但是專家們主張，潛力是非常重要的。
column8: To defend a belief or keep affirming that it's true is to contend. A lot of supporters would contend that the earth was flat, but eventually, when no one dropped off the edge no matter how far they traveled, the "round" theory won.
column9: One of the meanings of contend is from the French "to strive with," and it is a literal fighting, as in "to contend with fists." Most contemporary uses of the verb contend illustrate competitions of proof or defense, where a person will contend that something is true, or better, or wrong. It is still a striving but more of a verbal kind, where what you contend is what you hope to convince others is correct.
column11:
1[VERB 動詞]處理；對付；解決 If you have to contend with a problem or difficulty, you have to deal with it or overcome it.
  [V with n]

  • It is time, once again, to contend with racism...

    又一次到了與種族主義戰鬥的時刻了。

  • American businesses could soon have a new kind of lawsuit to contend with.

    美國公司可能很快就要有一種新型的官司去應付了。

2[VERB 動詞]聲稱；爭辯；主張 If you contend that something is true, you state or argue that it is true.
  [V that]
  [V with quote]
  [FORMAL 正式]

  • The government contends that he is fundamentalist...

    政府認定他是原教旨主義者。

  • 'You were just looking,' contends Samantha. 'I was the one doing all the work.'

    「你不過是看看而已。」薩曼莎爭辯道，「什麼活兒都是我來幹。」

3[V-RECIP 相互動詞]競爭；爭奪 If you contend with someone for something such as power, you compete with them to try to get it.
  [pl-n V for n]
  [V with n]
  [V-ing]

  • ...the two main groups contending for power.

    兩大集團爭權奪利

  • ...with 10 UK construction yards contending with rivals from Norway, Holland, Italy and Spain.

    10家英國建造廠與來自挪威、荷蘭、意大利和西班牙的對手展開競爭

  • ...a binding political settlement between the contending parties.

    角力各派間一項具有約束力的政治協議

column5: n.爭論；爭辯；爭奪；論點
column6:
(1) This is an issue of great contention at the moment.
(2) The subject deserves contention.
(3) The judge balanced the contention of both parties .
(4) Three players are in contention to win the title.
(5) My contention is that the government's plan would never have been successful whatever had happened.
column7:
(1) 眼下這個問題是爭論的熱點。
(2) 這個問題值得爭論。
(3) 法官權衡了雙方的爭辯。
(4) 三個運動員在爭奪這個項目的冠軍。
(5) 我的論點是無論發生什麼事情，政府的計劃都不會成功。
column8: There is nothing "content," or satisfying, about being in contention, and that's probably because the word contention means being in a competition that ends with one side, usually the winning one, being content.
column9: And in this corner, the contender is heard at most boxing matches to describe each of the fighters about to go into contention in the ring. Sometimes, though, a contention can be a battle of words or a struggle between two parties over a single point. The expression "bone of contention" describes a narrow object of disagreement that reaches the level of strife, or contention. For two hungry dogs, though, the bone of contention might be a serious matter.
column11:
1[N-COUNT 可數名詞](爭論或討論時的)看法，觀點 Someone's contention is the idea or opinion that they are expressing in an argument or discussion.
  [usu poss N]

  • This evidence supports their contention that the outbreak of violence was prearranged.

    這一證據證實了他們的觀點，即此次突發暴力事件是有預謀的。

  • Sufficient research evidence exists to support this contention.

    有足夠的調查證據支持這個觀點。

2[N-UNCOUNT 不可數名詞]See also:bone of contention；不和；爭吵；爭執 If something is a cause of contention, it is a cause of disagreement or argument.
  [usu n of N]

  • They generally tried to avoid subjects of contention between them...

    他們一般都盡量避免會引起彼此不和的話題。

  • A particular source of contention is plans to privatise state-run companies.

    發生爭執的一個根源就是國營公司的私有化方案。

3[PHRASE 短語]有機會獲勝 If you are in contention in a contest, you have a chance of winning it.
  [v-link PHR]

  • He was in contention for a place in the European championship squad.

    他有望在歐洲錦標賽代表隊中獲得一席之地。

column5:
n.競賽；比賽
vt.駁斥；爭取
vi.奮鬥
column6:
(1) She won a gold medal for her fine performance in the contest.
(2) This football match is an unequal contest.
(3) Janet said she is thinking about attending a KTV contest.
(4) We would hotly contest this idea.
(5) The soldiers contested every inch of ground.
column7:
(1) 她在競賽中成績優異獲金牌。
(2) 這場足球賽是一場實力懸殊的比賽。
(3) 珍妮說她正考慮參加一個KTV歌唱比賽。
(4) 我們猛烈地批駁這一觀點。
(5) 士兵們為爭奪每一寸土地而鬥爭。
column8: A contest is a struggle to determine who's tops –- you might wrestle an alligator in a contest of brute strength versus strategy. You can also enter a contest — a yodeling contest or a cake-decorating contest, depending on your talents.
column9: If you're being sued and you respond to the court order saying "no contest," you're saying you're not going to put up a fight. When you put the accent on the second syllable, contest becomes a verb, and it means to dispute something. You lost the election for class president, but you think there was something fishy going on at the ballot box, so you contest the results and ask for a recount.
column11:
The noun is pronounced /'kɒntest/. The verb is pronounced /kən'test/. 名詞讀作 /'kɒntest/，動詞讀作 /kən'test/。
1[N-COUNT 可數名詞]See also:beauty contest；競賽；比賽 A contest is a competition or game in which people try to win.

  • Few contests in the recent history of British boxing have been as thrilling.

    英國近年的拳擊比賽中很少有如此激動人心的。

  • ...a writing contest.

    寫作比賽

2[N-COUNT 可數名詞](權力或控制權的)爭奪，競爭 A contest is a struggle to win power or control.

  • The state election due in November will be the last such ballot before next year's presidential contest...

    定於11月舉行的州選舉將是明年總統競選前最後一次此類投票選舉。

  • ...a clear contest between church and state.

    教會與政府之間明顯的爭鬥

3[VERB 動詞]爭取贏得(選舉、比賽等)；角逐 If someone contests an election or competition, they take part in it and try to win it.
  [V n]
  [V-ed]
  [mainly BRIT 主英]

  • He quickly won his party's nomination to contest the elections.

    他很快獲得了本黨提名，角逐大選。

  • ...a closely contested regional flower show.

    各方爭奇鬥艷、難分高下的地區花卉展

4[VERB 動詞]爭辯；對…提出異議 If you contest a statement or decision, you object to it formally because you think it is wrong or unreasonable.
  [V n]
  [V-ed]

  • Your former employer has to reply within 14 days in order to contest the case...

    你的前任僱主若對本案存有異議，必須在14天內予以答覆。

  • Gender discrimination is a hotly contested issue.

    性別歧視是一個爭論激烈的話題。

column5: n.上下文；環境；背景
column6:
(1) It is usually easier to pick out the meaning of a phrase in a given context.
(2) In the context of the present economic crisis it seems unwise to lower taxes.
(3) This speech needs to be set in the context of Britain in the 1960s.
column7:
(1) 在特定的上下文中理解一個短語的含意往往要更容易些。
(2) 鑒於當前的經濟危機，降低稅率似乎不妥。
(3) 這篇演說需要放到20世紀60年代的英國這一背景之下來看待。
column8: Context means the setting of a word or event. If your friend is furious at you for calling her your worst enemy, remind her that the context of those remarks was Opposite Day.
column9: Context comes from the Latin for how something is made. It was first used to talk about writing, as in "the beautiful phrase occurs in the context of the concluding paragraph." We use it now to talk about any circumstance in which something happens. You might say that you can't understand what happens without looking at the context. When someone takes your words but makes it sound like you meant something else, they've taken your words out of context.
column11:
1[N-VAR 可變名詞](想法、事件等的)背景，環境 The context of an idea or event is the general situation that relates to it, and which helps it to be understood.
  [usu with supp]

  • We are doing this work in the context of reforms in the economic, social and cultural spheres.

    我們是在對經濟、社會、文化諸領域進行改革的背景下從事這項工作的。

  • ...the historical context in which Chaucer wrote...

    喬叟寫作的歷史背景

  • This is the context in which President Chirac must decide his policy.

    這是希拉克總統必須確定其政策的背景。

2[N-VAR 可變名詞]上下文；語境 The context of a word, sentence, or text consists of the words, sentences, or text before and after it which help to make its meaning clear.

  • Without a context, I would have assumed it was written by a man.

    如果沒有上下文，我會以為這是出自一名男子筆下。

3[PHRASE 短語]在上下文中；置於背景之下 If something is seen in context or if it is put into context, it is considered together with all the factors that relate to it.

  • Taxation is not popular in principle, merely acceptable in context...

    徵稅基本上是不受歡迎的，在一定情境中才勉強為人接受。

  • It is important that we put Jesus into the context of history.

    我們將耶穌置於歷史環境中來看是很重要的。

4[PHRASE 短語]脫離上下文；斷章取義地 If a statement or remark is quoted out of context, the circumstances in which it was said are not correctly reported, so that it seems to mean something different from the meaning that was intended.

  • Thomas says that he has been taken out of context on the issue...

    托馬斯說，在這個問題上他的話被斷章取義了。

  • Quotes can be manipulated and used out of context.

    引語可能會被篡改，使用時斷章取義。

column5: adj.鄰近的；連續的；接觸的
column6:
(1) California and Mexico are contiguous.
(2) They are two immediately contiguous areas.
(3) California and Mexico are contiguous.
column7:
(1) 加利福尼亞和墨西哥相鄰。
(2) 他們是緊密接鄰的地區。
(3) 加利福尼亞和墨西哥相鄰。
column8: Use the adjective contiguous when you want to describe one thing touching another thing, or next to it but not actually touching.
column9: Things that are contiguous are near or next to but not actually touching and yet they are also defined as "touching, sharing a border." You can use this adjective to describe people or things related to and nearby others. It comes from the Latin word contiguus, which means pretty much the same thing, "bordering upon." Because the word has two meanings that are very similar but not always the same it can be a bit confusing. This is an example of what's called "semantic ambiguity," when something can mean more than one thing or a word or phrase is not precise.
column11:
1[ADJ 形容詞]相接的；相鄰的 Things that are contiguous are next to each other or touch each other.
  [oft ADJ to/with n]
  [FORMAL 正式]

  • Its vineyards are virtually contiguous with those of Ausone.

    其葡萄園差不多緊挨著歐頌堡的葡萄園。

  • ...two years of travel throughout the 48 contiguous states.

    兩年遊遍美國本土的48州

column5: n. 洲(指歐、亞、非、南北美、澳、南極洲之一), 大陸
column6: the maritime zone is richer in varieties of plant than the continent.
column7: 海域植物品種比大陸豐富

column5: n.大陸；洲；(the Continent)歐洲大陸
column6:
(1) The discovery of the new continent is usually referred to Columbus.
(2) There are seven continents in the world.
(3) Asia is the largest continent on Earth.
(4) Many people embark at Dover for the Continent.
column7:
(1) 人們通常認為新大陸是哥倫布發現的。
(2) 世界上有七大洲。
(3) 亞洲是地球上最大的洲。
(4) 許多前往歐洲大陸的人都在多佛搭船。
column8: A continent is one of the seven largest landmasses found on Earth. Asia, Australia, and Africa are three continents. Can you name the other four?
column9: Some folks forget the continent of Antarctica, because so few humans live there—none of them permanently. And you might be surprised how many people think that Africa is a country and not a continent. Due to a process known as continental drift, the extremely slow movement of the continents across the face of the globe, our world looks very different from the way it did 100 million years ago.
column11:
1[N-COUNT 可數名詞]大陸；洲 A continent is a very large area of land, such as Africa or Asia, that consists of several countries.

  • She loved the African continent...

    她熱愛非洲大陸。

  • Dinosaurs evolved when most continents were joined in a single land mass.

    恐龍進化的時候，多數大陸連為一體。

2[N-PROPER 專有名詞](指英國之外的)歐洲大陸 People sometimes use the Continent to refer to the continent of Europe except for Britain.
  [the N]
  [mainly BRIT 主英]

  • Its shops are among the most stylish on the Continent.

    其店舖躋身歐陸最時尚的店舖之列。

column5:
n.周線；輪廓；等高線；概要；電路
vt.畫輪廓(畫等高線)
adj.顯示輪廓的
column6:
(1) The set of edges which bound the region is the contour of the region.
(2) The contour of that mountain looks like a dragon.
(3) The smooth contour of the sculpture is wonderful.
(4) The figure shows a part of a contour map.
(5) Please show me the contour map.
column7:
(1) 包圍某區域的邊的集合稱為區域的周線。
(2) 那座大山的輪廓看上去像一條龍。
(3) 雕塑物平滑的輪廓線簡直太美了。
(4) 附圖是一幅等高線地圖的一部分。
(5) 請把等高線地圖給我看看。
column8: Contour is the outline or shape of something. A shoe that fits well along the contours or shape of your foot is a good fit.
column9: Contour comes from the Italian contorno meaning "to draw a line," which is precisely what you are doing when you trace the contour of something. A road that contours a mountain follows along its edge and a mattress that contours to your body, adjusts to your shape. You might buy the kind of shoes that are designed to contour or mold to the shape of your feet over time, in which case you'll have to break them in.
column11:
1[N-COUNT 可數名詞]輪廓；外形 You can refer to the general shape or outline of an object as its contours .
  [usu pl]
  [LITERARY 文]

  • ...the texture and colour of the skin, the contours of the body...

    皮膚的肌理和顏色，身體的輪廓

  • I cradled my video camera nervously on my lap, but its cold contours did nothing to comfort me.

    我緊張地把攝影機架在大腿上，但是它冰冷的外形並沒能給我任何安慰。

2[N-COUNT 可數名詞](地圖上的)等高線 A contour on a map is a line joining points of equal height and indicating hills, valleys, and the steepness of slopes.

  • There were three moderate climbs to just below the 450 feet contour.

    剛好在450英尺的等高線之下有3個緩坡。

  • ...a contour map showing two hills and this large mountain in the middle.

    標示著兩座小山和中間這座大山的等高線地圖

column5:
adj.禁運的
n.走私貨
網絡:禁運品；違禁品；走私品
column6:
(1) What kind'a contraband you hiding in there, boy?
(2) The seizure of contraband is made by customs.
(3) Actually, I'm not quite sure what's contraband.
column7:
(1) 你在那兒藏了什麼違禁品，小子？
(2) 那些走私品是被海關沒收的。
(3) 實際上我不大清楚什麼是違禁物品。

column5:
n.合同；婚約；合約；契約
v.縮小；訂合同；縮短；感染（疾病）；招致
column6:
(1) They had set a term to the contract.
(2) Families sought favourable alliances, either by marriage or contract.
(3) Several companies will bid for the contract.
(4) He managed to disengage himself from the contract.
(5) The heat contracted the woollen garment.
(6) It's an urgent business, we have no time for unnecessary consideration—please contract your inspection period!
(7) She has contracted a severe fever.
(8) He has contracted the habit of talking to himself.
column7:
(1) 他們已給合同定了期限。
(2) 各個家庭通過婚姻或者婚約來建立有力的親緣關係。
(3) 數家公司要投標爭取合約。
(4) 他成功地為自己解除了契約義務。
(5) 高溫讓羊毛衣縮小了。
(6) 這是個緊急時間,我們沒時間做多餘的考慮了——請縮短你的審查期！
(7) 她感染上了嚴重的熱病。
(8) 他養成了自言自語的習慣。
column8: When you and someone else have agreed on something and that agreement is both binding and enforceable by law, you have a contract. When you rent an apartment, you and your future landlord sign a rental contract.
column9: You can also use the word in this sense as a verb meaning "to hire." Wouldn't you like to contract someone to clean your room for you? In other verbal uses of contract, place the accent on the second syllable — kun-TRAKT. If you contract a disease, you catch it, but only use this if it's something serious. You catch a cold, but contract malaria. Contract also means "shrink." When the economy contracts, consumers stop buying things, and people lose their jobs, and if you freeze water, it contracts too.
column11:
The noun is pronounced /'kɒntrakt/. The verb is pronounced /kən'trakt/. 名詞讀作 /'kɒntrakt/，動詞讀作 /kən'trakt/。
1[N-COUNT 可數名詞]合同；契約 A contract is a legal agreement, usually between two companies or between an employer and employee, which involves doing work for a stated sum of money.

  • The company won a prestigious contract for work on Europe's tallest building...

    這家公司贏得了一份極為重要的合同，參與建設歐洲最高的大廈。

  • He was given a seven-year contract with an annual salary of $150,000.

    他簽下了一份為期7年的合同，年薪為15萬美元。

2[VERB 動詞]簽合同，訂立契約(做某事) If you contract with someone to do something, you legally agree to do it for them or for them to do it for you.
  [V with n to-inf]
  [V to-inf]
  [FORMAL 正式]

  • You can contract with us to deliver your cargo...

    你可以跟我們簽訂送貨合同。

  • The Boston Museum of Fine Arts has already contracted to lease part of its collection to a museum in Japan.

    波士頓美術博物館已經簽訂合同，將其部分藏品租借給日本一家博物館。

3[V-ERG 及物/不及物動詞](使)收縮；(使)縮小；(使)縮短 When something contracts or when something contracts it, it becomes smaller or shorter.
  [V]
  [V n]

  • Blood is only expelled from the heart when it contracts...

    血液在心臟收縮的時候從心臟流出。

  • New research shows that an excess of meat and salt can contract muscles.

    新的研究表明，過量食用肉類和鹽可能會導致肌肉收縮。

contraction

  • ...the contraction and expansion of blood vessels...

    血管的收縮和擴張

  • Foods and fluids are mixed in the stomach by its muscular contractions.

    通過胃部肌肉的收縮食物和流質在胃中混合。

4[VERB 動詞](經濟、市場等)緊縮，縮小 When something such as an economy or market contracts, it becomes smaller.
  [V]

  • The manufacturing economy contracted in October for the sixth consecutive month.

    10月，製造業經濟已經連續第6個月出現萎縮狀況。

5[VERB 動詞]感染，患(病) If you contract a serious illness, you become ill with it.
  [V n]
  [V-ed]
  [no cont]
  [FORMAL 正式]

  • He contracted AIDS from a blood transfusion...

    他因為輸血而感染了艾滋病。

  • Ovarian cancer is the sixth most common cancer contracted by women.

    卵巢癌是女性常患的第六大癌症。

6[VERB 動詞]訂立(婚約)；簽訂(盟約等) If you contract a marriage, alliance, or other relationship with someone, you arrange to have that relationship with them.
  [V n]
  [FORMAL 正式]

  • She contracted a formal marriage to a British ex-serviceman.

    她和一個英國退役軍人正式訂婚了。

7[N-COUNT 可數名詞]買兇殺人的協議 If there is a contract on a person or on their life, someone has made an arrangement to have them killed.
  [usu N on n]
  [INFORMAL 非正式]

  • The convictions resulted in the local crime bosses putting a contract on him...

    這些判罪導致當地犯罪團伙的老大們要雇兇殺他。

  • The police advised her to get out of town because there was a contract on her life.

    警察建議她離開這個城市，因為有人雇殺手殺她。

8[PHRASE 短語]簽訂工作合同的 If you are under contract to someone, you have signed a contract agreeing to work for them, and for no-one else, during a fixed period of time.
  [oft PHR to n]

  • The director wanted Olivia de Havilland, then under contract to Warner Brothers.

    導演想要當時簽約於華納兄弟娛樂公司旗下的奧利維婭·德哈維蘭出演。

相關詞組：
contract out

column5: vt.反駁；與 ... 矛盾
column6:
(1) He did not contradict his attorney's comment.
(2) Don't contradict your father.
(3) The report contradicts what we heard yesterday.
(4) The two statements contradict each other.
column7:
(1) 他沒有反駁律師的意見。
(2) 別和你父親強嘴。
(3) 這個報道與我們昨天聽到的有矛盾。
(4) 兩種說法相互牴觸。
column8: Contra- usually means "against," and to contradict is to go against or say the opposite of what someone else is doing or saying. Sometimes to contradict is to frustrate with words, like when one person says "The sky is blue" and another says "No, it's azure."
column9: Denying or distorting the truth is a big part of trying to contradict. It can be harmless verbal back-and-forth, like when a husband and wife disagree just to disagree, or contradict each other to make a humorous point, but at other times people contradict something to make another person look like a liar. Often, a person who has lied will later contradict himself by saying something different from what he said earlier — and sometimes the two sides contradict each other, and neither is actually right.
column11:
1[VERB 動詞]反駁；否認；駁斥 If you contradict someone, you say that what they have just said is wrong, or suggest that it is wrong by saying something different.
  [V n]
  [V pron-refl]

  • She dared not contradict him...

    她不敢反駁他。

  • His comments appeared to contradict remarks made earlier in the day by the chairman...

    他的意見似乎和當天早些時候主席所說的相矛盾。

  • He often talks in circles, frequently contradicting himself and often ends up saying nothing.

    他說話經常兜圈子，老是自相矛盾，常常到最後什麼也沒說。

2[VERB 動詞]與…矛盾；同… 牴觸 If one statement or piece of evidence contradicts another, the first one makes the second one appear to be wrong.
  [V n]

  • Her version contradicted the Govern-ment's claim that they were shot after being challenged...

    政府聲稱他們是在受到盤問後被開槍射殺的，而她的說法卻與此相矛盾。

  • The result seems to contradict a major U.S. study reported last November.

    這一結果似乎和去年11月美國研究人員發表的一項重要成果相矛盾。

3[VERB 動詞]違背；與…背道而馳 If one policy or situation contradicts another, there is a conflict between them, and they cannot both exist or be successful.
  [V n]

  • Mr Grant feels that the cutbacks contradict the Government's commitment to better educational standards.

    格蘭特先生感覺這些縮減措施和政府提高教育水平的承諾背道而馳。

column5:
adj.相反的；截然不同的；執拗的
n.反面；相反
column6:
(1) Hot and cold are contrary terms.
(2) My sister's taste in dresses is contrary to my own.
(3) Mrs. Smith is too contrary to make friends easily.
(4) Cruelty is the contrary of kindness.
(5) On the contrary,I have tons of things to do.
column7:
(1) 熱與冷是相反的詞語。
(2) 在服裝方面，我妹妹的愛好和我完全不同。
(3) 史密斯太太過於固執而不易交朋友。
(4) 殘忍是仁慈的反面。
(5) 正相反,我有一大堆事要做。
column8: Use contrary when two things are exactly opposite or entirely different. If something is contrary to something else, it is opposed to or against it.
column9: A contrary child is one who opposes people in authority. As a noun, the contrary means the opposite, as in "We will not give up; on the contrary, we will fight with all our power." The adjective contrary derives from Latin contrarius "opposite, opposed," from contra "against."
column11:
1[ADJ 形容詞]相反的；相對的 Ideas, attitudes, or reactions that are contrary to each other are completely different from each other.
  [usu v-link ADJ to n]

  • This view is contrary to the aims of critical social research for a number of reasons...

    之所以說此觀點違背了批判性社會研究的宗旨，有幾點理由。

  • Several of those present, including Weinberger, had contrary information.

    幾個在場的人，包括溫博格，所掌握的信息截然不同。

2[PREP-PHRASE 短語介詞]與…相反 If you say that something is true contrary to other people's beliefs or opinions, you are emphasizing that it is true and that they are wrong.
  [emphasis]

  • Contrary to popular belief, moderate exercise actually decreases your appetite...

    與通常的看法相反，適度的運動事實上會降低食慾。

  • Contrary to what you might think, neither man was offended.

    你也許以為那兩個人生氣了，但實際上正相反，兩個人都沒有生氣。

3[PHRASE 短語]相反地 You use on the contrary when you have just said or implied that something is not true and are going to say that the opposite is true.
  [PHR with cl]

  • It is not an idea around which the Community can unite. On the contrary, I see it as one that will divide us.

    這種想法並不能讓歐共體團結一致。相反地，我認為它會導致我們的分裂。

4[PHRASE 短語]恰恰相反；正相反 You can use on the contrary when you are disagreeing strongly with something that has just been said or implied, or are making a strong negative reply.
  [emphasis]

  • 'People just don't do things like that.' — 'On the contrary, they do them all the time.'

    「人們根本不會做那樣的事情。」——「恰恰相反，他們一直在那樣做。」

Usage Note :

Do not confuse on the contrary with on the other hand. On the contrary is used to contradict someone, to say that they are wrong. On the other hand is used to state a different, often contrasting aspect of the situation you are considering. Prices of other foods and consumer goods fell. Wages on the other hand increased.

不要混淆 on the contrary 和 on the other hand。on the contrary 用來駁斥某人，認為其是錯誤的。而 on the other hand 用來陳述所考慮的情形中不同的、通常是相對立的一個方面，如，Prices of other foods and consumer goods fell. Wages on the other hand increased (其他食物和生活消費品的價格都下降了，而另一方面，薪水卻提高了)。

5[PHRASE 短語]完全相反；完全不同；根本不是 You can use quite the contrary to emphasize a previous negative statement, or when you are making a strong negative reply.
  [PHR with cl]
  [emphasis]

  • I'm not a feminist, quite the contrary...

    我不是一個女權主義者，根本不是。

  • 'Are there any signs that he may quit soon?' — 'Quite the contrary.'

    「有沒有跡象表明他可能很快就會辭職？」——「完全沒有。」

6[PHRASE 短語]相反地 When a particular idea is being considered, evidence or statements to the contrary suggest that this idea is not true or that the opposite is true.
  [n PHR]

  • That does not automatically mean, however, that the money supply has been curbed, and there is considerable evidence to the contrary...

    然而，那並不一定意味著貨幣供應量受到了限制，有大量證據表明事實正好相反。

  • Despite repeated assurances to the contrary, Pakistan has not ended its nuclear programme.

    儘管巴基斯坦再三保證停止其核項目，但事實卻並非如此。

column5:
n.對比；差別；對照物
v.對比；成對照
n.[計算機] 反差
column6:
(1) There is a great contrast between good and evil.
(2) The little village was a total contrast to San Francisco.
(3) The microscope image contains contrast effects.
(4) When you contrast their work records, Julie is clearly more qualified.
column7:
(1) 善與惡有明顯的差別。
(2) 這個小村莊與聖弗朗西斯科形成強烈對照。
(3) 顯微鏡所成的圖像具有反差效應。
(4) 對比他們的工作記錄,你會發現茱莉更有能力。
column8: The verb contrast means to show a difference, like photos that reveal how much weight someone lost by contrasting the "before" and "after" shots.
column9: You probably know contrast in its relation to compare. To contrast something is to look for differences among two or more elements, but compare is to do the opposite, to look for similarities. It's easy to tell the difference if you remember that contrast comes from the Latin root contra, and means "against." Contrast is also a noun meaning basically the same thing — you might notice the contrast of a dark tree against a snow-covered hill.
column11:
The noun is pronounced /'kɒntrɑːst, -trast/. The verb is pronounced /kən'trɑːst, -'trast/. 名詞讀作 /'kɒntrɑːst, -trast/，動詞讀作 /kən'trɑːst, -'trast/。
1[N-VAR 可變名詞]差異；差別；懸殊 A contrast is a great difference between two or more things which is clear when you compare them.
  [oft N between pl-n]

  • ...the contrast between town and country...

    城鄉差別

  • The two visitors provided a startling contrast in appearance...

    這兩位訪客的外表截然不同。

  • Silk was used with wool for contrast.

    絲綢和毛料用在一起以形成對比。

2[PHRASE 短語]相比之下；與…相反 You say by contrast or in contrast, or in contrast to something, to show that you are mentioning a very different situation from the one you have just mentioned.
  [PHR with cl]

  • The private sector, by contrast, has plenty of money to spend...

    相比之下，私營部門就有很多錢可供開銷。

  • In contrast, the lives of girls in well-to-do families were often very sheltered...

    相反，生活在富裕家庭的女孩子通常都備受呵護。

  • In contrast to similar services in France and Germany, Intercity rolling stock is very rarely idle.

    與法國和德國的類似鐵路服務系統不同，「城際列車」很少閒置。

3[PHRASE 短語]與…截然不同；與…對比鮮明 If one thing is in contrast to another, it is very different from it.
  [v-link PHR]

  • His public statements have always been in marked contrast to those of his son...

    他和他兒子在公開場合的言論總是截然不同。

  • That is in stark contrast to the situation during the 1970 oil crisis.

    那和1970年石油危機時的情形完全不同。

4[N-COUNT 可數名詞]截然不同的事物；差異明顯的事物 If one thing is a contrast to another, it is very different from it.
  [oft N to/with n]

  • The boy's room is a complete contrast to the guest room.

    這個男孩的房間和客房截然不同。

  • ...a country of great contrasts.

    一個截然不同的國家

5[VERB 動詞]對比；對照 If you contrast one thing with another, you point out or consider the differences between those things.
  [V n with n]
  [V pl-n]

  • She contrasted the situation then with the present crisis...

    她將當時的情況和目前的危機進行對比。

  • Contrast that approach with what goes on in most organizations...

    將那個方法和大多數機構現行的做法進行對比。

  • In this section we contrast four possible broad approaches.

    在這個部分，我們將對4種可行的廣義方法進行對比。

6[V-RECIP 相互動詞]截然不同；有明顯差異；對比鮮明 If one thing contrasts with another, it is very different from it.
  [V with n]
  [V-ing]
  [Also pl-n V]

  • Johnson's easy charm contrasted sharply with the prickliness of his boss...

    約翰遜的親和力和他老闆易怒的性格形成了鮮明的對比。

  • Paint the wall in a contrasting colour.

    把這面牆刷成對比鮮明的顏色。

7[N-UNCOUNT 不可數名詞](照片、電視圖像、畫作等的)顏色反差，明暗對比 Contrast is the degree of difference between the darker and lighter parts of a photograph, television picture, or painting.

  • ...a television with brighter colours, better contrast, and digital sound.

    顏色更為鮮艷、圖像對比度更高、具備數字音響效果的電視

column5:
vt.捐助；投稿
vi.投稿；貢獻；是原因之一
column6:
(1) It was generous of her to contribute such a large sum.
(2) She asked him to contribute a biweekly article on European affairs.
(3) Don't contribute after the closing date.
(4) It is an honour to be invited to contribute to your magazine.
(5) Honesty and hard work contribute to success and happiness.
(6) Henry, whose goal in life was to contribute towards the happiness of others, died a hero.
(7) The first is to cut back on treats and snacks. These are generally high in calories and may contribute to weight gain.
column7:
(1) 她很大方，捐助了這麼大筆錢。
(2) 她讓他每兩周寫一篇有關歐洲情況的文章。
(3) 請在截止日期前投稿。
(4) 應邀向貴雜誌投稿是一個榮譽。
(5) 誠實加苦幹有助於成功和幸福。
(6) Henry英勇獻身，他的生活目標是為他人的幸福作貢獻。
(7) 首先,就是減少小零食。這些零食一般都含有很高的熱量,很容易引起狗狗的發胖;
column8: To contribute something is to provide a part of the whole. When your company has their annual softball game and potluck picnic, you will probably be asked to contribute a dish, like your famous macaroni salad.
column9: Contribute comes from a Latin word that means 「to bring together, add, or unite.」 When you contribute to a cause, you are adding to what other people have kicked in, which makes the effort complete. You can contribute your singing talent to a traveling a cappella group; you can contribute money or time to save rhinoceroses; you can contribute cupcakes to the gymnastics team bake sale; or you can even contribute ideas on healthcare reform to a Washington think tank.
column11:
1[VERB 動詞](為…)做貢獻 If you contribute to something, you say or do things to help to make it successful.
  [V to n]
  [V n to n]
  [Also V]

  • The three sons also contribute to the family business...

    這3個兒子也為家族事業做出了貢獻。

  • I believe that each of us can contribute to the future of the world...

    我相信我們每一個人都能夠對世界的未來有所貢獻。

  • He believes he has something to contribute to a discussion concerning the uprising.

    他認為自己能夠為有關起義的討論提供一些信息。

2[VERB 動詞]捐獻；捐助；援助 To contribute money or resources to something means to give money or resources to help pay for something or to help achieve a particular purpose.
  [V n]
  [V n to/towards n]
  [Also V]

  • The US is contributing $4 billion in loans, credits and grants...

    美國將提供40億美元的信貸和贈款。

  • They say they would like to contribute more to charity, but money is tight this year...

    他們說他們很想捐獻更多的錢支持慈善事業，但是今年的錢非常緊張。

  • NATO officials agreed to contribute troops and equipment to such an operation if the UN Security Council asked for it.

    北約官員同意可在聯合國安理會要求的情況下派出部隊並提供裝備參加這樣的軍事行動。

contributor

  • ...the largest net contributors to EU funds.

    向歐盟基金淨捐資額最大的捐助者

3[VERB 動詞]促成；促使；是導致…的原因之一 If something contributes to an event or situation, it is one of the causes of it.
  [V to n]
  [V-ing]

  • The report says design faults in both the vessels contributed to the tragedy...

    報告說兩艘船存在的設計缺陷也促成了這場悲劇的發生。

  • Stress, both human and mechanical, may also be a contributing factor.

    來自人的和機械方面的壓力可能也是一個因素。

4[VERB 動詞](為報刊、書籍等)撰稿 If you contribute to a magazine, newspaper, or book, you write things that are published in it.
  [V to n]
  [V-ing]

  • I was asked to contribute to a newspaper article making predictions for the new year...

    我受邀為報紙撰寫一篇文章，對新的一年進行預測。

  • Frank Deford is a contributing editor for Vanity Fair magazine.

    弗蘭克·德福特是雜誌《名利場》的特約編輯。

contributor

  • Reporter Alan Nearn covers Central America and is a regular contributor to The New Yorker.

    記者艾倫·尼恩負責在中美洲採訪報道，定期向《紐約客》雜誌投稿。

column5: adj. 痛悔前非的; 悔恨不已的
column6:
(1) a contrite apology, manner
(2) She was contrite the morning after her angry outburst.
(3) a contrite tone.
(4) She was instantly contrite. `Oh, I am sorry! You must forgive me.'
column7:
(1) 深表懊悔的致歉、 樣子
(2) 她發了一頓脾氣之後一早上追悔莫及
(3) 懊悔的語氣

column5: v.圖謀；發明；設計；設法做到
column6:
(1) The prisoner contrived a way to escape.
(2) He contrived to gain their votes.
(3) He contrived a new machine for flying.
(4) Can you contrive to be at the station by noon?
(5) I can contrive without meat.
column7:
(1) 囚犯圖謀越獄。
(2) 他施展計謀獲得了他們的選票。
(3) 他設計了一種新式飛行器。
(4) 你能設法在中午前趕到車站嗎?
(5) 我沒有肉也能湊合吃這頓飯。
column8: When you contrive, you make a plan or a plot. It may take you longer to contrive your way out of doing your homework than would to actually do it.
column9: Even though contrive often has a false or cunning feel to it, it is not always a bad thing. Mental effort is always required though, as contrive is often used in connection with inventing schemes and plans to make something happen. Contraption, a complicated mysterious device that does something, is related to contrive. Have you ever seen a Rube Goldberg contraption? When you contrive to do something, your plan may end up being that complicated.
column11:
1[VERB 動詞]圖謀；策劃；謀劃 If you contrive an event or situation, you succeed in making it happen, often by tricking someone.
  [V n]
  [FORMAL 正式]

  • The oil companies were accused of contriving a shortage of gasoline to justify price increases.

    石油公司被控故意製造石油短缺以名正言順地提高油價。

2[VERB 動詞]發明；(精巧地)設計出，製造 If you contrive something such as a device or piece of equipment, you invent and construct it in a clever or unusual way.
  [V n]

  • We therefore had to contrive a very large black-out curtain.

    因此我們得製作一塊很大的遮光窗簾。

3[VERB 動詞]成功做到；設法做到 If you contrive to do something difficult, you succeed in doing it.
  [V to-inf]
  [FORMAL 正式]

  • The orchestra contrived to produce some of its best playing for years.

    這支管絃樂隊呈現了精彩的演奏，堪稱其多年來的巔峰演奏。

4[VERB 動詞](用欺騙的手法)策劃，圖謀，設法做到 When someone has done something dishonestly, you can say that they have contrived to do it.
  [V to-inf]
  [disapproval]

  • They somehow contrived to lose tens of thousands of applications.

    他們精心策劃故意遺失了數萬份申請書。

column5: adj.有爭議的；引起爭論的
column6:
(1) We tried to stay away from controversial topics at the dinner party.
(2) This is a controversial question.
column7:
(1) 晚宴上我們盡力避免一些有爭議的話題。
(2) 這是個引起爭論的問題。
column8: If a politician ran for office on the platform that children should be put to work from age six, his platform is likely to be controversial, meaning it will cause controversy, or a long discussion among people with opposing opinions.
column9: Controversies are usually public disagreements about important matters. The adjective controversial is from the Latin from controversus "disputed," formed from the prefix contra- "against" plus versus, from vertere "to turn." The Latin suffix –ialis, corresponding to the English suffixes –ial and –al, means "relating to or characterized by."
column11:
1[ADJ-GRADED 能被表示程度的副詞或介詞詞組修飾的形容詞]有爭議的；引發爭論的 If you describe something or someone as controversial, you mean that they are the subject of intense public argument, disagreement, or disapproval.

  • Immigration is a controversial issue in many countries...

    在很多國家，移民都是一個頗有爭議的問題。

  • ...Morton's controversial book, 'Diana, Her True Story.'...

    莫頓頗有爭議的一本書，《戴安娜：真實的故事》

  • The changes are bound to be controversial.

    這些變化注定會引起爭議。

  • ...the controversial 19th century politician Charles Parnell.

    19世紀頗具爭議的政治家查爾斯·帕內爾

controversially

  • More controversially, he claims that these higher profits cover the cost of finding fresh talent...

    更具爭議的是，他聲稱這些更高的利潤可足以支付尋找新人才所花費的成本。

  • David Hirst was controversially sent off on his European debut for Sheffield Wednesday last night.

    週三，也就是昨天晚上大衛·赫斯特代表謝菲爾德足球俱樂部參加他在歐洲的首場比賽時被罰下場，引來一片爭議。

column5: n.謎語；難題
column6:
(1) I'm going to tell you why this conundrum exists.
(2) Let me tell you what science has done with the conundrum.
column7:
(1) 我打算告訴你們為什麼這個謎題存在。
(2) 讓我告訴你們科學與謎題曾有的關係。
column8: The tricky word conundrum is used to describe a riddle or puzzle, sometimes including a play on words or pun.
column9: One of the most famous conundrums is the riddle of the Sphinx, famously in the play Oedipus the King by Sophocles. Oedipus encounters the Sphinx, a mythical beast, who asks him, "What walks on four legs in the morning, two in the afternoon, and three in the evening?" The answer is "A person": crawling as a child, walking as an adult, and using a cane in old age. The scary thing is that if the Sphinx asked you the riddle and you didn't know, she'd eat you!
column11:
1[N-COUNT 可數名詞]難題；複雜難解的問題 A conundrum is a problem or puzzle which is difficult or impossible to solve.
  [FORMAL 正式]

  • ...this theological conundrum of the existence of evil and suffering in a world created by a good God.

    在善良的上帝創造的世界裡存在著邪惡和苦難這一神學之謎

column5:
vi.集合
vt.集合；召集；召喚
column6:
(1) The tribunal will convene tomorrow.
(2) The committee will convene at 11.30 next Thursday.
(3) The Board shall convene an emergency meeting to review and confirm such report.
(4) People were convened here for an emergency meeting.
column7:
(1) 法庭將於明日開庭。
(2) 委員會將在下星期四上午 11:30 開會。
(3) 董事會應召開緊急會議對該報告進行審議並核准。
(4) 人們被召集到這裡舉行緊急會議。
column8: The verb convene is a somewhat formal way of saying "to bring together for the purpose of a meeting."
column9: Convene is one of those words that lend an air of formality to a situation. We use it in place of the words "call a meeting" for such situations as government assemblages, court hearings, and conferences. Its meaning can be easily seen in its history — it comes from the Latin con-, which means "together," and the verb venīre, "to come." Imagine, if the syllables had just fit the music, the John Lennon song "Come together," might have been called Convene.
column11:
1[V-ERG 及物/不及物動詞]召集；集合；開會 If someone convenes a meeting or conference, they arrange for it to take place. You can also say that people convene or that a meeting convenes .
  [V n]
  [V]
  [V-ing]
  [FORMAL 正式]

  • Last August he convened a meeting of his closest advisers at Camp David...

    去年8月，他召集自己最親近的顧問在戴維營開會。

  • Senior officials convened in October 1991 in London.

    1991年10月，高級官員在倫敦會齊。

  • ...the convening of an international peace conference.

    一次國際和平會議的召開

column5: n.便利；舒適；適宜；便利設施；方便的時間
column6:
(1) It's a great convenience to live in town.
(2) I stock upon grocery at the convenience store.
(3) The hotel combines comfort with convenience.
(4) Analyzed experiment data, the best one is ultrasonic in the light of convenience, quick, especially avoid sample color disturbing and hydrargyrum pollution.
(5) We find our folding table a great convenience.
(6) Please come at your convenience.
column7:
(1) 住在城市裡有很大的方便。
(2) 我到便利商店買食品備用。
(3) 這家旅館既舒適又方便。
(4) 通過實驗得出數據，進行分析，確定了超聲法為最適宜樣品前處理方法。
(5) 我們發現可折疊的桌子使用非常方便。
(6) 請在你方便的時候前來。
column8: Even though the real reason you want the newest phone is that it's incredibly cool looking, you might pretend that what interests you is its convenience, or how easy and useful it will be.
column9: The noun convenience is a quality of ease or accessibility. Just think of a convenience store, which is arranged to be easy to get in and out of, and sells things you might need to grab on your way home. Some things are referred to as a convenience if the whole reason for their existence is to make life easier in some way, like electricity, indoor plumbing, and microwaveable meals.
column11:
1[N-UNCOUNT 不可數名詞]方便；便利；合宜 If something is done for your convenience, it is done in a way that is useful or suitable for you.
  [with poss]
  [PHR with v]
  [FORMAL 正式]

  • He was happy to make a detour for her convenience.

    為了她方便，他很樂意繞道。

  • ...the need to put the rights of citizens above the convenience of elected officials.

    需要把公民的權利置於當選官員的便利之上

  • If something is arranged to happen at your convenience, it happens at a time which is most suitable for you.就…的方便；在…方便的時候

    • Delivery times are arranged at your convenience.

      送貨時間會安排在您方便的時候。

2[N-COUNT 可數名詞]帶來方便的事物 If you describe something as a convenience, you mean that it is very useful.

  • Mail order is a convenience for buyers who are too busy to shop.

    郵購對於那些沒有時間逛商店的購物者來說是一項非常方便的服務。

3[N-COUNT 可數名詞]便利設施；便利裝置 Conveniences are pieces of equipment designed to make your life easier.
  [usu pl]

  • Some TVRs have power steering and conveniences such as central locking and powered windows.

    一些特雷沃車型配有動力轉向系統以及中央鎖和電動窗之類的便利裝置。

  • ...an apartment with all the modern conveniences.

    現代化便利設施一應俱全的公寓

4[N-COUNT 可數名詞]公共廁所 A public convenience is a building containing toilets which is provided in a public place for anyone to use.
  [usu supp N]
  [BRIT FORMAL 英]

  • ...the cubicles of a public convenience.

    公共廁所的小隔間

5See also:convenient；

column5: n.大會；協定；慣例；公約
column6:
(1) The convention looms as political battle.
(2) Delegates will be picked at a convention.
(3) This convention results in no ambiguity.
(4) The handshake is a social convention.
(5) Convention requires that such meetings open with prayer.
(6) Property Management Convention agreed receivers?
(7) We follow Geneva Convention procedures.
column7:
(1) 這場大會將是一場政治角鬥。
(2) 代表將在大會上選出。
(3) 這個協定不會導致誤解。
(4) 握手是社交慣例。
(5) 慣例上要求這樣的集會應當以祈禱開始。
(6) 物業管理公約約定啥？
(7) 我們遵守日內瓦公約規定的程序。
column8: A convention is a meeting, usually of a particular group. Political parties, teachers, plumbers, gardeners, toymakers and computer designers all hold conventions.
column9: In fact, lots of cities have built Convention Centers in hopes of attracting convention-goers. The best-known conventions happen every four years when the Democrats and Republicans meet to nominate presidential candidates. A convention can also be used to describe the normal or accepted way of doing things. It's the convention, for example, for your employer to give you a three-day weekend around the Fourth of July, even if it falls on a weekend.
column11:
1[N-VAR 可變名詞]習俗；慣例；常規 A convention is a way of behaving that is considered to be correct or polite by most people in a society.

  • It's just a social convention that men don't wear skirts...

    男人不穿裙子只是一種社會習俗。

  • Despite her wish to defy convention, she had become pregnant and married at 21.

    儘管她不想遵循傳統習俗，但她還是在21歲的時候就懷孕並且結婚了。

2[N-COUNT 可數名詞](藝術、文學、戲劇中的)傳統做法，傳統風格 In art, literature, or the theatre, a convention is a traditional method or style.

  • We go offstage and come back for the convention of the encore.

    按照加演的傳統做法，我們走到後台後又再次返場。

  • ...the stylistic conventions of Egyptian art.

    埃及藝術的傳統風格

3[N-COUNT 可數名詞](國家或組織間的)公約，協定，協約 A convention is an official agreement between countries or groups of people.
  [oft n N]

  • ...the UN convention on climate change.

    聯合國有關氣候變化的公約

  • ...the Geneva convention.

    日內瓦公約

4[N-COUNT 可數名詞](組織、政治團體的)大會，大型會議 A convention is a large meeting of an organization or political group.

  • ...the annual convention of the Society of Professional Journalists.

    職業新聞工作者協會年度大會

  • ...the Republican convention.

    共和黨代表大會

column5: adj.傳統的；慣例的；常規的
column6:
(1) Her book is a hilarious send-up of a conventional spy story.
(2) According to conventional wisdom, voters usually make their choice on the basis of domestic issues.
(3) After a conventional opening remarks, he made a brilliant speech.
(4) I can never get a girl like that with conventional methods.
column7:
(1) 她寫的書用的是取笑傳統偵探小說的筆法，令人捧腹。
(2) 按一般人在這些問題上的看法，選民常常著眼於國內問題來選擇候選人。
(3) 在一個常規的開場白後,他做了個很精彩的演講。
(4) 我用尋常套路可永遠也得不到這樣的女孩。
column8: Conventional is an adjective for things that are normal, ordinary, and following the accepted way. Ho-hum.
column9: This word describes what is typical and ordinary and that which follows accepted standards of behavior or taste. This is a word that's current definition is still very similar to its Latin root, conventionalis, which is "pertaining to an agreement." One way this word is used is with respect to conventional weapons, as in those "not using, making, or involving nuclear weapons or energy; nonnuclear."
column11:
1[ADJ-GRADED 能被表示程度的副詞或介詞詞組修飾的形容詞]（行為、觀念等）傳統的，符合習俗的 Someone who is conventional has behaviour or opinions that are ordinary and normal.

  • ...a respectable married woman with conventional opinions.

    一位觀念傳統、受人尊敬的已婚女性

conventionally

  • People still wore their hair short and dressed conventionally.

    人們還留著短髮、穿著傳統服飾。

2[ADJ 形容詞]（方法或產品）通常的，傳統的 A conventional method or product is one that is usually used or that has been in use for a long time.
  [usu ADJ n]

  • It is simpler and quicker to use than conventional methods.

    這比通常的做法更簡單、更快捷。

  • These discs hold more than 400 times as much information as a conventional computer floppy disk.

    這些光盤能容納的信息量是普通計算機軟盤的400多倍。

conventionally

  • Organically grown produce does not differ greatly in appearance from conventionally grown crops.

    有機農產品在外觀上和以傳統方法種植的作物沒有很大的區別。

3[ADJ 形容詞](武器、戰爭等)常規的，非核的 Conventional weapons and wars do not involve nuclear explosives.
  [usu ADJ n]

  • We must reduce the danger of war by controlling nuclear, chemical and conventional arms.

    我們必須通過控制核武器、化學武器和常規武器的數量來減少戰爭的危險。

4 conventional wisdom→see: wisdom；

column5:
vi.聚合；集中；會聚
vt.使集合
column6:
(1) The roads converge just before the station.
(2) These lines converge at a certain point.
(3) If you look at the end of your nose, your eyes converge.
(4) In this case the rays obviously do not converge.
column7:
(1) 四面八方的道路會聚在火車站前。
(2) 這些線集中於某一點。
(3) 如果你看著你的鼻尖，你的兩眼就向一點集中。
(4) 此時，光線顯然不會聚。
column8: Use the verb converge to describe something that comes together at a common point: 「Thousands of Elvis fans plan to converge on the small Arkansas town where unconfirmed sightings of the deceased superstar eating at a local barbeque restaurant had been widely reported.」
column9: Two roads, a roomful of politicians, or a group of rabid fans — when things come together from different points they converge. Converge traces back to the Latin word vergere, meaning 「to bend or to turn." The prefix con- means "with," a good way to remember that things that converge come together. Don't confuse it with diverge, which means the opposite: "move away," because the prefix 「dis-」 means 「apart.」
column11:
1[VERB 動詞]彙集；集中；聚集 If people or vehicles converge on a place, they move towards it from different directions.
  [V on n]

  • Competitors from more than a hundred countries have converged on Sheffield for the Games...

    來自100多個國家的選手齊聚設菲爾德參加此次運動會。

  • Hundreds of coaches will converge on the capital.

    數百輛長途汽車將會在首都彙集。

2[VERB 動詞](路、線等)交會，交叉，匯合 If roads or lines converge, they meet or join at a particular place.
  [pl-n V]
  [FORMAL 正式]

  • As they flow south, the five rivers converge.

    5條大河在南邊交匯。

3[V-RECIP 相互動詞](不同的思想、社會等)趨同，趨於一致，融合 If different ideas or societies converge, they stop being different and become similar to each other.
  [pl-n V]
  [V with n]

  • Speeches delivered by Mr Dewar and Mr Wallace indicated their views were converging...

    杜瓦先生和華萊士先生發表的講話表明他們的觀點越來越接近了。

  • The views of the richest householders converged with those of the poorest and created a new consensus.

    最富的房主和最窮的房主觀點趨於一致，達成了新的共識。

column5:
n.相反的事物；逆命題
adj.相反的；逆向的；倒的
v.交談；談話
n.談話
column6:
(1) He says she is satisfied, but I believe the converse to be true: she is very dissatisfied.
(2) I believe the converse of what you are saying.
(3) It is a pleasure to converse with her.
(4) They wish for secrecy, since we are to converse in a private room.
(5) This statement is converse to that one.
(6) Would you give me half an hour to converse with you?
(7) It is a pleasure to converse with her.
column7:
(1) 他說她已心滿意足了，不過我認為實際情況相反: 她很不滿意。
(2) 我相信的和你說的正相反。
(3) 和她談話是一種樂趣。
(4) 他要保密，所以要找個單間談話。
(5) 這個聲明和那個相反。
(6) 我想跟你談談，半小時就行。
(7) 和她談話是一種樂趣。
column8: Converse is a more formal way of saying "carry on a conversation." You could converse with your best friend for hours over lunch, but continue the chit-chat through the afternoon matinee and you might get shushed.
column9: Oddly enough, converse was originally a verb meaning 「to move about, live or dwell」 when it first came into existence in the mid 14th century. But today we only use converse to talk about, well, talking. Quipped the German philosopher Friedrich Nietzsche, 「When marrying, one should ask oneself this question: Do you believe that you will be able to converse well with this woman into your old age?」 A good question for marrying men and women!
column11:
The verb is pronounced /kən'vɜːs/. The noun is pronounced /'kɒnvɜːs/. 動詞讀作 /kən'vɜːs/，名詞讀作 /'kɒnvɜːs/。
1[V-RECIP 相互動詞](與…)交談；(和…)說話 If you converse with someone, you talk to them. You can also say that two people converse .
  [V with n]
  [pl-n V]
  [FORMAL 正式]

  • Luke sat directly behind the pilot and conversed with him...

    盧克就坐在飛行員後面，並且和他說著話。

  • They were conversing in German, their only common language.

    他們正用德語交談，這是他們唯一的共同語言。

2[N-SING 單數名詞]相反的聲明；相反的話；相反的言論 The converse of a statement is its opposite or reverse.
  [the N]
  [FORMAL 正式]

  • What you do for a living is critical to where you settle and how you live — and the converse is also true.

    一個人的謀生手段對於其居住地的選擇和生活方式來說有著至關重要的影響，反之亦然。

column5:
v.(使)轉變；使…改變信仰；轉化；兌換；換算
n.皈依者；改變信仰的人
column6:
(1) The solar cell can convert the energy of sunlight into electric energy.
(2) The old barn we bought to convert into flats was practically tumbling down.
(3) My mother has converted to Catholicism.
(4) Coal can be converted to gas.
(5) We convert our pound into Swiss Francs.
(6) At what rate does the dollar convert into pounds?
(7) Convert the following denary numbers to base 8.
(8) He is a recent convert to Christianity.
column7:
(1) 太陽能電池能把陽光的能量轉化為電能。
(2) 那個舊穀倉我們買下想改建住房的，實際上已經快塌了。
(3) 我母親已轉而信仰天主教。
(4) 煤可以轉化成煤氣。
(5) 我們把英鎊兌換成瑞士法郎。
(6) 美元以什麼匯率兌換成英鎊?
(7) 把下列各十進制換算成以8為基值的數。
(8) 他最近改信基督教了。
column8: Think of the word convert as meaning "change," whether it is a person who adopts a new belief, or a changing action, such as when you convert dollars into euros.
column9: Many times we can catch a word's meaning by looking at its origins. In this case, the Latin con means "around," while vertere means "turn." So we can figure that convert means to "turn around," an object or one's thoughts on an idea. For example, you might convert a meat eater into a vegetarian or an empty-nester might convert the kids' bedroom into an exercise room.
column11:
The verb is pronounced /kən'vɜːt/. The noun is pronounced /'kɒnvɜːt/. 動詞讀作 /kən'vɜːt/，名詞讀作 /'kɒnvɜːt/。
1[V-ERG 及物/不及物動詞](使)改變；更改；(使)轉變 If one thing is converted or converts into another, it is changed into a different form.
  [be V-ed into/to n]
  [V n into/to n]
  [V into/to n]

  • The signal will be converted into digital code.

    信號會被轉變為數字代碼。

  • ...naturally occurring substances which the body can convert into vitamins.

    自然產生的能被身體轉化成維生素的物質

  • ...a table that converts into an ironing board.

    能轉換成熨衣板的桌子

2[VERB 動詞]改造，改建(房屋等) If someone converts a room or building, they alter it in order to use it for a different purpose.
  [V n]
  [V n into n]
  [V-ed]

  • By converting the loft, they were able to have two extra bedrooms.

    把閣樓改造一下，他們就可以多出兩間臥室。

  • ...the entrepreneur who wants to convert County Hall into an hotel...

    想把市政廳改建成旅館的企業家

  • He is living in a converted barn.

    他住在一個改造過的倉庫裡。

3[VERB 動詞]改造，改裝(車輛或設備) If you convert a vehicle or piece of equipment, you change it so that it can use a different fuel.
  [V n to/into n]
  [V n]

  • Save money by converting your car to unleaded...

    將車改裝一下，使用無鉛汽油，這樣可以省錢。

  • The programme to convert every gas burner in Britain took 10 years.

    完成對英國所有煤氣灶的改造花了10年時間。

4[VERB 動詞]換算；折算 If you convert a quantity from one system of measurement to another, you calculate what the quantity is in the second system.
  [V n prep]
  [Also V n]

  • Converting metric measurements to U.S. equivalents is easy.

    將公制計量換算成美制計量非常簡單。

5[V-ERG 及物/不及物動詞](使)改變宗教（或政治）信仰；(使)皈依；(使)歸附 If someone converts you, they persuade you to change your religious or political beliefs. You can also say that someone converts to a different religion.
  [V n]
  [V n to n]
  [V to n]

  • If you try to convert him, you could find he just walks away...

    如果你試圖改變他的信仰，他就會走開。

  • He was a major influence in converting Godwin to political radicalism...

    戈德溫變成政治激進主義者主要是受他的影響。

  • He converted to Catholicism in 1917.

    他於1917年皈依天主教。

6[N-COUNT 可數名詞]皈依者；歸附者；改變信仰者 A convert is someone who has changed their religious or political beliefs.
  [oft N to n]

  • She, too, was a convert to Roman Catholicism.

    她也皈依了天主教。

  • ...a Muslim convert now known as Yusuf Islam.

    現以優素福·伊斯蘭這個名字為大家熟知的伊斯蘭教皈依者

7[VERB 動詞]使…迷上；使…熱衷於 If someone converts you to something, they make you very enthusiastic about it.
  [V n to n]
  [Also V n]

  • He quickly converted me to the joys of cross-country skiing.

    他很快就使我迷上了越野滑雪。

8[N-COUNT 可數名詞]剛迷上…的人；最近開始熱衷於…的人 If you describe someone as a convert to something, you mean that they have recently become very enthusiastic about it.
  [usu N to n]

  • ...recent converts to vegetarianism.

    最近開始熱衷於素食主義的人

9
to preach to the converted→see: preach；

column5:
adj.可改變的；可轉換的；同意義的
n.敞篷車
column6:
(1) This sofa is convertible into a bed.
(2) This table is convertible into an ironing board.
(3) Heat is convertible into electricity.
(4) They don't have access to a convertible currency.
(5) You can hire a small convertible for $100 a day.
(6) She cruised the neighborhood in her new convertible.
column7:
(1) 這張沙發可改變成床。
(2) 這個桌子是可轉變的，而成燙衣板。
(3) 熱可以轉換為電。
(4) 他們無法得到可兌換貨幣。
(5) 你可以以100美元一天的價格租一輛敞篷車。
(6) 她乘她的敞篷車漫遊了附近地區。
column8: If it starts to rain while you』re riding in a convertible car with the top down, you can always put the top back up. Convertible is an adjective that means 「capable of changing from one form to another.」
column9: Something that is convertible can be changed or transformed from one thing to another. Money, for instance, is convertible because it can be changed from one currency to another — for example, from dollars to euros. A sofa bed is convertible because it can be transformed from a sofa into a bed. Likewise, a convertible jacket is a jacket that can be changed (by removing the sleeves or an inner lining) depending on the weather.
column11:
1[N-COUNT 可數名詞]敞篷車；折篷汽車 A convertible is a car with a soft roof that can be folded down or removed.

  • Her own car is a convertible Golf.

    她自己有一輛敞篷高爾夫。

2[ADJ 形容詞](投資工具、貨幣等)可兌換的，可轉換的 In finance, convertible investments or money can be easily exchanged for other forms of investments or money.
  [BUSINESS 商]

  • ...the introduction of a convertible currency.

    可兌換貨幣的採用

convertibility

  • ...the convertibility of the rouble.

    盧布的可兌換性

  • ...rapid export growth based on currency convertibility.

    基於貨幣自由兌換基礎上的快速出口增長

column5: vt.表達；傳達；運輸；轉移
column6:
(1) I find it hard to convey my feelings in word.
(2) Word will suffice to convey his grief.
(3) A vibrating membrane in the ear helps to convey sounds to the brain.
(4) This train conveys both passengers and goods.
(5) They asked me to convey their sincere apology to you and promised to replace these rollers by new ones.
column7:
(1) 我覺得難以用言語表達我的感情。
(2) 他的悲傷足以用言辭表達。
(3) 耳膜的振動幫助聲音傳送到大腦。
(4) 這趟列車客貨均載。
(5) 他們請我向你們轉移他們真誠的歉意，他們還保證用新滾筒替換這些滾筒。
column8: When you convey something, you carry or deliver it. Little Red Riding Hood conveyed a basket of muffins to her grandmother. Your sad smile might convey more about your feelings than words ever could.
column9: You can also convey a message or information, which means that you communicate it to someone directly or indirectly through your words or actions. In law, the word convey means to transfer or pass property to someone. This verb is from Middle English conveyen, from Old French conveier, ultimately from the Latin prefix com- "together" plus via "way."
column11:
1[VERB 動詞]傳達；表達；傳遞 To convey information or feelings means to cause them to be known or understood by someone.
  [V n]

  • When I returned home, I tried to convey the wonder of this machine to my husband...

    回到家後，我竭力地想把這台機器的精妙之處描述給丈夫聽。

  • In every one of her pictures she conveys a sense of immediacy...

    她拍的每一張照片中都傳遞出一種臨場感，使人有如親臨現場。

  • He also conveyed his views and the views of the bureaucracy.

    他也表達了自己的看法和官方的看法。

2[VERB 動詞]運輸；運送；輸送 To convey someone or something to a place means to carry or transport them there.
  [V n]
  [FORMAL 正式]

  • The railway company extended a branch line to Brightlingsea to convey fish direct to Billingsgate.

    鐵路公司修建了一條通往布賴特靈西的支線，以便直接將魚運送到比林斯門。

column5:
vt.宣判 ... 有罪；使 ... 知罪
n.囚犯；罪犯
adj.被定罪的
column6:
(1) You can't convict a man of a crime on circumstantial evidence alone.
(2) The criminal was convicted of murder.
(3) He was convicted of his errors.
(4) I'd rather die than be a convict.
(5) The convict confessed his crime.
(6) The convict has to serve his sentence.
(7) The instruction of the policeman set the convict on the right path.
(8) Let a convict person go free without any punishment.
column7:
(1) 不能只靠旁證就判定一個人有罪。
(2) 歹徒被判謀殺罪。
(3) 他認識到自己所犯的過失。
(4) 我寧願死也不願做個囚犯。
(5) 罪犯供認了他的罪行。
(6) 罪犯不得不認罰服刑。
(7) 警察的教育使這個罪犯走上了正路。
(8) 讓被定罪的人自由，不進行任何懲罰。
column8: A convict is a person who has been found guilty — convicted — of a crime and is serving a sentence in prison.
column9: When you convict (accent on the second syllable) someone of a crime, you find them guilty. The person is then a convict (accent on the first syllable). When the person is released from jail, he's an ex-con, that is, he's not a convict any more.
column11:
The verb is pronounced /kən'vɪkt/. The noun is pronounced /'kɒnvɪkt/. 動詞讀作 /kən'vɪkt/，名詞讀作 /'kɒnvɪkt/。
1[VERB 動詞]給…定罪；宣判…有罪 If someone is convicted of a crime, they are found guilty of that crime in a law court.
  [be V-ed of n/-ing]
  [V n]
  [V-ed]
  [Also V n of n]

  • In 1977 he was convicted of murder and sentenced to life imprisonment...

    1977年，他被判謀殺罪名成立，判處終身監禁。

  • There was insufficient evidence to convict him.

    沒有足夠證據給他定罪。

  • ...a convicted drug dealer.

    已定罪的毒品販子

2[N-COUNT 可數名詞]已決犯；囚犯 A convict is someone who is in prison.
  [JOURNALISM 新聞]

column5: vt.使確信；使信服；說服
column6:
(1) I try to convince him of the reality of the danger.
(2) It took many hours to convince me of his guilt.
(3) He convinced me of his sincerity.
(4) There was not an atom of evidence to convince him.
(5) Your argument is too weak to convince me.
column7:
(1) 我試圖使他相信危險的確存在。
(2) 研究了許多個小時我才相信他有罪。
(3) 他使我確信他的真誠。
(4) 沒有一點能使他信服的證據。
(5) 你的論點太薄弱了，說服不了我。
