column8: How again was it that you convinced me to do this? the boy said to his friend before they jumped out of the plane on their first sky dive. Convince means to talk someone into something, or win someone over.
column9: A person convinces by making an argument—you can convince your parents to let you go to the movies by promising you'll do all your homework the next day. A thing can convince as well. The cash prize convinced me to enter the contest. The threat of failure convinced the kids to study.
column11:
1[VERB 動詞]使確信；使信服；使相信 If someone or something convinces you of something, they make you believe that it is true or that it exists.
  [V n of n]
  [V n that]
  [Also V n]

  • Although I soon convinced him of my innocence, I think he still has serious doubts about my sanity...

    雖然我很快便讓他相信我是清白的，但是我想他仍然非常懷疑我是否神志正常。

  • The waste disposal industry is finding it difficult to convince the public that its operations are safe.

    廢物處理行業發現很難讓公眾相信其操作是安全的。

2[VERB 動詞]說服；勸服 If someone or something convinces you to do something, they persuade you to do it.
  [V n to-inf]
  [Also V n]
  [mainly AM 主美]

  • That weekend in Plattsburgh, he convinced her to go ahead and marry Bud.

    在普拉茨堡的那個週末，他說服她嫁給巴德。

column5:
v.（使）協調；（使）一致；（使）同等
n.坐標；同等的人物；配套服裝
adj.同等的；等位的；(大學)男女分院制的
column6:
(1) You must coordinate the movements of your arms and legs when swimming.
(2) If we coordinate our efforts we should be able to win the game.
(3) The filter is defined as a box of coordinates.
(4) This coordinate system is called the triad at the point.
column7:
(1) 游泳時你必須使臂和腿的動作相協調。
(2) 如果我們同心協力,我們應該能夠打贏這場比賽。
(3) 過濾器定義的是一個方框的坐標。
(4) 這個坐標系叫做該點的三面形坐標系。
column8: The word coordinate is all about getting things in order. Are your ducks in a row? Well, then you know what it means to coordinate something. And if you know exactly where to drop the bomb, then you know what the coordinates are.
column9: Coordinate is one of those words that can mean very different things but is rarely misunderstood in context. It』s a great way to describe the work of organizing, planning, and strategizing. When synchronizing the needs of two distinct groups, for instance, it is necessary to coordinate priorities and schedules. And as you speed down the highway, listening to the serene voice on your GPS announce the coordinates of your destination, chances are you don』t think she』s organizing resources.

column5: adj.豐富的；大量的；(指作家)多產的
column6:
(1) Every star is a copious source of neutrinos.
(2) He is possessed of a copious vocabulary.
(3) She supports her theory with copious evidence.
(4) She took copious notes of the professor's lecture.
(5) She was a copious writer.
column7:
(1) 每顆恆星都是豐富的中微子源。
(2) 他的詞彙量很大。
(3) 她以大量的例證來充實自己的理論。
(4) 上教授的課她記了大量的筆記。
(5) 她是一位多產作家。
column8: If you have a copious amount of something, you have a lot of it. If you take copious notes, you'll do well when it comes time for review sessions — unless you can't read your own handwriting.
column9: Copious comes from the Latin copia, meaning "abundance." You can use copious for something quantitative, like your copious admirers, or for something qualitative, like the copious gratitude you feel for your admirers. You will often see the word amounts following copious since the adjective is often used to modify a measurement of something — like copious amounts of wine or copious amounts of hair gel.
column11:
1[ADJ-GRADED 能被表示程度的副詞或介詞詞組修飾的形容詞]大量的；豐富的；充足的 A copious amount of something is a large amount of it.
  [usu ADJ n]

  • I went out for a meal last night and drank copious amounts of red wine...

    我昨晚出去吃飯，喝了很多紅酒。

  • He attended his lectures and took copious notes.

    他去聽他的課，做了大量的筆記。

copiously

  • The victims were bleeding copiously.

    受害人正在大量出血。

column5:
n.珊瑚
adj.珊瑚的；珊瑚色的
column6:
(1) Coral is formed by certain types of polyp.
(2) There are lots of coral in the sea.
(3) Although the coral is moveless , it is alive.
(4) The ship was wrecked on a coral reef.
(5) Beyond the coral reef the open sea is dark blue.
(6) It is reported that the coral reefs are being destroyed.
(7) I was going to wear a coral dress.
(8) Kate is wearing a coral necklace.
column7:
(1) 珊瑚是由某些水螅體構成的。
(2) 海裡有許多珊瑚。
(3) 珊瑚雖然一動不動,但其實是活體。
(4) 那艘船觸珊瑚礁失事。
(5) 珊瑚礁之外的大海是一片深藍色。
(6) 據報道，珊瑚礁正遭受破壞。
(7) 我將穿著珊瑚色的連衣裙。
(8) 凱特戴著一條珊瑚項煉。
column8: Coral is a marine polyp with a calcareous skeleton that lives in colonies. You probably last saw coral while scuba diving at the Great Barrier Reef. That or while looking at the coral necklaces in the beach shop.
column9: Though coral looks like stone with little holes, it is actually a kind of sea polyp with a stony, hole filled skeleton. Sometimes the word coral refers to the skeleton itself. Because of the red color of Mediterranean coral, coral is also an adjective meaning pink-red. Shakespeare wrote: 「My mistress' eyes are nothing like the sun; Coral is far more 「red than her lips' red.」 Coral can also be a noun for unfertilized lobster eggs that turn red when cooking.
column11:
1[N-VAR 可變名詞]珊瑚 Coral is a hard substance formed from the bones of very small sea animals. It is often used to make jewellery.

  • The women have elaborate necklaces of turquoise and pink coral.

    那些女人戴著由綠松石和粉色珊瑚製成的精美項鏈。

2[N-COUNT 可數名詞]珊瑚蟲 Corals are very small sea animals.
    3[COLOUR 顏色詞]珊瑚色；珊瑚紅；橘紅色 Something that is coral is dark orangey-pink in colour.

    • ...coral lipstick.

      珊瑚紅色的唇膏

    • ...the coral-colored flower buds.

      橘紅色的花蕾
